Title: 90-day ban on outdoor burning in Bastrop County, Texas
Description: Bastrop County commissioners extended a ban on outdoor burning through Nov. 9, after several brush fires, 21 citations and three warnings for violating the no burn order.  The fire restriction began in August and prohibited the ignition of any combustible material outside of an enclosure to contain the flames or sparks.  The Bastrop County emergency management coordinator stated that he intended to raise awareness of the ban and the fire danger through social media and the county’s website.  Across the state, there were 125 counties with active burn bans, according to the Texas A&M Forest Service.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 29, 2015
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Forage, hay crops, irrigated cotton in West Central Texas stressed from heat and drought
Description: Dryland cotton in West Central Texas was severely stressed by the lack of moisture and high temperatures, and even irrigated cotton was struggling.  Rangeland and pastures were drying up.  Producers were cutting hay, but yields were lower than those from earlier in the summer, due to the extremely dry weather.  Soil moisture was rapidly depleted.  Restrictions on outdoor burning remained in effect for all counties, with extremely high fire danger in areas with tall, dry forage and high winds.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 1, 2015Forage and hay crops in West Central Texas were stressed from heat and drought.  Rangeland and pastures were in fair condition, but were deteriorating quickly.Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 25, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions

Title: Livestock receiving supplemental feed in parts of South Texas; rangeland, pastures deteriorating
Description: The rangeland and pastures in the western portion of South Texas deteriorated further from the dry weather. Soil moisture was short to very short. In McMullen County, deteriorating rangeland and pastures led ranchers to wean herds to ease grazing pressure. Soil moisture was short to very short in the northern counties of South Texas. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 1, 2015Some producers in the northern and western parts of South Texas were offering supplemental feed to stocker cattle and cow-calf herds.  Forage availability and quality had declined in the western area because soil moisture was short.Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 25, 2015

Title: Burn ban in Harris County, Texas
Description: An outdoor burn ban was approved by the Commissioners Court in Harris County for the next 60 days, as requested by the county fire marshal.  Open-flame barbeque pit fires and campfires in designated rings were still allowed.  The Keetch-Byram Drought Index for Harris County was 670 on Aug. 11, compared to a typical August value of 400 to 600.Despite heavy rainfall and flooding in May and June, high temperatures dried out the area to the extent that the fire danger was a concern.  This is Harris County’s first open burn ban since the 2011 drought.Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 11, 2015
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Heat, drought of late summer halved cotton yields in Texas panhandle, West Texas
Description: The hot, dry August and September weather cut into high cotton yields in the Texas panhandle and West Texas where lush spring rains promised a good crop.  A sorely disappointed Howard County farmer expected about 10,000 bales from his 6,500 acres of cotton fields, but has realized he’ll only get about 4,000 bales.  In Midland, the farmers’ co-op cotton gin baled just 1,300 bales of cotton, considerably fewer than at this time in past years.  Adding to farmers’ problems were the weak prices for cotton since 2011, while production costs remained high.Midland Reporter-Telegram (Texas), Nov. 8, 2015

Title: Fireworks prohibited in unincorporated El Paso County, Texas
Description: The sale and use of fireworks in unincorporated El Paso County was prohibited on the Fourth of July for the fifth straight year.  The county judge issued a declaration of local disaster, valid for 60 hours, as drought conditions continued to intensify.  It was hoped that Gov. Greg Abbott would extend the declaration through midnight on July 5.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 22, 2015
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Limestone County, Texas, dry soils, pastures dead, farmers depleting hay stores to feed cows, low water levels
Description: Limestone County Texas is currently in a state of exceptional drought.  The last significant precipitation at this station was on June 17, 2015, and the only measurable precipitation during that period was 0.06 on August 21, 2015. At Station TX-LT-4, Crockett 2 soils are dry, packed, with deep cracks; native and domestic grasses in pastures are dead, and native ferns are dormant or dying.  Older trees are still in remarkably good shape, thanks to last years' spring rains.  Wildfires have been common here, with losses of hay and pasture in Shiloh VFD fire district, and the threat to animals and humans lives is great.  Ponds to mid sized reservoirs are at 1/2 to 3/4 capacity; larger reservoirs are faring better due to soaring rains.  Hay that was harvested in the early summer is being depleted due to use for animals this fall; most pastures are no longer able to support large animal operations.  The main economic impact of the current drought so far has been on cow-calf operations, who are being forced to use up valuable winter hay stores before the fall is halfway over; a hay shortage may occur in small- to mid-sized operations.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Mexia 5.9 S on 10/22/2015
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Limestone County, TX

Title: The North Texas Municipal Water District dredging Lavon Lake, Lake Jim Chapman
Description: The North Texas Municipal Water District is preparing to dredge Lavon Lake to clear away silt built up near the intake channels of the pump stations.  With the silt removed, the district can access 86,000 acre-feet of water that would otherwise be unusable if the lake level falls below 470 feet.  A dredging project is also in the works at Lake Jim Chapman to allow better access to the water.Plano Star-Courier (Texas), Feb. 19, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Collin County, TX, Delta County, TX, Hopkins County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority in Texas lowered its water supply projections by about 17 percent
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority lowered its water supply projections by about 17 percent following the revelation that the drought affecting the Highlands Lakes was the worst the area has endured since the 1930s when the lakes were constructed.  The inflow into the lakes was the second lowest ever recorded, leading the LCRA to recognize the situation as a new “critical period.”  The Highland Lakes were significantly above their record lows, due to prudent water management choices.KVUE-TV ABC Austin (Texas), Feb. 18, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Small towns in Palo Pinto, Parker counties in Texas urgently seeking water
Description: The communities of Gordon, Strawn and Mingus were on the verge of running out of water and were looking for groundwater in Erath and Eastland counties.  Those communities and the Barton Water Supply Cooperative sought $2 million worth of emergency grants from the Texas Water Development Board.Mineral Wells’ reverse-osmosis plant to treat water from the Brazos River is expected to be operational before Lake Palo Pinto goes dry, possibly as soon as July 1, said the secretary and treasurer of Palo Pinto County Municipal Water District No. 1.  A new reverse-osmosis plant in Parker County will also draw from the Brazos River, thereby decreasing their reliance on Mineral Wells.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Jan. 16, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Gordon, TX, Mingus, TX, Strawn, TX, Parker County, TX

Title: Drought-Related USDA Disaster Declarations in 2015
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture began declaring counties as primary and secondary disaster areas related to drought in January, for the 2015 growing season. Farmers in affected counties have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for low-interest emergency loans. For more information, agricultural producers should contact their Farm Service Agency office. From Farm Service Agency press releases.

Title: Wholesale water priced at drought rate for Lower Colorado River Authority in Texas
Description: The 2015 drought rate of $175 per acre-foot of water was reduced to the new firm water rate of $145 per acre-foot on Nov. 18 after the Lower Colorado River Authority Board of Directors lowered the wholesale water rates for cities and industry.  The LCRA withheld water from downstream rice farmers for several years and the lost revenue forced the nonprofit river authority to raise wholesale water rates to cover fixed costs.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 18, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: El Paso, Texas water utility drawing more water from Hueco Bolson aquifer
Description: The El Paso Water Utility has pumped more water than usual from the Hueco Bolson aquifer to replace water normally taken from the Rio Grande River.  The chief executive officer with the utility said that such pumping was not a sustainable option and that drought-proof components must be added to the utility’s water options.El Paso Times (Texas), Dec. 9, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Paso County, TX, El Paso, TX

Title: City council in Odessa, Texas offered more than $38 million to boost production from Ward County well fields
Description: The Colorado River Municipal Water District board members turned down a $38 million offer by City of Odessa officials to increase production at the Ward County well fields.Odessa American (Texas), Feb. 25, 2015The Odessa City Council decided to offer more than $38 million to the Colorado River Municipal Water District to increase the water production of the Ward County well fields to provide additional water to supplement surface water from reservoirs during times of drought.  The city council would like to see well output increased from the current withdrawal rate of 45 million gallons daily to 65 million gallons daily.  The mayor stated that the city’s water supply was a hindrance to luring businesses to Odessa.Odessa American (Texas), Nov. 26, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Odessa, TX, Ward County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority seeking permission to cut irrigation water releases from Highland Lakes
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority is seeking permission from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality to cut the amount of water it releases from the Highland Lakes for irrigation for the fourth straight year.  Water releases take place for six weeks in late spring to aid spawning of blue sucker fish.  “This was not an easy decision, but we must protect the region’s water supply,” said the LCRA’s General Manager Phil Wilson. “More than a million people depend on water from the Highland Lakes, and right now, there is just not enough water for everyone to have all they want."Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 19, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Big boats cannot be launched at Cooper Lake in Texas due to low water level
Description: Boaters cannot launch big boats from ramps on Cooper Lake after the water level dropped significantly in October.  Lake Tawakoni was low also.Tyler Morning Telegraph (Texas), Nov. 5, 2014
Places: Delta County, TX, Hunt County, TX, Rains County, TX, Van Zandt County, TX

Title: Most West Central Texas wheat growers waiting for rain before planting
Description: Some West Central Texas farmers planted their wheat, but most growers were waiting for rain before planting.  Some early-planted small grains showed signs of moisture stress.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 4, 2014
Places: Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Concho County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Irion County, TX, Jones County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Sterling County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Most Bermuda grass fields in Central Texas continued to recover from drought
Description: Most Bermuda grass fields in Central Texas continued to recover from drought.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 4, 2014
Places: Bell County, TX, Bosque County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Erath County, TX, Falls County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Hamilton County, TX, Hill County, TX, Hood County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Leon County, TX, Limestone County, TX, McLennan County, TX, Milam County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Somervell County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Wheat moisture-stressed, dying in Glasscock County, Texas
Description: Wheat was moisture-stressed in Glasscock County.  Newly emerged stands were struggling and some of those were beginning to die.  Some wheat did not emerge well, resulting in skimpy stands.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 4, 2014
Places: Glasscock County, TX

Title: Forage condition declined in Jim Wells County, Texas
Description: Forage condition declined in Jim Wells County due to the lack of rain.  Soil moisture remained short throughout most of South Texas.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 4, 2014
Places: Jim Wells County, TX

Title: Drought may be responsible for reduction in rangia clam population in Galveston Bay in Texas
Description: Scientists studying rangia clams found fewer of them in 2014 than in past years in the northeast inlet of Galveston Bay, suggesting to scientists that there was not enough fresh water flowing into the bay from the Trinity River.  Rangia clams are found near sources of fresh water and do not reproduce or mature when the water is too salty.  Because the mollusk is not commercially harvested, its location and abundance has not been closely monitored, except in connection with oyster surveys. One marine biologist noted that the clams' population had been on the decline for decades, before the current multi-year drought and the widening of the shipping channel.Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Oct. 31, 2014
Places: Chambers County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Harris County, TX

Title: Low stock tank levels were becoming a serious concern for some ranchers in West Central Texas
Description: Low water levels in stock tanks were becoming a serious concern for some ranchers in West Central Texas.  The Charlotte Observer (N.C.), Oct. 28, 2014
Places: Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Concho County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Irion County, TX, Jones County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Sterling County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Property valuations around Lake Travis in Texas continued to rise, despite the low level of the lake
Description: Property valuations around Lake Travis continued to rise, despite the low level of the lake and increasing distances from the shoreline to homes that were once waterfront property.  Lake Travis has fallen to 41 feet below average.  Some residents have appealed the appraisal of their land and received decreases on the assessments of their property due to drought.  Real estate agents agree that the land around the lake has less value than it did before the drought and that the Travis County appraisal district’s opinion does not reflect drought's effect on the value of homes that are at least temporarily no longer waterfront properties.  This year property values established by the Travis Central Appraisal District increased 6.5 percent, while in Travis County, property values went up overall by 11 percent.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Oct. 27, 2014
Places: Burnet County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Continued water conservation in the North Texas Municipal Water District
Description: Customers of the North Texas Municipal Water District were asked to curb sprinkler use to once every two weeks from Nov. 1 through March 31, 2015.  The district’s reservoirs were very low from years of drought.  Lake Lavon was 12.53 feet below conservation level, Jim Chapman Lake was 11.59 feet low and Tawakoni was 11.3 feet low.  Lakes Lavon and Chapman held less than 50 percent of capacity.  Lake Texoma, which provides about 25 percent of the district’s water, is so salty that it must be mixed with “sweeter” water from Lavon and Chapman at a ratio of 4:1.Dallas Morning News, Oct. 23, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: All boat ramps closed at Eagle Mountain Lake near Fort Worth, Texas
Description: Ongoing drought dropped lake levels to the point that many boat ramps were no longer useable in north central Texas.  The last accessible boat ramp at Eagle Mountain Lake was closed mid-September when water levels fell to a critical point.  At Benbrook Lake, the only open boat ramp was at Mustang Park.  Many boat ramps were closed at Lake Grapevine, but most ramps were open at Joe Pool Lake, Lewisville Lake and Lake Ray Roberts.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 18, 2014

Title: Salamanders collected from wild to protect endangered species near San Marcos, Texas
Description: San Marcos salamanders were collected from Spring Lake and will be housed in the San Marcos Aquatic Resources Center’s refuge facilities to have some creatures in reserve in the event that a dramatic change would take place in their habitat, devastating the population.  Drought has led biologists to monitor the salamanders’ habitat more and think about how they could increase their holding capacity to keep more salamanders.Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Oct. 8, 2014
Places: Hays County, TX

Title: 90-day burn ban for Tarrant County, Texas
Description: Tarrant County commissioners enacted a ban on outdoor burning for 90 days beginning Oct. 7, 2014, because the drought index rose in the preceding six weeks.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 7, 2014
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: Voluntary Irrigation Suspension Program for the Edwards Aquifer Authority in south Texas
Description: The Edwards Aquifer Authority will offer the Voluntary Irrigation Suspension Program Option in 2015.  The program conserves water in the aquifer by giving payments to farmers and other heavy water users in exchange for them not irrigating.  The VISPO became an option for irrigators because the J-17 index well in Bexar County fell below the historic average of 630.6 feet above sea level, triggering the use of the no-irrigation program.Landowners will leave about 39,000 acre-feet in the aquifer, or nearly 7 percent of the EAA’s total permitted pumping.  Farmers and others will receive $8 million from pumping and customer fees and contributions.My San Antonio.com (Texas), Oct. 1, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Medina County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority plans new reservoir in Wharton County, Texas
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority approved plans on Sept. 17 to construct a new reservoir near Lane City in Wharton County.  Their aim is to bolster the water supply for the basin by locating the $214.9 million reservoir in an area that receives about twice as much rainfall as the Highland Lakes.  The LCRA estimates that the new reservoir will provide an average of 90,000 acre-feet annually to the LCRA’s total water supply.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Oct. 8, 2014

Title: Extreme heat and drought have hindered agriculture in South Texas
Description: Livestock producers in northern South Texas continued giving supplemental feed to cattle because rangeland and pastures were in poor condition.  Soil moisture remained short across much of the region.In eastern South Texas, soil moisture remained short to very short in Jim Hogg and Jim Wells counties.Producers in western South Texas continued the supplemental feeding and light culling of livestock.  Producers who could irrigate were pre-watering fields before planting wheat because soil moisture was short to very short.Odessa American (Texas), Sept. 9, 2014Forage supplies in the northern part of South Texas were not plentiful, and livestock producers were purchasing hay for supplemental feed.  Stock tank water levels were dropping rapidly.  Ranchers had to move cattle from some pastures for lack of water.  In eastern South Texas, rangeland and pastures deteriorated with little to no rain.  Livestock producers in western South Texas increased supplemental feeding because poor forage quality and declining cattle body conditions warranted action.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), Sept. 3, 2014Extreme heat and drought have hindered agriculture in South Texas, where rangeland and pastures were deteriorating.In the northern part of the region, ongoing limited forage availability was a problem in some areas.  Stock tanks were rapidly drying down as heat and evaporation took their toll.  In the eastern part of the region, forages dried out unusually fast due to extreme heat and strong winds; and soil moisture was short to very short.  Producers in Jim Hogg County were feeding corn and hay to livestock and wildlife to compensate for the lack of nutritional range and pastureland forages.Ranchers in the western part of South Texas had reduced stocking rates, so not as much supplemental feeding was needed, but the need for supplemental feeding increased as pastures deteriorated.  High evaporation rates kept water levels in stock tanks falling.  In the southern part of the region, soil moisture was short to very short, and range and pasture conditions were slipping with high temperatures and strong winds.Austin American Statesman (Texas), Aug. 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Dimmit County, TX, Duval County, TX, Frio County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Jim Wells County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Live Oak County, TX, Maverick County, TX, McMullen County, TX, Starr County, TX, Webb County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Drought continued to hinder agriculture in Texas
Description: Drought continued to hinder agriculture in Texas even while parts of the state have received rain and emerged somewhat from drought.  Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service agents shared how dry conditions were affecting their parts of the state. In Lynn County, crops are stressed by the hot dry conditions, despite the use of irrigation systems.  Pasture conditions in Kaufman County have deteriorated, due to the hot, dry weather.  Ward County ranchers were also seeing a deterioration of range conditions and were weaning and shipping calves early as a result.  The hot, dry conditions stopped all hay operations in Burnet County and have increased the fire danger.  Pastures and timber stands in Orange County were stressed by the heat and lack of rain.  Timber die off has been more noticeable during the past month.  The lack of rain has stressed livestock production in Uvalde County and may force ranchers to sell cattle soon.Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Aug. 25, 2014
Places: Burnet County, TX, Kaufman County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Orange County, TX, Uvalde County, TX, Ward County, TX

Title: Barge in use to draw water from Lake Bridgeport in northern Texas
Description: A barge with intake pumps was installed several hundred yards from the shore of  Lake Bridgeport in case the lake fell below intake pipes for the Walnut Creek Special Utility District. The lake has fallen about 23 feet, including 3 feet in the last year, and if drought continues, it could be below the intake pipes by October 2014. The Walnut Creek and Brazos Electric Power Cooperative worked together to protect their water intakes as the lake level dropped.  The barge can be moved 1,000 feet to a deeper part of the lake if needed and supports two rotating pumps which can take up to 15 million gallons out of the lake daily. Lake Bridgeport is the main water source for Walnut Creek Special Utility District, which supplies water to Rhome, Boyd, Paradise and several other cities.  Brazos Electric  was using  6.5 million gallons per day from the barge for  a power plant in Jack County.  The project cost $860,000.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Aug. 28, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Jack County, TX, Springtown, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: Victoria County, Texas, wells going dry
Description: Read in the Sunday Victoria Advocate that a well and possibly more than one had gone dry at 70 feet around the Nursery, Texas area.  This was reported on the editorial page and not reported by an official.  My well is 90 feet and although I am seeing more minerals when the water dries, we still have water.  Very worrisome!  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Nursery 0.4 NNW on 8/19/2014
Places: Victoria County, TX

Title: Stage 4 water restrictions for the Guadalupe-Blanco River Authority in  Texas
Description: The Guadalupe-Blanco River Authority entered stage 4 water restrictions because the average 24-hour spring flow rate from Comal Springs was 94 cubic feet per second, below the trigger of 100 cubic feet per second.  There are tighter limits on landscape watering, pool filling and vehicle washing, among other things.New Braunfels Herald-Zeitung (Texas), Aug. 11, 2014

Title: Oyster production was down along the Texas Gulf Coast, due to drought and other factors
Description: Oyster production was down along the Texas Gulf Coast as sediment from Hurricane Ike in 2008, warmer water temperatures, higher salinity due to drought, and greater water consumption have all contributed to the decline in the oyster population.  Parasites and disease are more of a problem for oysters when the salinity is higher.  Fewer oysters means higher prices.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 5, 2014

Title: Biodegradable product in use to reduce evaporation near Wichita Falls, Texas
Description: The evaporation suppression powder used on Arrowhead Lake during the 2014 summer was successful, said representatives of Flexible Solutions International, Inc. of Victoria, British Columbia.  A report by the Texas Water Development Board said the measure may have reduced normal evaporation by 15 percent.  Wichita Falls officials were evaluating the report and considered it inconclusive.  The city spent about $294,000 on the project.Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Jan. 28, 2015Wichita Falls water authorities began using a biodegradable palm oil and lime based product to reduce evaporation from Arrowhead Lake, which has dropped to 22 percent of capacity.  The pilot project, which started on July 23 and will last for 75 days, will cost the city $375,000.  Crews must reapply 5,700 pounds of the mixture every three days to replace the biodegradable material as it breaks down.  CBS, Aug. 4, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Archer County, TX, Clay County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wichita Falls, TX

Title: Crop production around Fort Worth, Texas slowed by late spring freeze, below normal precipitation
Description: A late spring freeze and below normal rainfall has slowed crop production in the Fort Worth area.  A Cisco farmer lost his tomatoes to an April 15 freeze and needs more moisture for his crops.  Many farmers have purchased irrigation systems to cope with the dry weather.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), June 9, 2014

Title: Burn and fireworks ban in Ector County, Texas
Description: A burn ban took effect in Ector County for the next 90 days after county commissioners voted in favor of the ban on June 9.  They also banned rockets with sticks and missiles with fins for the Fourth of July.Odessa American (Texas), June 9, 2014

Title: Most wheat being grazed in West Central Texas
Description: Most wheat in West Central Texas was being grazed because drought damage left it too poor to harvest.  Of the wheat to be harvested for grain, yields were expected to be low.Recent rainfall helped the region.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 2, 2014

Title: Drought surcharge for water customers in western Travis County, Texas
Description: The West Travis County Public Utility Agency approved a 20 percent drought surcharge for all water customers starting in July.  Water conservation resulted in reduced revenue for the WTCPUA, while fixed costs mean that the utility must increase revenue, which will happen through the drought surcharge.  Unfilled salary positions have remained unfilled and other measures were taken to cut costs, but the WTCPUA has little choice but to adopt the drought surcharge.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 28, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Fire in Texas Panhandle consumed 156 structures
Description: A fire in Hutchinson County, Texas burned 156 structures, including at least 89 homes, said a spokesman for the Texas A&M Forest Service.  Roughly 2,100 people were evacuated from their homes.  The blaze was 65 percent contained on the evening of May 12.  The region was in exceptional drought.ABC News (New York), May 12, 2014
Places: Hutchinson County, TX, Fritch, TX, Sanford, TX

Title: Kendall County, Texas, cracked, dry dirt, water restrictions
Description: Noticed soil shrinkage starting this spring, resulting in a long crack in backyard several feet long.  Two trees near a wet weather creek have died; estimated benefits per tree (according to http://www.treebenefits.com/) is $71.  Kendall West Utility is currently in Stage II restrictions, with sprinklers only allowed during certain hours 2x per week.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Boerne 2.2 WNW on 6/20/2014
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kendall County, TX

Title: Dry, windy, dusty conditions worrying farmers in the South Plains of Texas
Description: Wind, blowing dirt and the continued absence of rain in the South Plains of Texas worried crop producers.  Some farmers were planning to plant irrigated cotton in the next few weeks, but there would be no dryland cotton without substantial rain in the very near future.  A big dust storm blew out sunflowers in Hale County.Pastures in Swisher County were not producing enough vegetation to feed many cattle and were starting to show leaf curl and other signs of moisture stress.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014

Title: Persistent drought in Rolling Plains of Texas, forcing herd sellouts, water shortages, restrictions
Description: The sky in the Rolling Plains of Texas had a brown tint most of the week of April 28 through May 4 as strong winds blew the dry, dusty soil.  Farmers were cutting their small grains for hay.  Cotton growers were waiting for rain before planting.  In the southwestern part of the Rolling Plains, some ranchers were looking at the prospect of having to sell their entire herd.  Just as farmers and ranchers were struggling to cope with drought, municipal water users in towns were enduring water restrictions and shortages.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014

Title: Central Texas wheat not doing well; rangeland, pastures in worst condition since 2009
Description: Small grain fields were plowed under or harvested for forage in Central Texas because drought prevented them from producing harvestable grain.  Recent rains improved soil moisture, rangeland and some crops, but more was needed to fill stock ponds.Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 10, 2014The best wheat fields in Central Texas were anticipated to yield 35 bushels per acre, but drought and freeze damage is expected to drop the yield some.  Rangeland has not been in such poor condition since 2009.  Clay soils were powder dry.Corn and sorghum need rain soon if they are to produce a crop.  Farmers were baling oats, wheat and rye grass for hay with the expectation that drought would persist through the summer.  Stock pond water was low.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014

Description: Coastal Bend pastures remained in good to poor condition, despite rain in recent weeks. Title: The wells of roughly two dozen homeowners north of Lubbock, Texas run dry when cotton farmers irrigate their crops
Description: The wells of roughly two dozen homeowners north of Lubbock run dry when cotton farmers irrigate their crops.  This has been a recurring event during irrigation lasting for weeks or months since drought took hold in the region years ago.  Regional water supplies in general were low, but years of drought have drawn down groundwater levels to the point that shallow wells produce little to nothing when deep wells are in use.Another resident who still has water, worries that he too may be out of water soon because his neighbor irrigates so much.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 27, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lubbock County, TX

Title: Insects thriving during drought in Wichita Falls, Texas
Description: Ticks were more of a problem than usual in Wichita Falls because drought offers ideal conditions for ticks’ eggs to hatch.  Other insects, such as roaches, ants, fleas and mosquitoes, also seem to be thriving during drought.Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), April 17, 2014
Places: Wichita County, TX, Wichita Falls, TX

Title: Drought exposed truck in Lake Granbury in Hood County, Texas, explaining disappearance of woman nearly 35 years ago
Description: The drought-depleted level of Lake Granbury exposed a pickup truck containing the skeletal remains of a woman last seen nearly 35 years ago when she vanished after an argument with her husband, who has also since died.The pickup was located about 15 feet from the normal shoreline and would have been in 15 to 16 feet of murky water if the lake were full.  The location of the truck was not near a roadway, suggesting to law enforcement that foul play was involved and that this was not the result of an accident.  The Hood County sheriff said that the investigation into the woman’s death will continue.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), April 19, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Hood County, TX

Title: Consumption advisory for Lubbock, Texas
Description: A consumption advisory was issued for Lubbock because one of its water sources, Lake Alan Henry in Garza County, held less than 65 percent of capacity.  The lake was created 20 years ago at an expense of $245 million.  The lake lost about 4 billion gallons to evaporation in 2011, according to the Lubbock Avalanche-Journal.My San Antonio.com (Texas), April 15, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Garza County, TX, Lubbock, TX

Title: Ranchers in the Rolling Plains of Texas tried to protect pastures  by rotating cattle to avoid overgrazing
Description: Ranchers in the Rolling Plains of Texas tried to protect pastures  by rotating cattle to avoid overgrazing, but it did not help much.  While farmers had prepared fields for spring planting, high winds led to blowouts and the need to go over the plowed ground again.  Several counties had burn bans.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014

Title: Stage 4 pumping restrictions for groundwater permit holders in the San Antonio Pool of the Edwards Aquifer Authority in Texas
Description: The Edwards Aquifer Authority entered stage IV restrictions, an unprecedented move requiring a 40 percent reduction in pumping from the aquifer.  The increase in restrictions was triggered by the 10-day well average falling below 630 feet above sea level.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Aug. 12, 2014The J-17 monitoring well in Bexar County fell to 629.6 feet above sea level on Aug. 6.  If the well remains at or below 630 feet above sea level, it will trigger stage IV restrictions in the Edwards Aquifer Authority’s critical period plan, requiring a 40 percent reduction in pumping.  The Edwards Aquifer was 13.4 feet lower than one year ago and fell nearly 10 feet in the last two weeks.  At Comal Springs, the water flowed at 101 cubic feet per second on Aug. 6 and may lead to stage IV restrictions if the flow drops below 100 cubic feet per second.My San Antonio.com (Texas), Aug. 6, 2014The Edwards Aquifer Authority (EAA) declared Stage 3 pumping reductions for users within the San Antonio Pool. Stage 3 of the EAA’s drought plan requires Edwards groundwater permit holders in Bexar and Medina counties, and parts of Atascosa, Caldwell, Comal, Guadalupe and Hays counties to reduce their annual authorized pumping by 35 percent. The EAA declared Stage 3 based on declining water level readings at the J17 index well in Bexar County. On April 10, the 10-day average dropped below the Stage 3 trigger of 640 feet above sea level. Stage 3 will remain in effect as long as the water level of the monitoring well stays below this threshold. The San Antonio Pool was previously in Stage 3 from December 16, 2013 – January 3 of this year. Edwards Aquifer Authority (San Antonio, Texas), April 10, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Medina County, TX

Title: Val Verde County, Texas, livestock requires extra feed and water
Description: Extreme drought, no grasses, sparse vegetation, much less than normal. Requires extra feed and water for stock and wildlife.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Comstock 29.7 NW on 5/7/2014
Places: Val Verde County, TX

Title: Farm family in Matagorda County, Texas growing corn instead of rice
Description: A Matagorda County farm family that usually grows rice has switched to 700 acres of corn this year because the Lower Colorado River Authority was not providing water for rice growers for the third consecutive year.  Corn provides about half  as much income per acre as rice does, but the family needs to grow some crop to have an income.  The family has returned two of three combine harvesters that they leased from a dealership.  Three combines were needed in 2011 to harvest the rice crop, but the lack of irrigation water since 2012 means that one combine can easily harvest any small amount of rice they might be able to grow.  The patriarch of the family lays awake at night, worrying about the future of the farm, his sons and grandsons because there isn’t as much money in corn as there is in rice.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), April 6, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Matagorda County, TX

Title: Hay suppliers in Central Texas have no hay to sell
Description: The Feed Station, a livestock supply store just west of Oak Hill, began carrying pelletized packaged hay because the hay suppliers in Central Texas have no hay to sell, due to the drought.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 6, 2014

Title: High hay prices in Burnet County, Texas
Description: Grasses were dead in Burnet County after a dry, cold winter.  Hay prices have risen from $85 per bale to $100, said an agriculture and natural resources extension agent for Burnet County.  Horse-quality hay rose from $100 in 2011 to $145 at present.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 6, 2014
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Ongoing drought brought about the proliferation of tumbleweeds in southeastern Colorado, parts of New Mexico and the Texas panhandle
Description: Ongoing drought brought about the proliferation of tumbleweeds in southeastern Colorado, parts of New Mexico and the Texas panhandle.  Rainfall in September 2013 spurred the growth of the Russian thistles, which grew well with little moisture in places where much of the native vegetation was sparse or had died from the drought.  There were also fewer cattle in many areas as drought led ranchers to sell livestock, leaving fewer ruminants to nibble on the Russian thistle shoots.  The tumbleweeds are abundant in many areas, blocking roads and drainage culverts and piling up against fences and homes.In Fountain, Colorado, just southeast of Colorado Springs, a windstorm blew an incredible number of tumbleweeds into town, building mounds more than 10 feet high that residents strove to rake together and bag to get rid of them.An older couple in Clovis, New Mexico was trapped in their home in January when it became engulfed in tumbleweeds.  "I looked out the window to see why it got so dark all of a sudden, and they were over 12-feet high, blocking my front and back doors," the man said. "We couldn't get out."A neighbor managed to dig through and get into the garage to free the couple.Tumbleweeds have been an ongoing problem in Crowley County, New Mexico where they continue to make travel on some roads very difficult.Baltimore Sun (Md.), March 27, 2014

Title: Dryland wheat in West Central Texas was deteriorating; rangeland in bad shape
Description: The dry, windy and warm conditions continued in West Central Texas, elevating the fire danger as temperatures rose into the triple digits.  Wheat remained in very poor condition, with most of it being grazed.  A small portion of the wheat crop was to be harvested, but yields will likely be very low.  Low subsoil moisture will probably delay cotton planting in coming weeks.  The drought kept farmers from planting summer annuals because seed was too expensive to gamble that rain will fall to water the crop.  Ranchers continued to feed their livestock as some rangeland and pasture manifesting signs of moisture stress.  Water supplies were on the decline.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014The growth and development of all small grains in West Central Texas was limited by warm, dry and windy conditions, and some fields were already a total loss.  Other wheat fields were very short with spotty stands and were in poor to fair condition.  Stock tank levels continued to decline and were presently a problem for some farmers.  Heavy supplemental feeding continued for all livestock.The fire danger increased with the dry, windy conditions.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014Dryland wheat in West Central Texas was deteriorating and manifested signs of drought stress.  Rangeland and pastures were in poor condition and were also deteriorating.  Soil moisture was very low, and extreme fire danger was increasing.  Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014

Title: Dry winter killed much vegetation in pastures in Central Texas
Description: The dry winter killed much vegetation in pastures in Central Texas.  Producers continued culling cattle, due to ongoing drought.  Poor moisture reserves did not encourage good corn germination, leaving spotty stands. Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014

Title: Low soil moisture hindered Texas Panhandle farmers who were preparing their fields, some fields a total loss
Description: Cattle on the range in the Texas Panhandle needed supplemental feed because there was not enough vegetation growing to sustain the cattle.  Ranchers sold cattle if they did not have wheat for the cattle to graze.  Soil moisture was short to very short.  Winter wheat was in fair to very poor condition.  Some Ochiltree County farmers have crop insurance adjusters to assess their fields.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014Windblown soil erosion was a problem throughout the Texas Panhandle where drought conditions were worse than in other parts of the state.  Dryland wheat growers in Wheeler County have brought in crop insurance adjusters to witness the devastation caused by drought, said the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  Even irrigated wheat manifested signs of drought damage.Wildfires charred roughly 10,000 acres in Lipscomb County over the past three weeks, according to the AgriLife Extension agent in the county.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014.Low soil moisture hindered Texas Panhandle farmers who were preparing their fields for the upcoming growing season.  High winds further depleted soil moisture.  Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014

Title: Stock water tanks were low in South Texas as dry conditions persist, pastures deteriorating
Description: Drought caused South Texas pastures to deteriorate, and soil moisture was short to very short throughout the region.  The fire threat remained high with all of the dry vegetation.Atascosa County ranchers bought hay for supplemental feeding, and McMullen County ranchers also continued supplemental feeding.  In Webb County, ranchers were holding off on restocking cattle and livestock until the rangeland recovers.  Stock tank water levels were low.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014Stock water tanks were low in South Texas as dry conditions persist.  Soil moisture was short to very short in the northern portion of South Texas.  Rangeland and pastures were in fair condition as spring greening begins.  Cattle body condition scores in some places were slipping.   Forage production in Jim Wells County was better than it had been, but more rain and warm temperatures were needed to boost forage growth.  The wheat yield in the county was in question due to a lack of rain early in its growing period.Forage in Webb County has not recovered from previous drought, prompting producers to sell some cattle until the forage is healthier.Drovers Cattle Network (Lenexa, Kan.), March 26, 2014

Title: Planted crop acreage remained lower than usual in south Texas
Description: Planted crop acreage remained lower than usual in south Texas as the area struggles with drought and Mexico’s failure to comply with the 1944 water treaty, under which it owes the U.S. 860,000 acre-feet which it must deliver by October 2015.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), March 24, 2014
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Eighty-seven percent of dryland wheat crop in the High Plains and Rolling Plains of Texas rated in fair to very poor conditions
Description: Eighty-seven percent of the dryland wheat crop in the High Plains and Rolling Plains of Texas was rated in fair to very poor conditions as dry weather takes a toll on the crop, according to Dr. Travis Miller, an AgriLife Extension agronomist and Texas A&M University soil and crop sciences associate department head.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 23, 2014

Title: Water releases into and from the Rio Grande River for the irrigation season in southern New Mexico and El Paso, Texas delayed
Description: Water releases into and from the Rio Grande River for the irrigation season in southern New Mexico and El Paso, Texas were delayed from a typical March start to June 1, due to ongoing drought, said the president and CEO of El Paso Water Utilities Co.  All parties in New Mexico; El Paso, Texas and Mexico agreed with a June 1 start date.Drought in 2013 also led to delayed water releases beginning on June 1.El Paso Times (Texas), March 13, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dona Ana County, NM, Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: Many counties in the Texas Panhandle banned outdoor burning
Description: Many counties in the Texas Panhandle banned outdoor burning, due to the ongoing dry, windy and warm conditions.  Counties on the northern and southern edges of the panhandle, such as Dallam, Hartley, Sherman, Hansford, Ochiltree, Lipscomb, Collingsworth, Hall, Briscoe and Swisher do not have burn bans.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), March 12, 2014
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Carson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Moore County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Abundance of tumbleweeds in Texas Panhandle
Description: The abundance of tumbleweeds was causing problems for Randall County residents, prompting county officials to remind the public that the burn ban also applies to annoying tumbleweeds.  People were urged to crush them and put them in the trash, haul them to landfills or shred them with a mower when the humidity exceeds 15 percent.Tumbleweeds were also “terrorizing” the better part of the Texas Panhandle as drought allowed tumbleweeds to thrive while other vegetation did not.  Southeastern Colorado was also trying to get a handle on a bumper crop of tumbleweeds.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), March 12, 2014
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Dust storm rolled across West Texas
Description: A wall of dust up to 1,000 feet tall and 200 miles wide rolled across West Texas and New Mexico on the evening of March 112, as drought continues to impact the region.  Strong winds from a cold front stirred up the dust, reducing visibility to roughly one mile in Lubbock and to zero in Muleshoe and Friona.  The dust storm started in Amarillo and stretched from the New Mexico border east to Post.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 12, 2014

Title: Hydropower production down in central Texas
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority has generated less hydropower from its six dams as drought reduces the amount of water flowing in the Colorado River.  In early 2014, the LCRA produced roughly one-third of the hydropower it generated in 2011.  The executive manager of water operations at the LCRA said that water levels could drop too low to turn the generators within several years.Of the power produced by the LCRA from power plants and hydropower, less than 6 percent comes from the dams on the Colorado River, whereas most of its power previously came from hydropower prior to the mid-1960s.  Water managers do not often use the generators to their full potential and only use the generators when water is being released downstream for other purposes.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), March 10, 2014
Places: Austin County, TX, Bastrop County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Colorado County, TX, DeWitt County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Gonzales County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Lavaca County, TX, Lee County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Travis County, TX, Waller County, TX, Washington County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Texas rice growers on Lower Colorado River to go without water for third year
Description: While rice farmers on the Lower Colorado River did not expect to get water, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality sealed their fate by postponing a decision on trigger levels for releasing water from lakes Travis and Buchanan.  This is the third straight year without water for rice growers.KXAN-TV NBC 36 Austin (Texas), Feb. 26, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Llano County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Frustrated residents around Lake Texoma  on the Oklahoma/Texas border feel that too much water is being taken from the lake
Description: Frustrated residents around Lake Texoma feel that too much water is being taken from the lake for hydropower generation, and the low lake levels hurt the area’s economy.KGOU-FM (Norman, Okla.), Jan. 28, 2014
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bryan County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Cooke County, TX, Grayson County, TX

Title: Dryland winter wheat in Texas panhandle threatened by dry conditions
Description: Dryland wheat growers in Wheeler County brought in crop insurance adjusters to witness the devastation caused by drought, said the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  Even irrigated wheat manifested signs of drought damage.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 13, 2014.Winter wheat in the Texas panhandle was struggling and needs moisture.  Texas A&M AgriLife Research wheat breeder Jackie Rudd and AgriLife Extension small grains specialist Clark Neely said that the dry conditions are a major problem for the winter wheat and may kill the dryland wheat if there isn’t precipitation soon.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), Jan. 27, 2014

Title: Ongoing drought keeps ban on outdoor burning in many Texas panhandle counties
Description: Drought led many counties in the Texas panhandle to keep in plance bans on outdoor burning, due to the fire risk.  According to the Texas A&M Forest Service, counties with bans include Armstrong, Childress, Deaf Smith, Donley, Hemphill, Hutchinson, Moore, Parmer, Randall, Roberts and Wheeler.Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), Jan. 27, 2014

Title: Wheat not fully emerged in Hardeman County, Texas
Description: About 85 percent of the acres planted with wheat have emerged in Hardeman County as dry conditions continue.  Farmers were hopeful that the remaining 15 percent will emerge yet.With the dry conditions and the wheat not growing as well as it could, very few ranchers have their cattle on the wheat.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Jan. 26, 2014
Places: Hardeman County, TX

Title: Farmers in Zavala County, Texas continued to water all crops
Description: Farmers in Zavala County continued to water all crops and small grains since the weather has been so dry, according to the AgriLife Extension agent.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Jan. 26, 2014
Places: Zavala County, TX

Title: Farmers in Dawson County, Texas were not hopeful about the upcoming growing season
Description: With no precipitation in the last 28 days, farmers in Dawson County were not hopeful about the upcoming growing season, according to the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  Winds have dried out the topsoil, and the pasture looks like it could burn quickly.Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Jan. 26, 2014
Places: Dawson County, TX

Title: A rural nightclub cannot drill a well on its property in Gillespie County, Texas because there is a moratorium on new well drilling
Description: A rural nightclub cannot drill a well on its property in Gillespie County because there is a moratorium on new well drilling in the Hill Country Underground Water Conservation District that began in August 2013 and will not expire until February 2014.  My San Antonio.com (Texas), Jan. 13, 2014
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Gillespie County, TX

Title: Drought-Related USDA Disaster Declarations in 2014
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture began declaring counties as primary and secondary disaster areas related to drought in January, for the 2014 growing season. Farmers in affected counties have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for low-interest emergency loans. For more information, agricultural producers should contact their Farm Service Agency office. From Farm Service Agency press releases.

Title: Ranchers continued hauling water for livestock in Tarrant County, Texas
Description: Ranchers near Saginaw attested that they were still hauling water for livestock because there was no water in stock tanks.  Some grass did grow in 2013, which was more than could be said for the past couple of years.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Jan. 5, 2014
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: Many days of blowing dirt in South Plains of Texas
Description: The South Plains of Texas has endured 29 days of blowing dirt since the start of 2014, with more such days forecast.  During the same period in 2013, there were only 14 days of blowing dirt.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), May 7, 2014
Places: Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Cotton, well production down in Texas' Rolling Plains
Description: Cotton production in Texas’ Rolling Plains in 2015 was down to about one-quarter to one-half of that of an average year.  The gin manager of the Rhineland gin said that he expected this year’s bale count to be about 26,650, in comparison with years prior to the drought when average production ranged from 50,000 to 100,000 bales.  Cotton production was down because intense drought caused farmers to draw heavily from their irrigation wells, and well production has not yet recovered to pre-drought levels.Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Jan. 19, 2016
Places: Baylor County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Knox County, TX

Title: Crops, livestock continue to be affected by drought in Young County, Texas
Description: Drought is persistent in Young County.  High temperatures and strong winds continue to impact farmers and ranchers across the county.  The few rains that have fallen have been followed by consistent winds as high as 30 mph.  Municipalities have instituted drought restrictions limiting water usage, and lake levels are below 50% capacity and livestock tanks are virtually empty.  Ranchers continue to cull herds since the native and improved grasses are still not growing at a rate that will sustain livestock.  Because the winter wheat crop progressed faster than normal rates due to the early rise in temperatures, the crop headed out before maturity; the subsequent occurrence of some below-freezing nights and hail led to a failure of almost 80% of the crop.   Very few farmers are choosing to plant spring hay crops because of the drought conditions.From a USDA employee in Graham, Texas, on May 16, 2014.
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Low cotton prices, low cotton production hurting farmers in the Big Country of Texas
Description: Low prices for cotton and reduced cotton production due to drought has hurt farmers significantly in the Big Country of Texas.  A cotton ginner reported that most of the cotton in the region was shredded because cotton production was so low.  With less cotton to gin, the gin brought in fewer workers, who will certainly miss the paycheck.  KTAB TV 32 & KRBC TV 9 (Abilene, Texas), Dec. 16, 2014
Places: Brown County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Erath County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Howard County, TX, Jones County, TX, Kent County, TX, Knox County, TX, Mills County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX

Title: Persistent drought affecting farmers, water supplies in Young County, Texas
Description: Drought remains persistent in Young County.  July rains did bring temporary relief to farmers and ranchers in the area, but a rise in temperatures and consistent winds have dramatically reduced soil moisture, leaving grass growth stagnant and top soil dry and powdery.  Row crop farmers are already considering whether or not planting of winter wheat will make a viable crop.  The City of Graham has announced emergency Stage 5 water restrictions and that lake levels are so low that bulk water sales have been suspended.  Lake Graham has less than 365 days left of water for public use; this restriction affects rural Young County and the cities of Graham, Bryson, Throckmorton and Newcastle.From an FSA employee in Graham, Texas, on August 5, 2014.
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Pasture and forage affected in Bandera County, Texas
Description: Pasture grass and forage for cattle/calves is disappearing rapidly, resulting in extra expenses for hay and minerals to supplement feed for the livestock in order to keep the cows and their calves healthy.From Bandera County, Texas, on March 21, 2018
Places: Bandera County, TX

Title: Farmers in the El Paso's Lower Valley in Texas received less than 40 percent of full allotments
Description: Farmers in the El Paso's Lower Valley had a hard year in 2014 and received just 18 acre-inches, rather than their four acre-feet allotments.  Farmers with pecan trees, which cannot go without water, were in particularly dire straits because they had to find water for their orchards.  A Tornillo pecan grower was hoping and praying for water to sustain his trees and said he would be in serious trouble without water.The general manager of the El Paso County Water Improvement District No. 1 said it was very difficult to tell farmers that little water was available for irrigation, especially since allocations in 2013 were a record low.  The meager ration was hardest for pecan growers who had little option but to get long-unused wells functioning again.  Well water quality is poor.  To add insult to injury, irrigators must pay annually for water from the Rio Grande River, even if they do not receive the water.  El Paso Times (Texas), Dec. 14, 2014
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Covers for water pits save money and water for hydraulic fracturer in eastern Permian Basin in Texas
Description: A hydraulic fracking company based in Oklahoma City began experimenting in 2013 with the use of pit covers to reduce water lost to evaporation.  With drought being an ongoing concern, hydraulic frackers, which typically use 4 million gallons of water per well, strive to conserve and protect their water supplies.  Although covers can cost from $150,000 to $350,000, businesses can recover the cost after two to four months of use, according to a senior superintendent for Devon Energy Corp.’s operations in the east Permian Basin area in Texas.  Devon uses covers on 24 of its 39 waters pits there.  In the long run, the covers can result in savings of millions of dollars and millions of gallons of water.  NewsOK.com (Oklahoma City, Okla.), Sept. 16, 2014
Places: Oklahoma City, OK, Borden County, TX, Crockett County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Garza County, TX, Glasscock County, TX, Howard County, TX, Irion County, TX, Kent County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Martin County, TX, Midland County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Reagan County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sterling County, TX, Tom Green County, TX, Upton County, TX

Title: Thirty-two communities or water systems in south Texas have restrictions on water use
Description: Thirty-two cities or water suppliers in the Rio Grande Valley were under voluntary or mandatory water restrictions, due to low reservoirs.  Restrictions were in effect for seven public water suppliers In Cameron County, 13 in Hidalgo County, six in Starr County, four in Zapata County and two in Willacy County.  There are emergency restrictions in three public water systems, indicating a water supply  that could be exhausted in 45 to 180 days.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Dec. 15, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Hay supplies have been low in Texas after years of drought
Description: Hay supplies have been low in Texas after years of drought, but hay growers in McLennan County finally had a good hay season this fall.  A Texas AgriLife extension agent noted that Bermuda grass production was down, presumably due to drought-stressed roots.  Hay prices were still somewhat high in Texas, and supplies were selling out quickly.  Hay and Forage Grower (Minneapolis, Minn.), Dec. 10, 2013
Places: McLennan County, TX

Title: Rancher in Bailey County, Texas sold most of his cattle herd
Description: A Bailey County rancher sold 290 cattle and kept only 85 cattle from his herd as drought prevented pasture and corn from growing well.    High feed prices made profit nearly nonexistent.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 30, 2013
Places: Bailey County, TX

Title: Site around water intake cleared out to allow continued pumping for Olney, Texas
Description: The area around the water intake in Lake Cooper was dug out and deepened to allow Olney, Texas to continue to withdraw water from Lake Cooper, which held 24 percent of its capacity on Nov. 21.  Water from Lake Olney can be used if or when there was no longer enough water in Lake Cooper, but water from Lake Olney contains more silt, making it more expensive and difficult to treat.  Olney still gets water from Lake Kickapoo, just as Wichita Falls does.  Wichita Falls was at stage 4 drought restrictions because its primary water supplies fell to less than 30 percent of capacity.  Olney Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 27, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX, Olney, TX

Title: Matagorda Bay, Texas suffering from drought, lack of fresh water inflows
Description: Years of drought and reduced fresh water inflows to Matagorda Bay have allowed the salinity of the bay to climb to unhealthy levels for oysters, shrimp and other aquatic life, reducing their populations.  The lack of fresh water also has limited the bird population at Matagorda Bay, the birding capital of North America.One oysterman stated that this daily hauls were just one-third of the amount of oysters he used to catch prior to the 2011 drought, forcing him to downsize his seafood shops and oyster processing.  Texas Public Radio (San Antonio, Texas), Nov. 20, 2013
Categories: Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Matagorda County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority board in central Texas approved an emergency plan allowing them to keep 1.1 million acre-feet of water in the Highland Lakes
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority board approved a plan that would allow them to keep 1.1 million acre-feet of water in the Highland Lakes before sharing water with downstream users.  Previously, Lake Buchanan and Lake Travis had to contain at least 850,000 acre-feet, or 42 percent of capacity, before water would be released, but persistent drought made the board realize that the lakes needed additional time to recover from drought.  The Texas Board of Environmental Quality must approve the plan before it takes effect.Since lakes Buchanan and Travis were at 36 percent of capacity, it seems unlikely the lakes will fill enough to allow rice farmers to receive irrigation water in 2014 for the third consecutive year.  The lack of irrigation water may be the death knell for many rice farmers who were desperately hoping for irrigation water this year.  Matagorda Bay also relies on the Highland Lakes for fresh water inflows to reduce the bay’s salinity for oyster beds and fisheries.The emergency plan also requires municipal water customers to restrict water use.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Nov. 19, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Llano County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: The mayor of Del Rio strongly opposed a proposed plan to move water from the Edwards-Trinity aquifer in Val Verde County to San Antonio, Texas
Description: The mayor of Del Rio strongly opposed a proposed plan to move water from the Edwards-Trinity aquifer in Val Verde County to San Antonio by 2018.  The V.V. Water Co. proposed to pipe sufficient water to supply 150,000 households yearly, but the mayor feels that such a water transaction would shortchange San Felipe springs, the Del Rio community and the region.  People opposing the proposed plan noted that there was not enough water to recharge the aquifer when rainfall was less than 80 percent of average and that springs and creeks in Val Verde County were presently dry.San Antonio officials are looking at bringing in water from other areas to reduce their drain on the Edwards Aquifer.  My San Antonio.com (Texas), Nov. 18, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: San Antonio, TX, Val Verde County, TX

Title: Drought hampered the sugar cane crop in south Texas
Description: Drought hampered the sugar cane crop in south Texas, where farmers were hesitant to plant for lack of irrigation water.  Mill experts anticipate the sugar cane crop to be roughly 125,000 tons, or about 17 percent lower than the average harvest of 150,000 tons, for a loss of about $10.5 million.    The president and CEO of RGV Sugar Growers said that it is hard to break even with depressed sugar prices.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Nov. 17, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Fewer monarch butterflies passing through Texas this fall
Description: Two years of drought and habitat destruction in the Midwest have drastically limited the number of butterflies returning to Mexico to overwinter this year.  A master naturalist and entomology specialist in Victoria, Texas said that of the 300 million monarch butterflies that left Mexico this spring, just 60 million butterflies, or 20 percent of the original butterflies’ progeny, will return to Mexico in the fall.A Texas A&M butterfly expert noted that the number of monarchs leaving Mexico last spring was low, contributing to the small number of butterflies this year.  He heard that there were so few monarchs in Canada that an annual monarch count was cancelled this fall.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Nov. 11, 2013
Places: Texas, Victoria County, TX

Title: Lake Texoma entered Drought Level 2
Description: Lake Texoma entered Drought Level 2 on Nov. 6 when the lake receded to 612 feet, or 77 percent of conservation pool storage.  The lake’s recreational users are urged to be cautious about shallow areas and submerged hazards.  One boat ramp in Lakeside Public Use area closed, due to low water levels.   Inflows to the lake have been 23 percent of average this year.  North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), Nov. 6, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bryan County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Cooke County, TX, Grayson County, TX

Title: The faithful in eastern New Mexico and West Texas had a second day of prayer to give thanks for the rain
Description: The faithful in eastern New Mexico and West Texas had a second day of prayer to give thanks for the rain that has fallen and ameliorated drought in the region.  A Clovis man helped organize the days of prayer and thinks the precipitation that lessened the drought is a “true miracle.”  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Nov. 3, 2013
