Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority proposed unprecedented measures to keep water in the depleted Highland Lakes in central Texas
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority has proposed unprecedented measures to keep water in the depleted Highland Lakes in central Texas to allow the lakes to recover from years of drought.LCRA authorities recommend limiting releases for threatened river species, requiring curbs on outdoor watering in Central Texas cities and making it easier to withhold water from rice farmers near the Gulf Coast.  The LCRA wants to increase the amount of water that must be contained in the Highland Lakes before water is released for rice farmers.  Most rice farmers have not received water for the past two years.Lake Travis and Lake Buchanan are part of the Highland Lakes.  The Texas Tribune (Austin, Texas), Nov. 1, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Drought and higher salinity in Lavaca and San Antonio bays on the Texas Gulf Coast have cut oyster harvests by half
Description: Drought and higher salinity in Lavaca and San Antonio bays have cut oyster harvests by half, according to a seafood merchant in Port Lavaca.  He reported that oyster harvests since the season began on Nov. 1 have been about 50 percent of usual.  His seafood company usually sends three to four trucks out daily to transport oysters across the country, but has sent only two trucks per day.The business owner explained, “A lot of the oysters are dead.  We did get some rain later this summer, but it might have been too little too late for a lot of the oysters."The warmer, saltier water benefits oysters’ natural predators, such as the oyster drill, which is a snail that feeds on the oysters, and dermo disease, a parasite that kills oysters.  Once the drought ends and freshwater inflows to the bays resume, the oysters should recover in about two years, said the upper coast regional director for the coastal fishers division of Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Nov. 25, 2013
Categories: Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Calhoun County, TX, Port Lavaca, TX, Refugio County, TX

Title: Bermudagrass hay production has nearly ended in east-central Texas because the region has received little rain since early July
Description: Bermudagrass hay production has nearly ended in east-central Texas because the region has received little rain since early July, said a Cherokee County ag agent.  Many farmers got a normal first cutting of hay, but the second was not even 75 percent of a normal cutting, he said.  Since then, very little hay has grown.  Many east-central Texas farmers grow hay for their livestock and sell any extra, but may not have enough for their own herd this winter.Hay was being shipped in from Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi.  Hay and Forage Grower (Minneapolis, Minn.), Oct. 5, 2013
Places: Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Anderson County, TX, Angelina County, TX, Bell County, TX, Bosque County, TX, Brazoria County, TX, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Chambers County, TX, Cherokee County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Erath County, TX, Falls County, TX, Fort Bend County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Gregg County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Hamilton County, TX, Hardin County, TX, Harris County, TX, Harrison County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Hill County, TX, Hood County, TX, Houston County, TX, Jasper County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Lee County, TX, Leon County, TX, Liberty County, TX, Limestone County, TX, Madison County, TX, Marion County, TX, McLennan County, TX, Milam County, TX, Montgomery County, TX, Nacogdoches County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Newton County, TX, Orange County, TX, Panola County, TX, Polk County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Rusk County, TX, Sabine County, TX, San Augustine County, TX, San Jacinto County, TX, Shelby County, TX, Smith County, TX, Somervell County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Tyler County, TX, Upshur County, TX, Walker County, TX, Waller County, TX, Williamson County, TX, Wood County, TX

Title: Water supply nearly depleted for the North Central Texas Municipal Water Authority
Description: Water users in the North Central Texas Municipal Water Authority were asked to reduce their water use by 25 percent in 2013.Miller’s Creek Reservoir, the water authority’s main supply, was at 7.8 percent of capacity in October 2014.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Oct. 27, 2014
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Haskell County, TX, Knox County, TX, Stonewall County, TX

Title: Drought’s impact on Lake Travis near Austin, Texas led a second restaurant to close
Description: The Gnarly Gar, a floating restaurant on Lake Travis, announced that its last day of business would be on Sept. 29, due to the low level of the lake.  The restaurant might reopen if the lake refills.  At the end of September, Lake Travis was about 43 feet below average, giving patrons a walk of nearly 1,000 feet from the parking lot to the restaurant.Earlier in September, another restaurant, Carlos’N Charlie’s closed, due to drought’s impact on Lake Travis.  KXAN-TV NBC 36 Austin (Texas), Sept. 24, 2013
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Drought closing dairies in Archer County, Texas
Description: The Windthorst/Scotland area had more than 90 dairies 15 years ago, but drought has driven most of those dairies out of business until just 38 dairies remain at present.  The lack of water and grass has forced the remaining dairy owners to lay off employees or drill new wells in an effort to hang on until rain returns.  KAUZ-TV CBS 6 Wichita Falls (Texas), Sept. 19, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Archer County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority board requested that the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality exempt the LCRA from releasing water from the Highland Lakes
Description: The rising levels of lakes Buchanan and Travis persuaded the Lower Colorado River Authority to release water downstream for the benefit of Matagorda Bay, where salinity levels were high because little freshwater has flowed into the bay.  The LCRA had previously requested permission to withhold the water for the bay.  Lakes Buchanan and Travis were at 34 percent of capacity and rising.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Oct. 16, 2013The Lower Colorado River Authority board requested that the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality exempt the LCRA from releasing water from the Highland Lakes, northwest of Austin, to Matagorda Bay to reduce salinity in the bay.  The high salinity is harming wildlife.The Highland Lakes had a combined total storage of 638,000 acre-feet and was about 32 percent of capacity on Sept. 18.  In a matter of weeks, the lakes are expected to fall below a total storage of 30 percent, thereby meeting the criteria for the area being in a worse drought than during the late 1940s through the late 1950s.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Sept. 18, 2013
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Llano County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Communities along Lake Travis in central Texas out of water
Description: Mud clogged the only water supply line for Ridge Harbor on the edge of Lake Travis, forcing the small community to have water transported in for a few days.  KXAN-TV NBC 36 Austin (Texas), Sept. 6, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Cracks in foundation due to watering restrictions, dry pastures, Tarrant County, Texas
Description: Thing have deteriorated since my last report. Not only are stock tanks & ponds are either completely dry, or the deeper ones are nearly dry. Tree loss is significant. I have lost half of a 25 year old live oak, and have a tree service coming this morning to give me a definitive diagnosis and prognosis for this tree. Lost a red oak planted last fall, and a few outlying shrubs are gone. There are mature trees showing damage or are dead around the neighborhood. Because of watering restrictions, I'm just trying to save my foundation, although I see a crack where it was worked on before, and the trees and plants closest to the house. And of course, the oaks. The pasture is dry, and the horses my neighbor has bee grazing have been taken off. The ground cracks are trip hazards. Need beneficial rain, but none in the forecast. Got 0.39" in August. My water bill and electric bill are up. Lake levels continue to go down all over North Texas.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Haslet 2.2 S on 9/5/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Energy, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: The Brazos River Basin  in Texas in stage 1 water restrictions
Description: The Brazos River Basin was in stage 1 water restrictions as water levels in its reservoirs continued to decline, due to ongoing drought.  Lake Granbury hit a new low at 64 percent of capacity during the first week of September and was 7.3 feet low.  Possum Kingdom Lake was 73 percent of capacity, or 10 feet below normal.  “I would say the upper part of our basin upstream of Possum Kingdom it's in the same category as the drought of the ‘50s,” stated Brad Brunett, water services manager for the Brazos River Authority.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Sept. 3, 2013

Title: Victoria, Texas in stage 3 water restrictions, other area rivers dwindling
Description: Victoria entered stage 3 water restrictions when the flow of the Guadalupe River fell below 200 cubic feet per second.  Rainfall in Victoria amounted to 17.57 inches since the start of the year, more than 11 inches below normal.  The flow of the Guadalupe River was 145 cfs on Sept. 18.Other area rivers were also diminished by drought.  The Lavaca River was not flowing in Lavaca County; the Navidad River was barely flowing in Jackson County; and the Guadalupe River was flowing at 188 cubic feet per second at Cuero (DeWitt County), down from the annual flow rate of 919 cfs, or just over 20 percent of normal.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Sept. 18, 2013

Title: Central Texas offered no native flowering plants on which hummingbirds feed during their annual migration
Description: Central Texas offered no native flowering plants on which hummingbirds feed during their annual migration south to Mexico and Central America, reported the president of the Arroyo Colorado Audubon Society after a recent trip.  She urges people to put out feeders for the hummingbirds to help the creatures on their long journey south.  The hummingbirds will benefit from the food, and the people will benefit next year and in following years when the hummingbirds return on their migrations and bring offspring with them.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Aug. 25, 2013

Title: San Jacinto County, Texas, dry grass a fire danger
Description: The drought impact on my property is severe. My pond has not been full enough to support any life for several years. Some frogs reached maturity this spring, but there is very little water in it now. The water is stagnant & lifeless. The grass in my fields is dry, dead, & a fire danger. Rain is desperately needed.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Coldspring 4.3 SSW on 8/24/2013
Places: San Jacinto County, TX

Title: Comal County, Texas, livestock desperate for moisture, no grass in pasture
Description: Water levels in the Edwards aquifer continue to drop. The main spring in New Braunfels has quit flowing. There is no more green grass in the pasture. In fact the cattle fight over the watermelon and cantaloupe rinds when we throw them over the fence. You know things are desperate when we start looking to the Gulf of Mexico for hurricane relief! I estimate we have about 10 more feet of aquifer before our well begins to suck air. At present, the aquifer level drops between half a foot and a full foot each day.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #New Braunfels 5.9 NW on 8/24/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Comal County, TX

Title: Drought affecting wells, trees in Foard County, Texas; Stage 4 drought in effect
Description: We have no pond water for stock. We had 4" of rain in July and have some grass, but still no water. The drought has also killed many trees in our area and continues to affect our local water system. Generally we have about 25' of water in our wells at the first of August and this year we have 7' of water. We are in Stage 4 drought and would probably be out of water but we purchase water from the City of Crowell (they have water from Lake Greenbelt in Clarendon).CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Crowell 10.5 E on 8/23/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Guadalupe River dry above Canyon Lake north of San Antonio, Texas

Title: Stage three drought restrictions took effect in the Cow Creek Groundwater Conservation District in Kendall County, Texas

Monitoring wells that the CCGCD uses indicate that the Trinity Aquifer is lower than it has been in decades, said the general manager of the CCGCD.  It is 2 feet lower than in 2011 and 30 feet lower than in 2007.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 14, 2013

Title: South Texans are frustrated with Mexico’s noncompliance with the 1944 treaty and were signing a petition to be sent to President Obama urging him to take action
Description: Mexico acknowledges its water debt of 380,000 acre-feet, but does not have the water to give to the U.S., due to drought.  Washington Post (D.C.), Sept. 8, 2014South Texans are frustrated with Mexico’s noncompliance with the 1944 treaty and were signing a petition to be sent to President Obama urging him to take action.  The Rio Grande Regional Water Authority has copies of the petition that people may sign.  Petition organizers aim to get Mexico to comply with the treaty requiring it to deliver 1.75 million acre-feet of water during a five-year cycle unless an extraordinary drought or problem with its hydraulics system prevents Mexico from sharing the water, said a spokeswoman for the U.S. sector of the International Boundary and Water Commission in El Paso.  In return, the U.S. must provide 1.5 million acre-feet from the Colorado River annually.  About one thousand signatures have been gathered, but petition organizers intend to collect 10,000 signatures.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Aug. 13, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Exceptional drought conditions and late freezes cut into the amount of certified wheat produced in southeastern Colorado, leading to reduced supplies of seed for the next planting
Description: Exceptional drought conditions and late freezes cut into the amount of certified wheat produced in southeastern Colorado, leading to reduced supplies of seed for the next planting.  The executive director of the Colorado Wheat Research Foundation, which works with the growers of certified seed varieties created by Colorado State University, said that supplies would be tight, but there should be sufficient supplies if farmers contact their dealers early.  Growers of certified seed in northeastern Colorado have received requests for seed from southeastern Colorado, western Kansas, and the panhandles of Nebraska, Oklahoma and Texas since production was low in those areas.  A certified seed grower near Haxtun in extreme northeastern Colorado reported that 70 percent of his seed was sold because his usual customers wanted to claim their seeds early, knowing that the wheat crop in the southeastern part of the state was below par.A certified seed grower in southeastern Colorado near Sheridan Lake harvested only one-fifth of his total acres this summer, but only half of that seed was of decent quality to sell.  The harvested acres yielded roughly one-third of the usual amount.  Altogether, he had about 6 to 7 percent of the wheat he had to sell last year.  He was trying to buy seed from northern Colorado, but will have to raise the price 20 to 30 percent to cover transportation costs.  Denver Post (Colo.), Aug. 6, 2013

Title: Dryland cotton in the Rolling Plains of Texas was suffering from drought and heat
Description: Dryland cotton in the Rolling Plains of Texas was suffering from drought and heat.  Rangeland and pastures needed rain to keep growing.  Farmers worried about how reliable their wells would continue to be.  Hay was in demand and was often sold before it was baled.  Surface water supplies were going dry.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 16, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality

Title: The cotton crop in the Lower Rio Grande Valley in Texas is expected to be one of the region’s smallest
Description: The cotton crop in the Lower Rio Grande Valley is expected to be one of the region’s smallest since less acreage was planted, irrigation water was in short supply and the mild winter did not kill enough insects.  During the last three years, an average of 150,000 acres of cotton were planted in the Lower Rio Grande Valley, but this year, a Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service cotton integrated pest management entomologist said  that about 80,000 acres of cotton were planted.  The lack of moisture has slowed plant growth even where farmers irrigated before and since planting.  In some fields in Willacy County, the cotton never came up.  High Plains Journal (Dodge City, Kansas), July 15, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Irrigation water deliveries at an end on the Lower Rio Grande River in New Mexico
Description: Elephant Butte and Caballo lakes held just 3 and 2 percent of capacity, respectively, at the end of the irrigation season, which was cut short, due to low water levels.  Heavy rains sent 29,400 acre-feet of water into Elephant Butte and 25,200 acre-feet into Caballo Lake, bringing the storages in those lakes to 6 and 17 percent of capacity, as of Sept. 17.  The influx of water to the reservoirs was a godsend, but is far from guaranteeing a good irrigation season next year.  El Paso Times (Texas), Sept. 17, 2013Irrigation water from the Elephant Butte Reservoir began flowing on June 1 and will end on July 14, making this the shortest irrigation season ever for the district.  The reservoir is at 3.1 percent of capacity, lower than it has been in 40 years.  Growers received just 6 percent of a full allotment.  ABQJournal Online (Albuquerque, N .M.) July 9, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: Drought leads to tree loss in Wilbarger (Texas) County cemetary
Description: Cracked earth at this station has been repaired for the most part with the 1.84" of rain in this event. Ant mounds are appearing as the fire ants dig out. Will treat with organic product. Vegetation has greened up and is actively growing again. No unusual threat of grass/brush fires in the immediate area. Air conditioner use has been down due to the unseasonably cool temps. Cities in Tarrant and surrounding counties have been spraying for mosquitoes for several weeks in order to head off the threat of West Nile Virus infections, which caused significant morbidity and mortality last year. Stagnant water collections will be a problem again after this rain event. Only rain directly over area lakes helped replenish low lake levels by a few inches. No significant watershed runoff occurred, as most moisture was soaked up by the thirsty soil.I made a road trip to Vernon, TX, in Wilbarger County last Wednesday. Since there is apparently no reporting station for CoCoCaHS in that area, I shall report my observations. My main objective for the trip was to check the family burial plots in Eastview Memorial Cemetery, and it was evident when driving in the gate that they have had a tremendous loss of trees in the old section. Cemetery personnel reported to me that no significant rain had fallen in the last 3 years, and that they had lost many trees, including the old cedars that had existed nearly 100 years. Cedar trees are prevalent in old cemeteries in that part of Texas because of their drought and disease resistance.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Haslet 2.2 S on 7/21/2013
Places: Wilbarger County, TX

Title: Hard, dry ground causing problems for producer installing fences; mesquite and locust trees affected in Navarro County, Texas
Description: I use rotational grazing with electric fences. In trying to put the step-in posts down I have to look for either a crack in the ground or use a hammer to drive it in. Normally you step on it and shift a little weight.Cracks are becoming more numerous, wider and deeper. Even the mesquite is showing the effects with lots of dead limbs. Loosing locust trees as well (not a bad thing).CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Blooming Grove 2.4 SW on 7/10/2013
Places: Navarro County, TX

Title: High demand for well drilling in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas
Description: Low irrigation supplies led more farmers in the Rio Grande Valley to have wells drilled on their land.  One sod farmer refers to the two wells he had drilled as “insurance.”  The wells cost more than $30,000 and each produce about 200 gallons per minute.  A well driller from McAllen said that he has a lot of customers wanting to have wells drilled since irrigation supplies are not satisfying people’s water needs.  In other cases, people want to water their lawns, but municipal water is expensive.  KRGV.com reported that the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation listed more than 2,000 wells as being registered in the Valley.  KRGV-TV Channel 5 Weslaco (Texas), July 4, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Hidalgo County, TX

Title: Burn ban in the unincorporated parts of Travis County, Texas
Description: Travis County Commissioners Court approved a burn ban in the unincorporated parts of the county, due to drought and the elevated fire danger.  The ban was not related to the use of fireworks and remained in effect through July 30.  The Travis County fire marshal urged people to attend a public fireworks display and to forgo private fireworks in the interest of safety.
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Grasshopper population booming in Navarro, Henderson and Lampasas counties in Texas
Description: Dry conditions in July through the fall of 2012 led to an increase in the grasshopper population in June 2013, stated an AgriLife Extension entomologist in Dallas.  During the July through the fall period, grasshoppers put their eggs half an inch to two inches below the soil surface.  Moisture encourages the growth of fungus and other diseases, which limit the eggs’ survival, so during dry times, as in 2012, the eggs survive, leading to a healthy grasshopper population the following summer.  AgriLife Extension agents verified the presence of abundant grasshoppers in Navarro, Henderson and Lampasas counties.  Grasshoppers are affecting hay production in Navarro County.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 30, 2013
Places: Brazos County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Navarro County, TX

Title: Stage 1 drought restrictions end for Tarrant Regional Water District in Texas
Description: Stage 1 drought restrictions ended for the Tarrant Regional Water District on May 18 after being enacted nearly two years prior.  Recent rainfall brought the levels of the Richland-Chambers and Cedar Creek reservoirs to more than 100 percent of capacity; Eagle Mountain Lake was full and its floodgates were open slightly to  send water downstream to Lake Worth, which was at 84 percent of capacity, according to the water district’s community and government relations director.  The stage 1 drought restrictions took effect in June 2013 and could not end until the lake levels rose to 95 percent of capacity.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), May 12, 2015
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Denton County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Jack County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Parker County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Ector County, Texas
Description: Ector County commissioners extended the current burn ban, which took effect on June 24, by another 30 days because the Keetch-Byram Drought Index was 654 on Sept. 23.  Odessa American (Texas), Sept. 23, 2013 and Oct. 27, 2013Ector County commissioners adopted a burn ban for the county as the Keetch-Byram Drought Index (KBDI) rose to an average of 574, where a minimum KBDI value of zero represents very moist conditions and a maximum value of 800 indicates the driest conditions.  The sale and use of fireworks is unaffected by the burn ban.  Odessa American (Texas), June 24, 2013
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Producer cannot fertilize hay meadows because of lack of rain; grass for cattle going fast in Victoria County, Texas
Description: Still no rain, 9.00 in. below normal. Heat is almost not bearable around 2:00 pm. Grass for cattle is going fast. Have not fertilized hay meadows this year because of no rain. May be just as well, it would not have paid off without water. To the east, Houston area and beyond, good rains; to the north, San Antonio area last week got downpours, also to the west, Corpus Christi area last week got good rains, maybe not enough. I guess the old saying, we will get it when we need it, will have to be good enough for now.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Inez 1.1 SSE on 6/22/2013
Places: Victoria County, TX, Inez, TX

Title: Zebral mussel encroachment reported in 2 Tarrant County (Texas) lakes; water restrictions reported in some cities
Description: Yard grass/pasture have greened and are actively growing. Ground cracks have filled in except for the widest ones. All this noted after nice rains on 6/9-10 and 6/18. Mowing the yard weekly again, and the pasture needs it again to  prevent weeds and mesquites. Keeping pasture borders mowed low although fire danger is not great now.Tarrant County lakes remain low by 3 or more feet, with Bridgeport reported at -18 feet. Reports of zebra mussel encroachment in 2 lakes to the north affect municipal water supplies. Haslet is in Stage 1 Water Restrictions, but other cities are already in Stage 3.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Haslet 2.2 S on 6/21/2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Tarrant County, TX, Haslet, TX

Title: Loose livestock causing problems in DeWitt County, Texas
Description: Loose livestock have taken up more than 150 hours of sheriff’s deputies’ time during the last two months as the animals amble to roadways to graze.  Precipitation runs off of roads, greening up the vegetation along the roads, which draws livestock.  A number of accidents involving livestock has been reported in recent months, but another problem with the livestock is the high volume of phone calls about loose livestock that keeps deputies from other responsibilities.  KAVU & KUNU-TV Crossroads (Texas), Aug. 20, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health
Places: DeWitt County, TX

Title: Second year of drastically limited water supplies for rice farmers along the Lower Colorado River in Texas resulted in 30 percent reduction in rice acres
Description: The second year of drastically limited water supplies for rice farmers along the Lower Colorado River and cooler temperatures have resulted in a 30 percent reduction in rice acres in Texas, according to Dr. Ted Wilson with the Texas AgriLife Research Center in Beaumont.  About 10 percent of the crop has shown grain development, whereas last year at the time, 19 percent of the crop was developing grains.  The cost of rice will increase in grocery stores since rice production is down.  The lack of irrigation water pushed some rice farmers out of the business, while others have decided to try growing soybeans for the first time.  Texas Public Radio (San Antonio, Texas), June 19, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Colorado County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Low water levels causing bad smell in drinking water in Montague County, Texas
Description: We have had some good rains lately but still not enough to get the lake in Montague County where it needs to be or even close. The drinking water has a bad smell due to the low level. With the temps. being so high there is still a threat of grass fires.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Bowie 0.5 WSW on 6/12/2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Montague County, TX, Bowie, TX

Title: Wheat in poor condition in Childress County, Texas; eastern Colorado and Dakotas
Description: Wheat in Childress County, Texas was in such poor condition that much of it was grazed or baled, stated a custom harvester from Goodland, Kansas who has been in the business for 23 years.  This was one of the worst years for the area with yields of 5 to 10 bushels per acre.  He also noted that eastern Colorado did not get a good stand and the Dakotas did not have enough moisture to germinate their winter wheat.  Salina Journal & Salina.com (Kan.), June 11, 2013

Title: Some fireworks banned in Ector County, Texas
Description: Rockets with sticks and missiles with fins were banned during the Fourth of July holiday in Ector County on June 10 by Ector County commissioners.  Although commissioners discussed a burn ban, consensus was that a ban was not needed.  Odessa American (Texas), June 11, 2013
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Cutbacks in deliveries from Rio Grande River for farmers in El Paso, County, Texas and Mexico
Description: Farmers receiving water from the El Paso County Water Improvement District No. 1 will receive a record low allotment of 6 acre-inches, according to the general manager.  The El Paso Improvement Water District No. 1 usually gets 370,000 acre-feet from the Rio Grande, but will get only 60,000 acre-feet in 2013.  El Paso Water Utilities usually gets 60,000 acre-feet, but will get just 6,448 acre-feet this year.  Juárez irrigators in Mexico normally receive 60,000 acre-feet, but will get a meager 3,300 acre-feet in 2013.  Drought prompted El Paso Water Utilities to drill new wells, upgrade existing wells, build new pipelines to transfer water more efficiently from its well fields and boost production at the desalination plant.  The Elephant Butte reservoir in Sierra County, New Mexico holds just over 10 percent of capacity with 235,000 acre-feet in storage.  The water level is 92 feet below the dam spillway.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 7, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dona Ana County, NM, Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Title: Drought reduced carrying capacity on ranch in Texas Panhandle
Description: Drought has forced the JA Ranch to destock to protect the pastures and will force them to cull more cattle if drought continues.  Calves weigh 100 to 150 pounds, which is less than normal.  AgWeb.com (Mexico, Mo.), June 7, 2013
Places: Armstrong County, TX

Title: County judge in El Paso County, Texas seeking ban on all fireworks through the Fourth of July
Description: Drought and the elevated fire danger led County Judge Escobar to make a declaration of local disaster, valid for one week, and to request that county commissioners prohibit the sale and use of all fireworks in the unincorporated parts of El Paso County.  The governor and the El Paso Commissioners Court must approve the disaster declaration to extend it through July 5.  "Part of our challenge is that the drought has been ongoing for El Paso. It's not like we had a relief. We have had year after year of drought, the situation gets more severe as more time passes," said the county judge.  The Texas A&M Forest Service found the Keetch-Byram Drought Index to be 730 in El Paso and expects the KBDI to rise to 737 in the next two weeks.  If the disaster declaration is extended, this would be the third year that fireworks have been banned in unincorporated parts of El Paso County.  The area manager of TNT Fireworks opposes the potential fireworks ban, saying that the fireworks industry has lost millions of dollars in sales because the county has not allowed fireworks in unincorporated parts of the county in recent years, and has forced him personally to find other sources of income.  El Paso Times (Texas), June 2, 2013
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: El Paso County, TX, El Paso, TX

Title: Lavaca County, Texas, lowered water table, dry pastures, reduced hay yield
Description: I run a small plant nursery and daily watering of everything is taking its toll on our well. Water table seems to have dropped. We have never really recovered from the drought of several years ago. We had some spring rain this year, but not enough to really soak the soil or fill local wells and tanks. Now that we have had no rain for just several weeks, the pastures are crisp and dry. Local farmers harvested one, at the most two, cuts of hay this season.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Hallettsville 8.0 N on 6/28/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Temporary pumps in use, outdoor watering prohibited around White River Lake in Texas
Description: Two temporary floating pumps are pulling water out of White River Lake and sending it to the treatment plant on the lake’s shore since the permanent pumps cannot be used with the lake so low.  In May, the White River Lake district imposed severe watering restrictions that prohibited outdoor watering.  White River Lake provides water for about 10,000 people.  GO San Angelo/San Angelo Standard Times (Texas), July 24, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Crosby County, TX

Title: Hudspeth County, Texas, early sale of livestock, insufficient food for livestock
Description: .063 Total rain so far this year!  Grass is dying out in places!  Fewer mesquite beans this year.  Sage brush is still trying to grow.  Livestock has been moved to market and remainder having to be supplemented more than usual.  Deer herd has moved into alfalfa field to survive.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Salt Flat 10.7 NE on 5/28/2013
Places: Hudspeth County, TX

Title: Farmers in Hidalgo County, Texas selling their farmland due to drought, meager water supplies
Description: Farmers in Hidalgo County have resorted to selling their agricultural land because the drought and meager water supplies make it nearly impossible to turn a profit.  A real estate broker noted that many farmers were putting their land up for sale and some were putting the money into certificates of deposit at the bank because the interest earned is comparable to profits from farming.  A farmer selling agricultural land near Mercedes commented on how difficult it will be to sell land he farmed for a long time.  KRGV-TV Channel 5 Weslaco (Texas), May 28, 2013
Places: Hidalgo County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Wichita County, Texas
Description: Wichita County commissioners instituted a burn ban on May 28 because the Keetch-Byram Drought Index is high; fuel for wildfires is abundant; winds are strong; and water supplies for firefighting are dwindling.  Outdoor burning is banned in unincorporated parts of the county.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), May 29, 2013
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: Aerial fireworks banned in El Paso County, Texas
Description: El Paso County Commissioners banned the sale and use of aerial fireworks in unincorporated parts of the county, due to the drought and high fire danger.  The county judge plans to request a total ban on fireworks on June 3.  El Paso Times (Texas), May 21, 2013
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Grass growing on the exposed bed of Lake Bridgeport, north of Fort Worth, Texas
Description: Grass is growing on the exposed bed of Lake Bridgeport, which is 16.75 feet low.  The low level of the lake and others that hold supplies for Tarrant Regional Water District may lead to water restrictions in a few weeks when the district’s lakes fall to 75 percent of capacity.  The lakes were at 76 percent of capacity on May 14.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), May 14, 2013
Places: Wise County, TX

Title: Trees dying, homeowner watering landscaping plants in Fannin County, Texas
Description: We have been in a drought in North Texas for over 3 years; it has killed several of our pecan trees and a lot of shallow root trees. We have dead trees all along FM 1206.We have gotten some rain during the early spring but it just quit about 3 weeks ago. All the fronts that come through the rain goes south of us. I am watering garden and flowers and fruit trees to keep them alive. We have 2 katopa trees in our yard that are over 100 years and both of them have died.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Savoy 5.3 NNE on 5/11/2013
Places: Fannin County, TX

Title: Low lake levels affecting fishing and boating in Montague County, Texas; drinking water quality deteriorating
Description: May 11, 2013: The drought in Montague County since fall (2012) has lowered the lake levels to where boats are sitting on dirt...docks seem to be getting brittle due to their dryness. The regular fishing spots are dry and the mold has grown totally over the farm ponds that now just have water in the bottom area. Our drinking water over the last two months (March, April into May 2013) has a bad smell & is getting worse. We are boiling water & using filtering pitchers for drinking water.  Most grass & trees are green but brown grass is starting to show more over the last month. So far the fishing & boating recreation has been affected & the boating safety due to low water levels which bring the underwater trees, old wood decking etc. closer to the surface for boats to run into. The farm fields seem to be a bit dry at this time but not overdry so we still hope to get in fruits & veggies.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Bowie 0.5 WSW on 5/11/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Montague County, TX, Bowie, TX

Title: Drought, late freezes slow crop growth, delay opening of farmers markets in Vernon and Wichita Falls, Texas
Description: Drought and late freezes have delayed fruit and vegetable production and the opening of the farmers market in Vernon and Wichita Falls.  The farmers market in Vernon will delay its opening to June 1st instead of mid-May, while the farmers market in Wichita Falls will open on May 21 rather than on May 7.  KFDX-TV NBC 3 (Wichita Falls, Texas), May 7, 2013
Places: Wichita County, TX, Wichita Falls, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Vernon, TX

Title: Rio Grande Regional Water Authority in Texas attempting to draw attention to water situation with Mexico
Description: The board members of the Rio Grande Regional Water Authority voted to use all available funds in the budget to organize and execute a media blitz to show the public and Congress that Mexico is disregarding the water treaty and is violating the treaty by constructing dams to withhold more water.  Meanwhile, the Rio Grande Valley in deep south Texas is headed toward an agricultural disaster for lack of water.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), May 1, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Cotton farmers in the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas planted about half as much cotton as usual, due to drought, lack of irrigation water
Description: Farmers in the Rio Grande Valley planted an estimated 80,000 acres of cotton, down from the average 150,000 acres planted the last three years, due to drought and the lack of irrigation water.  Between 2004 and 2006, an average of 220,000 acres were planted in cotton in this area.  Most of the cotton in the dryland fields did not emerge from lack of moisture.  In some fields with irrigation, crop growth was slow despite preplant irrigation and a second irrigation.  The slow growth allows ample opportunity for pests to damage the crop, and insect pressure is expected to be more intense than usual this year, partly due to the lack of rain and irrigation water.  SeedQuest (Oakland, California), April 26, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Utility poles fires cause power disruption in Cameron, Willacy and Hidalgo counties in south Texas
Description: More than 2,200 electric customers in Cameron County, 631 customers in Willacy County and 621 in Hidalgo County lost power on April 24 from fires atop utility poles.  The fires occur when rain moistens accumulated dust and debris atop the utility poles, and allows it to conduct electricity, igniting the wooden poles.  KGBT-TV CBS 4 Harlingen (Texas), April 24, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: The International Boundary and Water Commission releasing water from Amistad and Falcon reservoirs on the Rio Grande River to provide more water to the Lower Rio Grande Valley in Texas and also to Mex
Description: The International Boundary and Water Commission is releasing water from Amistad and Falcon reservoirs on the Rio Grande River to provide more water to the Lower Rio Grande Valley in Texas and also to Mexico.  The water releases from Amistad Lake will likely drop the level near a record low of 1,058 feet set in August 1998.  Amistad and Falcon reservoirs were at 34.7 percent of capacity as of April 22.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 23, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Brownsville, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Val Verde County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX

Title: Fewer pollinators and flowering plants in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas
Description: There are fewer pollinators and flowering plants in the Rio Grande Valley, due to drought, stated a park naturalist.  He also noted that all wildlife is adversely affected by the drought if plants are not doing well.  The pollinators should return when drought abates.  KRGV-TV Channel 5 Weslaco (Texas), April 23, 2013

Description: Drought and cool temperatures slowed crop development in the Coastal Bend of Texas.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), April 30, 2013

Title: Some cow and calf producers in the Texas Panhandle finally liquidating their herds

Title: Few wildflowers blooming in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas
Description: The Rio Grande Valley has very few wildflowers to admire this year since drought has left most of the seeds dormant.  An outdoor journalist who travels the Valley said, “This is the worst I have ever seen it this time of year here in Deep South Texas. We might have to wait until next year for wildflowers in the Valley.”  Normally, fields full of bluebonnets, Western primrose and other flowers would be in bloom at this time of year.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 22, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority began releasing water from the Highland Lakes to provide sufficient water for the threatened blue sucker
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority began releasing water from the Highland Lakes to provide sufficient water for the threatened blue sucker fish, which will be spawning over the next four weeks.  Spring rains below Austin usually bring enough water for spawning, which occurs on gravel-bottomed stretches of the Colorado River between Eagle Lake and Bastrop, but drought has reduced the flow.  The LCRA may release about 20,000 acre-feet of water during the next four weeks.  As of April 22, the combined storage in lakes Buchanan and Travis was 40 percent.  Low water levels in the Highland Lakes led to a second year of irrigation water being denied to rice farmers along the lower part of the Colorado River.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), April 22, 2013
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Llano County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Drought continues to affect parts of South Texas
Description: Drought continues to affect parts of South Texas.  Cattle body condition scores In McMullen County were fair to poor and were deteriorating.  The majority of the row crops in Jim Wells County did not establish a stand.  Livestock producers in Webb County were burning the spines off prickly pear cactus for the cattle to eat. Title: Trees still weakened from drought near Abilene, Texas were suffering from more disease problems than usual
Description: Trees still weakened from drought in the Abilene area were suffering from more disease problems than usual, noted a tree specialist.  Hypoxylon canker, a fungus that affects wounded or weakened trees, has been found among mainly red and post oaks.  The tree specialist anticipates that the drought weary trees will suffer from more insect infestations than usual in the near future.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), April 17, 2013
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Only 10 percent of the grain sorghum in Nueces County, Texas germinated
Description: Only 10 percent of the grain sorghum in Nueces County has germinated and is not expected to last long without rain.  The county has gotten just 2.5 inches of rain in the last six months, the least amount for this period since 1961.  KRIS-TV Corpus Christi (Texas), April 16, 2013
Places: Nueces County, TX

Title: Concho County, Texas, producer has to clean air filter every day
Description: I had a producer who is in the center of Concho County (part that received the big rainfall last September 2012) [who said] that he has to blow out his air filter on his Honda Mule ATV each day after checking and feeding livestock. He has only the regular rangeland acreage of grass, mesquite and prickly pear so that indicates a huge photo to me of just how much grass cover has died and has been lost due to prolonged drought. Just had to pass it on since it was new way to me to explain drought. Submitted April 8, 2013, by Daniel J. Lange, CED, Concho-Menard County FSA
Places: Concho County, TX

One city is reporting deteriorating water quality.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Brownsville 6.4 WNW on 4/8/2013

Title: Low level of Medina Lake in Texas offers clean-up opportunity
Description: The falling level of Medina Lake has exposed plenty of rusty 55-gallon drums, a Jeep, a hot tub and other debris.  Residents around the lake intend to take advantage of the low water level to clean up trash around Medina Lake just like they clean up Medina River each year.  One resident on the lake paid to have 52 exposed drums removed from the lake in 2012, but the receding water level has revealed another 30 drums.  The lake was at 6.5 percent of capacity.  San Antonio Express-News (Texas), April 5, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bandera County, TX, Medina County, TX

Title: Agriculture showing effects of continued drought in Young County, Texas
Description: Young County is still suffering the effects of numerous years worth of low rainfall, unseasonal high temperatures, very high winds and drought.  Ranchers in the area have been forced to suspend cattle-on-the-gain activities as well as reduce stocking rates by as much as 60-70% of normal. Native and improved pastures have seen very little growth of grass over the last 4 years and ranchers are facing a 1:140 cow-to-acre ratio to provide adequate nutrition along with their supplemental feeding regiment.  Fall-seeded row crops (wheat) usually provide significant fall grazing within the county, but due to lack of moisture, crop growth has been stifled and grazing acres have been cut short.  Ranchers have stated that if no significant rain comes in the next two months, cattle numbers will again take a dive.  Farmers are being forced to decide whether to gamble paying the cost of land preparation, seed, and fertilizer for the upcoming spring planting season in the case that rain continues to evade the county.  The burn ban has been reinstated, and red flag days have been common as the temperature rises.  Lakes levels are teetering at 50% and water usage for private as well as agricultural use is being limited.
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Communities in South Texas striving to conserve water and maintain steady flow in canal system
Description: Authorities in Rio Hondo have imposed water restrictions and will fine violators up to $200 as the city strives to conserve water.  Rio Hondo, San Benito and the East Rio Hondo Water Supply Corporation were considering purchasing water together to maintain a steady flow in the region’s canal system so customers would continue to receive water.  Officials for the San Benito irrigation district have warned that they may run out of water by the end of May, but were unsure how much water they may need to purchase to keep water moving in the canals because the water situation has never been so dire before now.   The further the cities are from the Rio Grande River, the more water they need to purchase.  The cities were also considering using treated water in the canals.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 1, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Cameron County, TX, Rio Hondo, TX, San Benito, TX

Title: Desperation led ranchers in South Texas to burn the spines off prickly pear cactus to provide some nourishment for their livestock
Description: Desperation led ranchers in South Texas to burn the spines off prickly pear cactus to provide some nourishment and water for their livestock.  The cactus has little protein for the cattle, but ranchers can provide protein pellets, or range cubes, to sustain the livestock.  Ranchers also need an adequate supply of cactus, otherwise cattle will continue eating unburned cactus with spines, which hurt the animals’ mouths, leading to new problems.  Area ranchers were also transporting hay and water for their animals, stated an AgriLife Extension agent in Starr County.  He also noted that many area ranchers were in their late 60s and 70s, meaning that the timeframe for selling livestock, waiting for the drought to break,  rebuilding herds and recouping their investment might be out of reach for some ranchers, leaving them to hold on to their cattle rather than give in and sell.  SouthWest Farm Press (Texas), March 25, 2013
Places: Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Starr County, TX, Webb County, TX, Zapata County, TX

Title: Texas Congressional members asking for the President to intervene in fulfillment of 1944 Water Treaty with Mexico
Description: A group of 35 Texas Congressional members sent a letter to President Obama, requesting that his administration intervene on Texas’ behalf concerning Mexico’s fulfillment of the 1944 Water Treaty.  The group is frustrated that Mexico has not regularly delivered water it owes the U.S. and wants the highest levels of the U.S. government to act on the matter since the issue has not been resolved by the International Boundary and Water Commission.The treaty states that Mexico has to deliver 1,750,000 acre-feet of water to the U.S. every five years.The Monitor (McAllen, Texas), Sept. A number of U.S. congressmen, are seeking President Obama’s involvement with the desperate water supply situation in South Texas and sent drought maps to show that Mexico was not in such dire drought that they could not release water into the Rio Grande River to provide relief to South Texas communities.  Congressmen signing the letter were U.S. Rep. Filemon Vela, D-Brownsville; Ruben Hinojosa, D-Mercedes; Henry Cuellar, D–Laredo; Pete Gallegos, D-Alpine, and Beto O’ Rourke, D-El Paso.  The governor of Texas has also requested intervention from the president.  The U.S. State Department and the U.S. International Boundary and Water Commission have not been able to persuade Mexico to release more water in addition to the inadequate amount that they have already released.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 11, 2013Mexico began releasing water from one reservoir into the Rio Grande River on April 5 and stated that one-third of the water was intended for the U.S.  Water from certain tributaries flowing into the Rio Grande River is also for the U.S., so South Texas will get additional water when Mexico receives rainfall.  U.S. Rep. Filemon Vela, D-Brownsville urged the U.S. government to push Mexico to release the water it owes the U.S. so South Texas municipalities and farmers get the water they desperately need.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 8, 2013Four congressmen from South Texas sent a letter on Feb. 14 to Eduardo Medina Mora, Mexico’s ambassador to the United States, and Edward Drusina, commissioner of the International Boundary and Water Commission urging them to assist with getting Mexico to deliver the water it owes, according to the 1944 Guadalupe Treaty.  Leaders of several border communities reported that drought and the depleted Rio Grande River were not providing enough water for municipal and agricultural use.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Feb. 14, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality

Title: Low water supplies in Rio Grande River basin force New Mexico farmers to wait until June or July for irrigation water
Description: The manager of the Elephant Butte Irrigation District stated that farmers would most likely not receive their water allotments until June or July, if water is even released at all, because Elephant Butte Lake only held 9 percent of capacity as of Jan. 30.  The third year of drought for the Rio Grande River has left snow pack low, the riverbed dry and the need for water high in southern New Mexico.  Farmers have pumped groundwater for irrigation in past years, but the water is salty, leading to an accumulation of salt in the soil, which harms crops.  Most of the region’s annual snowfall usually arrives in January, February and early March, so there is still hope for more snow to bolster the water supply.  As of Jan. 30, Elephant Butte Lake held 181,530 acre-feet of water, compared to 330,870 acre-feet last year at this time last year, according to U.S. Bureau of Reclamation records.  Caballo Reservoir contained 8,340 acre-feet on Jan. 30, down from the 14,770 acre-feet that it held one year ago.  Las Cruces Sun-News (N.M.), Feb. 4, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Dona Ana County, NM, Sierra County, NM, El Paso County, TX

Travis County commissioners unanimously voted to extend the burn ban through April 24.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), March 26, 2013
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Water managers in the El Paso, Texas area urged to prepare for below normal water deliveries from the Rio Grande River
Description: Water managers in the El Paso area were urged to prepare for below normal water deliveries from the Rio Grande River because the snowpack was as much as 70 percent below normal in parts of southern Colorado and northern New Mexico that feed the Rio Grande River, according to a water specialist with the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  El Paso Times (Texas), Jan. 14, 2013
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: El Paso County, TX, El Paso, TX

Title: Cattle ranching scaled back in Winkler County, Texas; Midland and Odessa, Texas,  rationing water
Description: Cattle ranching is already scaled back by 70-80% due to lingering damage of 2011 drought, heat and wildfire. Nearby cities (Midland and Odessa, TX) are rationing water and securing sources of underground water due to lakes and reservoirs going dry. Nearby farms that irrigate from the Pecos River and a system of canals and ditches have no water to be released for this season.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Andrews 26.7 SW on 5/11/2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Ector County, TX, Midland County, TX, Winkler County, TX

Title: Drought-related USDA disaster declarations in 2013
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture began declaring counties as primary and secondary disaster areas related to drought in January, for the 2013 growing season. Farmers in affected counties have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for low-interest emergency loans. For more information, agricultural producers should contact their Farm Service Agency office. From Farm Service Agency press releases, beginning Jan. 9, 2013.

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority board members voted to deny rice farmers irrigation water if the combined storage of Lakes Travis and Buchanan is less than 850,000 acre-feet on March 1, 2013
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority board members voted to deny rice farmers irrigation water if the combined storage of Lakes Travis and Buchanan is less than 850,000 acre-feet on March 1, 2013.  The lakes held roughly 825,000 acre-feet in early January and were not likely to fill much more before the March 1 deadline.  The LCRA voted in November to withhold irrigation water if the combined lake storage was less than 775,000 acre-feet, but opted to reconsider that threshold since November and December brought little precipitation.   If rice farmers get no water again this year, it would be the second year since the lakes were constructed in the 1940s that no irrigation water was provided.  Victoria Advocate (Texas), Jan. 8, 2013
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Llano County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Travis County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Cotton growers in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas planted only 88,772 acres of cotton in 2013 and harvested just 38,348 acres
Description: Cotton growers in the Rio Grande Valley, or Cameron, Hidalgo, Starr and Willacy counties, planted only 88,772 acres of cotton in 2013 and harvested just 38,348 acres, according to the Texas Boll weevil eradication Foundation.  Of the 43 percent of cotton that was harvested, most of that was on irrigated land, said an agricultural economist with Texas A&M AgriLife Research and Extension Center at Weslaco.  The remainder was hurt by drought and not worth harvesting.  SeedQuest (Oakland, Calif.), Dec. 19, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Low power generation at Lake Texoma on Oklahoma/Texas border
Description: Power generation at Lake Texoma was lower in 2013 than it has ever been since hydroelectric power generation began on the lake in 1945.Herald Democrat (Sherman, Texas), Jan. 17, 2014
Places: Bryan County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Cooke County, TX, Grayson County, TX

Title: Farmers in the Rio Grande Valley in Texas lost roughly half of the 90,000 acres of cotton planted in 2013
Description: Rio Grande Valley farmers lost roughly half of the 90,000 acres of cotton planted in 2013.  About half of the cotton is irrigated.  Roughly 60 percent of the 410,000 acres of grain sorghum planted in the Valley was destroyed by drought.  Eighty percent of the grain sorghum is grown without irrigation.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), Sept. 1, 2013
Places: Cameron County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Starr County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: Drought sapped agricultural income in Bastrop County, Texas in 2013
Description: Drought sapped agricultural income in Bastrop County in 2013, said the county extension agent.  The county’s overall agricultural income was $47.5 million in 2013, in comparison with the normal annual income of $55 to $60 million.  Hay production was $13 million in 2013, down from $26 million in 2012.  Pasture conditions were very poor due to the lack of soil moisture.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), March 10, 2014
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Hydropower generation down in central Texas
Description: Hydropower generation by the Lower Colorado River Authority was 69 percent lower in 2013 than in 2011, due to reduced flows from the Highland Lakes. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), May 23, 2014
Places: Burnet County, TX, Llano County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Atascosa County, Texas, lack of grass forces ranchers to sell cattle
Description: Soil moisture dried out from previous years lack of rainfall.  What little soil moisture there was evaporated quickly when this past summer' s 100-degree temperatures have arrived. Grass dried and turned crispy resulting in having to sell 2/3 of our cattle herd.  We run a grass-fed operation, so supplemental feed was not an option.   We are trying to learn and use drought mitigation techniques in order to quickly restock and resume operations.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Jourdanton 5.2 NNW on 10/2/2013
Places: Atascosa County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Collin County, Texas
Description: Collin County commissioners instituted a 90-day outdoor burn ban, due to the elevated fire danger from drought.  Commissioners also prohibited the sale of fireworks with sticks and fins and the use of fireworks in unincorporated parts of the county.  Outdoor fires were also forbidden in the city of McKinney, while a hot work permit program began, requiring persons doing cutting or welding to get a free permit before starting their work.  Dallas Morning News (Texas), Dec. 13, 2012
Places: Collin County, TX, McKinney, TX

Title: Sen. Troy Fraser and Sen. Kirk Watson sent a letter to the Lower Colorado River Authority in central Texas, urging them not to release water to rice farmers
Description: Sen. Troy Fraser and Sen. Kirk Watson sent a letter to the Lower Colorado River Authority (LCRA), urging them not to release water to rice farmers.  The senators assert that giving water to the rice farmers would violate a court order and an agreement with the city of Austin.  The senators also intend to pursue legislation to prohibit future water releases for irrigation and would support legal action to prevent the LCRA from releasing the water to rice farmers in the spring.  The LCRA’s water management plan allows water releases for irrigation when lakes Travis and Buchanan are at 42 percent of capacity or greater, which is what the lakes hold as of Dec. 12.  If the state does not receive more rainfall next year than it did this year and rice farmers get irrigation water in 2013, the water left in lakes Travis and Buchanan may be about 33 percent in early 2014, according to some calculations.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 12, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Colorado County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Austin, TX, Wharton County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: The fire danger from drought in central Texas prompted two large fireworks vendors to choose to pull certain fireworks from shelves, some counties banned aerial fireworks
Description: The fire danger from drought in central Texas prompted commissioners in Hays, Bastrop, Blanco and Burnet counties to ban fireworks with sticks and fins, while two large fireworks vendors in the area decided not to sell fireworks with sticks and fins to keep the public safe during the Christmas-New Year’s holiday season.  County commissioners in Travis, Williamson and Caldwell county discussed partial fireworks bans, but did not pass them.  Counties must decide by Dec. 15 whether or not they want to ban certain fireworks.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 11, 2012
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Hays County, TX, Travis County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Voluntary water conservation urged in Killeen and Fort Hood, Texas
Description: Killeen water officials and Fort Hood authorities urged residents to begin conserving water voluntarily since the Bell County Water Control and Improvement District No. 1 was in stage 1 of its Drought Contingency Plan.  The Bell County water district receives water from the Brazos River Authority, which recently announced a stage 1 drought watch for the Lake Georgetown-Stillhouse Hollow subsystem.  Killeen Daily Herald (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bell County, TX, Killeen, TX, Coryell County, TX

Title: 30-day burn ban for Williamson County, Texas
Description: Williamson County commissioners voted in favor of a 30-day burn ban on Dec. 4.  The emergency management coordinator recounted how a controlled burn escaped containment the previous day to help commissioners understand the elevated fire danger.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: The sale and use of fireworks with sticks and fins was banned in the unincorporated parts of Harris County, Texas
Description: The sale and use of fireworks with sticks and fins was banned in the unincorporated parts of Harris County by the Commissioners Court, due to dry conditions.  The Keetch-Byram Drought Index for the county on Dec. 2 averaged 575, which is also the trigger for prohibiting fireworks.  The season during which fireworks are often permitted extends from Dec. 20 to Jan. 1.  Other types of fireworks were still allowed, but all fireworks prohibited in the city of Houston.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Low lake levels in the Texoma region close many boat ramps
Description: "Lake Diversion, Kemp, Buffalo, Wichita, all those the boat ramps will be high and dry," stated an employee with the Texas Parks & Wildlife, as drought reduced water levels in those lakes.  The only open boat ramps at Lake Arrowhead were at the west end boat docking area.  Possum Kingdom has extended its boat ramps as the shoreline receded.  KAUZ-TV CBS 6 Wichita Falls (Texas), Dec. 3, 2012
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Clay County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Wichita County, TX

Title: Thirty-four Texas counties received authorization to use Conservation Reserve Program land for emergency grazing in the fiscal year 2013
Description: Thirty-four Texas counties received authorization to use Conservation Reserve Program land for emergency grazing in the fiscal year 2013 to alleviate the drought-induced shortage of forage for livestock.  The counties are Armstrong, Bailey, Briscoe, Carson, Castro, Childress, Crosby, Dawson, Deaf Smith, Dickens, Donley, Floyd, Gray, Hale, Hardeman, Hemphill, Hockley, Kent, Lamb, Lipscomb, Lubbock, Nolan, Ochiltree, Oldham, Parmer, Potter, Randall, Roberts, Scurry, Sherman, Swisher, Terry, Wheeler and Yoakum.  To be eligible for emergency grazing, the CRP land must not have been hayed or grazed in the past two years.  Those who use eligible CRP land will get 25 percent less than the usual annual payment.  KVII-TV ABC 7 Amarillo (Texas), Dec. 3, 2012
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Childress County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Donley County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Kent County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Wheeler County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Stage 1 drought watch for the Lake Georgetown-Stillhouse Hollow subsystem in Texas
Description: The Brazos River Authority alerted water customers who are in the Lake Georgetown-Stillhouse Hollow subsystem that a stage 1 drought watch was in effect for the subsystem, meaning voluntary water conservation is requested.  Communities in the Lake Georgetown-Stillhouse Hollow subsystem include Round Rock, Georgetown, Lampasas, Kempner Liberty Hill and Harker Heights and others.  The water services manager for the Brazos River Authority explained that falling reservoir levels reached thresholds in the Drought Contingency Plan, prompting the issue of the stage 1 drought watch.  Killeen Daily Herald (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bell County, TX, Harker Heights, TX, Killeen, TX, Coryell County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Kempner, TX, Lampasas, TX, Williamson County, TX, Georgetown, TX, Liberty Hill, TX, Round Rock, TX

Title: Some of the dryland wheat in the Panhandle, South Plains and the Rolling Plains of Texas has died or was withering from insufficient rainfall
Description: Some of the dryland wheat in the Panhandle, South Plains and the Rolling Plains has died or was withering from insufficient rainfall, stated AgriLife extension agents in Hansford County, Lipscomb County and Lubbock County.  The AgriLife extension agent for Wilbarger County said, “The lack of rain is really taking its toll on everything.  The wheat is really hurting, and cotton harvest is going to be short and fast. A lot of stocker cattle that were brought in are starting to leave the county.”  SouthWest Farm Press (Texas), Nov. 28, 2012
Places: Archer County, TX, Armstrong County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Borden County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Childress County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Cottle County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Donley County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Foard County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Jack County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Montague County, TX, Moore County, TX, Motley County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Wheeler County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Wise County, TX, Yoakum County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Conditions dire for crops in Foard County, Texas; stock water reserves low
Description: Foard County continues to suffer from below-average moisture fall. Calendar year 2011 was the driest year in recorded history at only 9.37 inches (61% below normal) and though rains have come more frequently in 2012, conditions are currently dire for fall/winter small grain grazing and grain (our primary cash crop). Though all intended acres have been planted, with little or no Oct./Nov. moisture fall the crop may soon be lost. Little or no grazing has resulted from fall plantings. In addition, though the county received normal to above normal rainfall totals from May through September, stock water reserves are still dangerously low.From Jeff Peterson, Farm Service Agency, Crowell, Texas, on November 28, 2012
Places: Foard County, TX, Crowell, TX

Title: About a third of the cotton crop in Tom Green County, Texas not worth harvesting
Description: Roughly 30 percent of the cotton crop in Tom Green County was plowed under because it produced so little cotton, said a Monsanto representative for the area.  The irrigated cotton was average to below average as the land struggled to recover from drought last year.  KJTV-TV 34 Fox Lubbock (Texas), Nov. 26, 2012
Places: Tom Green County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Walker County, Texas
Description: The Walker County Commissioner’s Court enacted a 90-day burn ban for the county, due to the high fire danger and drought conditions.  The average Keetch-Byram Drought Index for Walker County was 537 on Nov. 28.  The county received 38 inches of precipitation so far in 2012, and is 6 inches behind average rainfall.  The Commissioner’s Court will reconvene on Dec. 10 to evaluate the need for a ban on New Year’s Eve fireworks.  The Houstonian (Texas), Nov. 29, 2012
Places: Walker County, TX

Title: Wheat in west central Texas exhibited signs of moisture stress
Description: Wheat in west central Texas exhibited signs of moisture stress as dry, windy conditions existed in the region.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), Nov. 20, 2012

Title: Some wheat and oats on the Rolling Plains of Texas died
Description: Some wheat and oats on the Rolling Plains of Texas have died from the lack of moisture.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), Nov. 20, 2012

Title: Some livestock producers on the South Plains of Texas have begun to give their cattle supplemental feed
Description: Some livestock producers on the South Plains of Texas have begun to give their cattle supplemental feed.  Slow winter wheat growth, due to inadequate moisture, likely means that livestock will not be able to graze it unless the area receives rain soon.  Drovers Cattle Network (Kan.), Nov. 20, 2012

Description: The Brazoria County Emergency Management Office announced a burn ban effective from Nov. 16 through the end of February 2013 for the unincorporated parts of the county.  The Commissioners Court favored the ban and will consider a ban on aerial fireworks when they meet on Dec. 11.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Dec. 4, 2012
Places: Brazoria County, TX

Title: Many cotton fields in the South Plains of Texas were zeroed out by insurance adjusters
Description: Many cotton fields in the South Plains of Texas were zeroed out by insurance adjusters who deemed the fields to have low yield potential.  Early planted winter wheat displayed signs of moisture stress.  Lubbock Avalanche-Journal (Texas), Nov. 18, 2012

Title: Parched pasture and rangeland grasses in Far West Texas were turning brown
Description: Parched pasture and rangeland grasses in Far West Texas were turning brown.  Livestock feeding costs will remain high if more rain does not fall.  Lubbock Avalanche-Journal (Texas), Nov. 18, 2012

Title: Small grains in Central Texas were not growing well
Description: Small grains in Central Texas were not growing well, due to the lack of moisture.  Stock ponds were very low and in need of substantial rain to replenish them.  Lubbock Avalanche-Journal (Texas), Nov. 18, 2012

Title: Low soil moisture in the Coastal Bend of Texas kept some farmers from fertilizing
Description: Low soil moisture in the Coastal Bend of Texas kept some farmers from fertilizing.  Winter grazing crops need rain to continue growing.  Livestock continue to receive hay and protein supplements.  Lubbock Avalanche-Journal (Texas), Nov. 18, 2012

Title: Wheat in the Rolling Plains of Texas manifested signs of drought stress
Description: Wheat in the Rolling Plains of Texas manifested signs of drought stress by curling or turning blue.  Pecans from rainfed orchards were a little smaller than usual, due to the lack of rain this summer.  Lubbock Avalanche-Journal (Texas), Nov. 18, 2012

Title: The Lower Colorado River Authority in Texas seeking emergency drought relief for second year
Description: The Lower Colorado River Authority board agreed on Nov. 14 to seek emergency drought relief, which would mean keeping more water in the Highland Lakes and denying irrigation water to rice farmers near the Gulf Coast.  The LCRA submitted an application with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality for a second year of emergency drought relief.   KVUE-TV ABC Austin (Texas), Nov. 21, 2012

Title: Burn ban in the unincorporated parts of Travis County, Texas
Description: Travis County commissioners enacted a burn ban for the unincorporated parts of the county through Dec. 12.  The fire marshal pushed for the ban because low humidity, reduced soil moisture and dry vegetation have upped the fire danger.  The previous burn ban for the county ended on Sept. 14.   Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 13, 2012

Title: Increased demand for new wells in the vicinity of Austin, Texas

Many of the wells the business drills in Austin were for lawn watering because those wells were not affected by the city’s water restrictions.  Austin leaders passed an ordinance in October requiring homeowners to publicly register private wells in an effort to monitor water use from the northern edge of the Edwards Aquifer. Title: Political pressure pushing the Lower Colorado River Authority in Texas toward curtailing water supplies to rice growers again
Description: Political pressure is pushing the Lower Colorado River Authority toward curtailing water supplies to rice growers, although the LCRA said last month that rice growers would not likely go a second year without irrigation water.  Austin and Travis County passed resolutions urging the LCRA to make an emergency request to curtail irrigation supplies to rice farmers in Colorado, Wharton and Matagorda counties.  Residents near lakes Travis and Buchanan have also petitioned to release less water downstream.  Rice production fell by 75 percent this year without irrigation water along the lower Colorado River.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 11, 2012
