Title: Wildfire burned in Possum Kingdom Lake, Texas again
Description: A wildfire broke out in the drought-stricken Possum Kingdom Lake area on August 30 and had consumed at least 6,200 acres through August 31.  Flames blocked several dozen residents’ escape routes, forcing them to flee by boat.  Fire burned through the Possum Kingdom Lake area earlier this year, charring 160 houses.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 31, 2011
Places: Palo Pinto County, TX

Title: Fish kill on Lake Grapevine in northeastern Texas
Description: A fish kill involving at least 124,000 fish occurred at Lake Grapevine on August 29 and 30 when heat reduced the oxygen content of the water, according to a fisheries biologist for the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.  Many dead fish, which were mostly threadfin and shad, accumulated at the Silver Lake Marina near the dam. A sample of the fish killed indicated that less than 1 percent of the dead fish were game fish, stated a biologist.  A fisherman who often fishes by the dam was driven away by the strong odor of the dead fish.  The lake was about 3 feet below normal.  Grapevine Courier (Texas), Aug. 31, 2011
Places: Denton County, TX, Tarrant County, TX

Title: Mandatory water restrictions begin in Fort Worth, Texas area
Description: Mandatory water restrictions began on August 29 for the 1.8 million customers of the Tarrant Regional Water District in the Fort Worth area.  Lawn watering was allowed twice weekly.  The district’s Drought Contingency Plan called for the restrictions when storage capacity fell to 75 percent.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Aug. 25, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Denton County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Jack County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Parker County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: Cotton grower in Hockley County, Texas lost 3,000 acres of dryland cotton
Description: A cotton grower near Ropesville plowed down 3,000 acres of dryland cotton a few weeks ago, but the irrigated cotton wasn’t doing so well either.  The heat and drought evaporated the moisture too quickly for the irrigation to have much effect.  The grower strove to cut expenses by foregoing the three or four laborers that he usually hires.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 28, 2011
Places: Hockley County, TX

Title: Cotton gins preparing for small cotton crop in Texas
Description: Cotton gins were trying to cut expenses by hiring fewer workers and purchasing fewer supplies because the drought has devastated the cotton crop.  The owner of the Lubbock Cotton Growers intends to process the cotton with half as many employees as usual in 12-hour shifts over a one month period rather than over a three-month period of 24-hour shifts.  The owner of the Meadow Co-Op Gin also planned to hire half of his usual crew and expects to lose money.  Both operators were expecting roughly one-third the typical volume of cotton to come through their gins, based on the assessment of the Plains Cotton Growers that just 2 million bales of cotton would be produced rather than the typical 5.3 million bales.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 28, 2011
Places: Lubbock County, TX, Terry County, TX

Title: Business greatly decreased for agricultural equipment supplier in Lubbock, Texas area
Description: An agricultural equipment supplier with five stores in the Lubbock area stated that business was off by up to 75 percent.  He anticipated selling fewer strippers and other pieces of harvest equipment since agricultural production had been poor due to the drought.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 28, 2011
Places: Lubbock County, TX

Title: Property owners around Lake Conroe in Texas dissatisfied with declining water level
Description: The president of Lake Conroe’s Community news stated that property owners around Lake Conroe continued to express displeasure at the falling level of Lake Conroe, which was constructed in 1973 to serve as a back-up supply for Houston’s water treatment plants on Lake Houston.  More sandbars were appearing and making navigation dangerous.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 26, 2011
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Montgomery County, TX

Title: Salamander population in jeopardy at Barton Springs in south central Texas
Description: Drought has decreased the salamander population of Barton Springs and has particularly reduced the number of juvenile salamanders, according to the city biologist who manages the salamander population.  Drought in 2008-09 decreased the salamander population, but between the previous drought and the present one, the population did not recover well.  Salamander numbers are usually documented at Eliza Springs, where there were 600 before the 2008-09 drought and 35 adults and no juveniles during the 2008-09 drought.  Between droughts, the salamander population rose to 300.  At last count, there were 140 salamanders, including nine juveniles.  Research indicated that 25 percent of the adult salamander population dies when the oxygen content of the water falls to 3.6 milligrams of oxygen per liter of water, which was the present oxygen content of the water at Eliza Springs.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 26, 2011
Places: Caldwell County, TX, Hays County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Many horses auctioned off in Stephenville, Texas
Description: At an auction in Stephenville in August, 763 horses were up for sale since horse owners had no grass or hay for their animals and knew it would cost too much to feed them through the winter.  In October, 450 horses were sold as owners couldn’t afford hay.  Great Falls Tribune (Mont.), Nov. 7, 2011
Places: Erath County, TX

Title: People removing their boats from marina on Lake Conroe in Texas
Description: People were removing their boats from a marina on Lake Conroe as the water level continued to fall, according to an owner of a marina and RV park on the north shore of Lake Conroe.  He noted that boat traffic was about two-thirds of the usual amount.  The lake level fell about an inch daily, leaving the lake too low for large family boats, but was still tolerable for jet skis and small bass boats.  Some popular restaurants on the south end of the lake where there was greater water depth reported that no customers were arriving by boat because their docks were fixed, not floating, so that people could not disembark on the docks which were too high.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 26, 2011
Places: Montgomery County, TX

Title: Cattle graze on grass growing in the lake bed of Lake Palestine in northeastern Texas
Description: The low level of Lake Palestine, exposing some of the lake bed, allowed lush grass to grow, providing some excellent grazing for cattle.  Tyler Morning Telegraph (Texas), Aug. 26, 2011
Places: Anderson County, TX, Cherokee County, TX, Jacksonville, TX, Henderson County, TX, Smith County, TX

Title: Warm-hearted farmers in Luana, Iowa donated hay to ranchers in vicinity of Alvarado, Texas
Description: Warm-hearted farmers in Luana, Iowa have donated two flatbed semitrailers’ worth of hay and intend to purchase another three semitrailers’ worth of additional hay to send to ranchers in the vicinity of Alvarado, Texas.  One compassionate Luana farmer gave 50,000 pounds of hay because he sympathizes with the plight of the Texas ranchers.  Dubuque Telegraph Herald (Iowa), Aug. 25, 2011
Places: Clayton County, IA, Luana, IA, Johnson County, TX, Alvarado, TX

Title: Livestock producers in Southeast Texas selling cattle
Description: Livestock producers in Southeast Texas were selling older cattle and weaning calves early.  The declining water table made it increasingly difficult for ranchers to provide water for their cattle.  Lots of grain sorghum and rice were being cut for hay since many producers were desperately searching for hay.  Ranchers were worried about the nutritional quality of alternative forages and were seeking help on devising feeding strategies for the present and the upcoming winter months.  Trees in pastures were dying.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Brazoria County, TX, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Chambers County, TX, Fort Bend County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Hardin County, TX, Harris County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Lee County, TX, Liberty County, TX, Madison County, TX, Montgomery County, TX, Orange County, TX, San Jacinto County, TX, Walker County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Corn and milo baled for hay in Central Texas
Description: Most of the corn and milo crops in Central Texas were baled for hay.  Water supplies for livestock were depleted.  Many trees across the region had gone dormant or were dying.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bell County, TX, Bosque County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Erath County, TX, Falls County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Hamilton County, TX, Hill County, TX, Hood County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Leon County, TX, Limestone County, TX, McLennan County, TX, Milam County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Somervell County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Dryland corn in Texas Panhandle abandoned or chopped for silage
Description: Farmers in the Texas Panhandle abandoned the dryland corn or were chopping it for silage.  Pastures were rated to be in very poor condition since there was very little moisture in the soil.  Many livestock producers were selling some of their herds and weaning calves early.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: No field preparation being done in West Central Texas
Description: No field preparation for fall planting was being done in West Central Texas because the soil was simply too dry.  The condition of rangeland and pastures worsened.  Drought pushed wildlife into communities for food and water.  Producers sold livestock, but some were determined to keep at least a small herd, weather this drought and rebuild their herd when the rain returns.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Places: Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Concho County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Irion County, TX, Jones County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Sterling County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Dryland cotton failed, livestock being fed in Southwest Texas
Description: The concern about wildfires in Southwest Texas remains high as the drought wears on and dust storms blow.  Surface water supplies were dry.  There was relatively little forage availability.  Cotton that wasn’t well irrigated failed.  Livestock were receiving supplemental feeding.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bandera County, TX, Bastrop County, TX, Bexar County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Caldwell County, TX, Comal County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Gonzales County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Kerr County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Kinney County, TX, Medina County, TX, Real County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Uvalde County, TX, Wilson County, TX

Title: Texas peanut production hurt by drought
Description: Peanut growers in Texas were not able to overcome drought conditions with nonstop irrigation starting in May, stated the executive director of Lubbock-based Texas Peanut Producers Board.  Due to heat and strong winds in the spring, it became too hot for the plants to set pegs, which grow into the ground and become peanuts.  Some of the peanut plants look decent, but did not produce peanuts, leading farmers to stop irrigating and abandon the crop.  Others were choosing to bale the plants.  More than 70 percent of the peanut production in Texas occurs in the western part of the state, especially in Gains, Yoakum and Terry counties.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Places: Andrews County, TX, Armstrong County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Brewster County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Crane County, TX, Crockett County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Culberson County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Ector County, TX, El Paso County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Glasscock County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Howard County, TX, Hudspeth County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Jeff Davis County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Loving County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Martin County, TX, Midland County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Pecos County, TX, Potter County, TX, Presidio County, TX, Randall County, TX, Reagan County, TX, Reeves County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terrell County, TX, Terry County, TX, Upton County, TX, Val Verde County, TX, Ward County, TX, Wheeler County, TX, Winkler County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: North Texas ranchers looking out of state for hay, selling livestock
Description: Cattle in North Texas were given hay and supplements since rangeland and pastures were in very poor condition.  Feed dealers sought assistance from AgriLife Extension offices to find hay and had to look as far as Alabama for it.  Many producers were selling some or all of their herds since it was just too expensive to keep the cattle.  Surface water supplies were desperately low or dry.  Some soybeans had been harvested recently, but most were cut for hay.  Cotton, late-planted sorghum and peanuts were suffering.  There were reports of skunks and armadillos burrowing under homes in search of moisture and a reprieve from the heat.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bowie County, TX, Camp County, TX, Cass County, TX, Collin County, TX, Cooke County, TX, Dallas County, TX, Delta County, TX, Denton County, TX, Fannin County, TX, Franklin County, TX, Grayson County, TX, Hopkins County, TX, Hunt County, TX, Kaufman County, TX, Lamar County, TX, Morris County, TX, Rains County, TX, Red River County, TX, Rockwall County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Titus County, TX, Van Zandt County, TX

Title: Cotton matured early on South Plains of Texas
Description: Hot, dry conditions on the South Plains led cotton to mature about 30 days early, allowing farmers to stop irrigating.  The absence of soil moisture probably means that farmers won’t plant small grain crops this fall unless precipitation arrives.  Herds were sold or taken to feeding lots since pastures and rangeland were dry.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Places: Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Many cattle being sold in the Coastal Bend of Texas
Description: Many beef cattle producers in the Coastal Bend were forced to liquidate their herds rather than keep them during drought.  The cattle that remained needed feed and hay as there was no pasture.  Surface water supplies were depleted, requiring ranchers to pump or transport water for livestock.  Livestock producers were bringing in hay from out of state.  Many trees across the region had gone dormant or were dying.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Aransas County, TX, Austin County, TX, Bee County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Colorado County, TX, DeWitt County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Goliad County, TX, Jackson County, TX, Karnes County, TX, Lavaca County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Nueces County, TX, Refugio County, TX, San Patricio County, TX, Victoria County, TX, Washington County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Cotton crop failed on the Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: Most counties on the Rolling Plains have not received measurable precipitation in almost one year.  Most of the cotton crop failed and has been assessed for insurance purposes.  The irrigated cotton showed severe signs of drought stress.  The demand for hay was so high that it was sold even before the hay was baled.  Some hay growers had stopped irrigating the hay to instead water their cotton.  Ranchers sold more cattle, while ranchers who held onto their cattle wondered how they could maintain them through the winter.   The window for haying Conservation Program Acres will close on August 31, but grazing may continue through October 31.  Fish kills occurred at Lake Kemp as the water level dipped ever lower.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Places: Archer County, TX, Baylor County, TX, Childress County, TX, Clay County, TX, Cottle County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Foard County, TX, Hardeman County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Jack County, TX, Kent County, TX, King County, TX, Knox County, TX, Montague County, TX, Motley County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Throckmorton County, TX, Wichita County, TX, Wilbarger County, TX, Wise County, TX, Young County, TX

Title: Cattle sales continued in South Texas
Description: Rangeland and pasture conditions in South Texas ranged from poor to very poor.  Surface water supplies were low.  Cattle prices were slipping since many livestock producers had sold some or all of their herds.  Cattle body condition scores were falling, but supplemental feeding kept the animals in fair condition.  Some livestock producers purchased hay from Nebraska for their livestock.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Brooks County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Dimmit County, TX, Duval County, TX, Frio County, TX, Hidalgo County, TX, Jim Hogg County, TX, Jim Wells County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Live Oak County, TX, Maverick County, TX, McMullen County, TX, Starr County, TX, Webb County, TX, Willacy County, TX, Zapata County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Many livestock being sold in East Texas
Description: Many beef cattle producers in East Texas were forced to sell some or all of their herds rather than keep them during drought.  Surface water supplies were depleted, requiring ranchers to transport water for livestock.  Livestock producers were bringing in hay from out of state.  Many trees across the region were dying.  Pastures were brown.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 24, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Anderson County, TX, Angelina County, TX, Cherokee County, TX, Gregg County, TX, Harrison County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Houston County, TX, Jasper County, TX, Marion County, TX, Nacogdoches County, TX, Newton County, TX, Panola County, TX, Polk County, TX, Rusk County, TX, Sabine County, TX, San Augustine County, TX, Shelby County, TX, Smith County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Tyler County, TX, Upshur County, TX, Wood County, TX

Title: Grape production down in the Hill Country of Texas
Description: Wine grape growers in Hill Country could not irrigate enough to avoid a roughly 50 percent reduction in yield on about 500 acres of vineyards, according to a Texas AgriLife Extension Service viticulture adviser to the Gulf Coast region.  Overall, he estimated that the yield was down by 20 to 30 percent.  More rain was needed to improve the outlook for next year’s crop.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 23, 2011
Places: Bell County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Comal County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Crockett County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Kerr County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Real County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Val Verde County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Some alfalfa growers stopped irrigating because they could not irrigate enough in Wilbarger County, Texas
Description: Some area alfalfa farmers stopped irrigating because they could not irrigate enough to compensate for the toll that the drought and heat took on the crops, according to a management economist and extension professor with Texas AgriLife Research and Extension Center at Vernon.  Some area wells were low or had gone dry.  Cotton bore just one or two bolls per plant, making it not worthwhile to harvest.  It was also too dry to plant a winter wheat crop, making three consecutive crop losses for area farmers if no rain falls to allow them to plant.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), Aug. 23, 2011
Places: Wilbarger County, TX

Title: Drought, other factors limited peach crop in Hill Country of Texas
Description: Drought, a late freeze in February and an April frost contributed to the smaller number of peaches produced in the Hill Country, with drought being less of a factor than the cold weather.  An AgriLife Extension Service fruit specialist in Fredericksburg stated that poor weather lowered the peach crop by about 60 percent.  Some fruit stands already closed, due to the small crop.  A grower posted a notice on the Hill Country Fruit Council website that no peaches were available this year.  A peach grower west of Stonewall stated that he harvested just one-third the number of peaches that he did in 2010, but that he was happy simply to have a crop and barely break even.  The peaches were smaller than usual, due to the drought, but were sweeter than usual.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 23, 2011
Places: Bell County, TX, Blanco County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Comal County, TX, Coryell County, TX, Crockett County, TX, Edwards County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Kerr County, TX, Kimble County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Real County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Sutton County, TX, Travis County, TX, Val Verde County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Pines, red oaks dying in Montgomery County, Texas
Description: We had a lot of Red Oaks in our area die.  About half of the pines have also died.  I am seeing a lot of new oaks and pines sprouting but it will take a long time to replace what has died.  On 5 acres, I lost at least 20 trees.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Conroe 8.9 WSW on 8/19/2012
Places: Montgomery County, TX

Title: 250 counties in Texas have bans on outdoor burning
Description: There are 250 counties out of the 254 counties in Texas with burn bans in effect.  Only Jefferson, Orange, Willacy and Zapata do not have restrictions on outdoor burning.  The previous record number of counties with bans on outdoor burning occurred in 2006 when 221 counties had bans.  Texas exceeded that record in June 2011.  Baytown Sun (Texas), Aug. 19, 2011, Dallas Morning News (Texas), Sept. 12, 2011, and 12 News KBMT (Beaumont, Texas), Sept. 29, 2011
Places: Anderson County, TX, Andrews County, TX, Angelina County, TX, Aransas County, TX, Archer County, TX, Armstrong County, TX, Atascosa County, TX, Austin County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Bandera Title: Water releases from Lake Conroe to replenish Lake Houston to allow proper operation of water treatment plants for Houston, Texas
Description: Water has been released from Lake Conroe to replenish Lake Houston since August 16.  The releases began with 50 million gallons on August 16 and rose to 150 million gallons by August 18 to keep the level of Lake Houston high enough to allow proper operation of the intake pumps for the water treatment plant.  Lake Conroe was constructed in 1973 to serve as a back-up supply for Houston’s water treatment plants on Lake Houston.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 26, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Harris County, TX, Montgomery County, TX

Title: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas arranged for backup power supplies
Description: The Electric Reliability Council of Texas asked two electricity providers to reactivate two natural gas units each to make sure that the state has sufficient electricity and can avoid more rotating power outages.  NRG Energy and Garland Power and Light are prepared to provide a total of 400 megawatts if and when needed through October 2011.  There is concern that there may be inadequate supplies of cooling water for power plants if drought and heat persist.  These reactivated units will only be used to prevent power outages and will not be used when there is an adequate power supply.  Pearland Journal (Texas), Aug. 16, 2011
Places: Texas, Denton County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Freestone County, TX, Henderson County, TX, Jack County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Parker County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: Weatherford, Texas farmer has reduced yield, high electric bill from extensive irrigation
Description: The electric bill of an organic farmer near Weatherford rose from $250 to $1,100 as drought forced her to irrigate around the clock with well water until the well became nearly depleted.  The heat led her to harvest her produce during the night, but her crops weren’t producing as much as usual, leading to a drastic cut in her income.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), Aug. 16, 2011
Places: Parker County, TX

Title: Wildlife move from the high Chisos Mountains in Big Bend National Park in Texas
Description: Black bears in Big Bend National Park were no longer found high in the Chisos Mountains as drought dried up streams and vegetation, but have come down to lodges and campgrounds for food and water.  Their lean appearance revealed that they were not finding enough food.  The high mountains offered no running streams like usual.  Oak trees had wilted leaves or no leaves; dry orange and brown leaves lay on the ground; and there were no acorns, pine nuts and madrone berries that bears normally enjoy.  Many birds that are usually found in the high mountains, such as blue-throated hummingbirds, Colima warblers and band-tailed pigeons, were absent.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 12, 2011
Places: Presidio County, TX

Title: One hundred acre reservoir dwindled to just 4 acres in Harris County, Texas
Description: A rancher in southwestern Harris County observed that his 100-acre reservoir has dwindled to just four acres in the drought.  The pastures were dried up; weeds weren’t growing.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 11, 2011
Places: Harris County, TX, Hockley, TX

Title: Lack of water forced a rancher in Harris and Liberty counties in Texas to sell half of his herd
Description: A rancher and hay farmer with 1,500 acres in Harris and Liberty counties attempted to have his well deepened to provide water for his cattle.  Sadly, the well driller had such a backlog of service requests that he could not help the rancher before he was forced to sell half of his herd.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 11, 2011
Places: Harris County, TX, Liberty County, TX

Title: Graveyard for freed slaves revealed by low level of Richland Chambers Reservoir in Texas
Description: The level of the Richland Chambers Reservoir fell low enough to expose human remains from a graveyard for freed slaves that dates back more than one hundred years.  Water erosion unearthed the graves, then drought depleted the reservoir and revealed the bones.  The remains were first seen in 2009 during a dry spell, but were hidden again quickly as the water level rose.  WBAP-AM 820 Arlington (TX), Aug. 4, 2011
Places: Navarro County, TX

Title: Resident dissatisfied with access to Lake Conroe, Texas
Description: A resident who lives on the shore of Lake Conroe complained about the low water level and appearance of the shoreline.  Whereas he previously had shoreline, there was a lot of vegetation.  He cannot launch his jet ski or boat and was resigned to not being able to use the lake the rest of the summer.  He also noted that there were many barely submerged obstacles out in the water, making navigating the lake dangerous.  Fewer people seemed to be using Lake Conroe this summer, probably due to the low level of the lake, according to a Texas Parks and Wildlife game warden.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 3, 2011
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Tourism & Recreation, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Montgomery County, TX

Title: Just one public boat ramp useable on Lake Travis in Texas
Description: The water level of Lake Travis was receding, leaving just one public boat ramp useable.  Business at the marinas has fallen with the water level.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Aug. 3, 2011
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Boat ramps were closed due to low water level in Lake Houston, Texas
Description: Boat ramps in Duesen Park were no longer useable because the water level of Lake Houston was too low.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Aug. 4, 2011
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Rancher in Sutton County, Texas sold most of his cattle
Description: A rancher in Sutton County sold 80 of his cattle and kept just six cow-calf pairs as drought has devastated pasture and water supplies.  Given that the rancher was 74 years old, he thought that at some point he might decide to sell the last of his herd and quit ranching.  Galveston County Daily News (Texas), Aug. 3, 2011
Places: Sutton County, TX

Title: Farmer in Lamb County, Texas unable to irrigate enough
Description: A farmer in Lamb County has spent much more on irrigation than he did in all of 2010 and has less cotton to harvest.  He resorted to reducing his cotton acreage because he can’t adequately irrigate it all since it’s so dry.  The intense reliance on irrigation has lowered the water table in the area.  The general manager of a Co-op Gin in Amherst stated that it would be fortunate if farmers could bring in 16,000 bales to the gin this year, which is 37 percent of last year’s crop.  KCBD-TV NBC 11 Lubbock (Texas), Aug. 3, 2011
Places: Lamb County, TX, Amherst, TX

Title: Part from space shuttle Columbia found in drought-stricken Lake Nacogdoches in eastern Texas
Description: A spherical object 4 feet in diameter was exposed by the receding waters of Lake Nacogdoches and was found to be from the space shuttle Columbia, which broke apart before it could land in February 2003.  Shreveport Times (La.), August 2, 2011
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Nacogdoches County, TX

Title: Topsoil blowing, cattle being sold in pairs in Jim Wells County, Texas
Description: Corn is tassling at 2' to 3' high.  Showers have brought up the seeds that had not sprouted in the same fields and that corn is 2-3" tall in the same fields.  Topsoil is blowing with each gust of wind - cattle are being sold by pairs due to no feed and high hay prices.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Orange Grove 3.3 NW on 5/13/2013
Places: Jim Wells County, TX

Title: O. C. Fisher Reservoir in West Texas turned red
Description: The O. C. Fisher Reservoir in San Angelo State Park was almost dry and colored a deep red from the prevalence of Chromatiaceae bacteria, which flourish in oxygen-depleted water.  The fish have all died, although just last summer the reservoir was a choice fishing destination for anglers wanting to catch catfish, bass, sunfish and more.  Some people were alarmed at the color of the water and viewed it as proof that the Apocalypse was approaching.  CBS, August 2, 2011
Places: Tom Green County, TX

Title: Drought conditions fuel 425-acre fire in Smith County, Texas
Description: Selling livestock, stock ponds almost completly dry. I am a volunteer firefighter with troup fire and we did have a 425ac fire this week due to drought conditions and the fuel it has provided. Trees easily snap with very little wind or just fall completely on their own. Top layer of soil not very stable with hard ground under top layer of soil. No hay is being produced as fields have all stopped growing and dried up.
Places: Smith County, TX, Tyler, TX

Title: Nearly two dozen graves were found in a dry portion of the Navarro County reservoir in Texas
Description: Nearly two dozen graves were found in a dry portion of the Navarro County reservoir over the summer as the lids of some coffins were apparent just beneath the soil.  An excavation is planned to relocate the coffins from land that once belonged to a slave owner to a cemetery.  The falling water levels of many Texas lakes have exposed a number of artifacts.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Nov. 20, 2011
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Navarro County, TX

Title: Increasing number of boaters running aground on Lake Houston, Texas
Description: As the water level in Lake Houston recedes, a sergeant with the police boat patrol said that more people needed to be rescued after running aground on sandbars.  More obstacles that were previously underwater are exposed, such as an old railroad bed.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), August 1, 2011
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Oil producers look for water sources in Oklahoma
Description: Some Oklahoma oil producers have had to find alternate sources of water for their operations.

Title: Drought, high salinity devastating oysters on Texas Gulf Coast
Description: The salinity of Galveston Bay rose, allowing predators and disease to devastate the oysters.  Texas oyster men hoped to harvest plenty of oysters since the absence of the shellfish from Mississippi and Louisiana, due to the oil spill and flooding, would leave a void in the market.  There will likely be very few Gulf Coast oysters to be found this year.  Shrimp and blue crabs may also be in short supply.  The salinity of Galveston Bay has not been so high since the 1980s, according to the regional director of the coastal fisheries division of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), July 31, 2011
Places: Aransas County, TX, Brazoria County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Cameron County, TX, Chambers County, TX, Galveston County, TX, Jackson County, TX, Jefferson County, TX, Kenedy County, TX, Kleberg County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Nueces County, TX, Refugio County, TX, San Patricio County, TX, Victoria County, TX, Willacy County, TX

Title: The Big Tree at Goose Island State Park in Texas was watered by volunteer fire fighters
Description: The Big Tree at Goose Island State Park was being watered by volunteer fire crews as drought continued.  On July 27 the tree was given 13,000 gallons of water, which is the equivalent of about half an inch of rain.  The 44-feet tall live oak tree has a crown spread of 89 feet and a trunk that is 11 feet in diameter.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), July 28, 2011
Places: Aransas County, TX

Title: Seven of 11 boat ramps on Lake Somerville in central Texas closed due to low water level
Description: Seven boat ramps on Lake Somerville were closed as the water level fell to 230.70 feet on July 28, according to a park ranger with the Army Corps of Engineers.  Four ramps remained useable.  Lake Somerville was on track to fall below its previous low of 230.70 feet in a matter of days. The record low occurred in October 1984.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), July 29, 2011
Places: Burleson County, TX, Lee County, TX, Washington County, TX

Title: Extension agent in Waller County, Texas receiving more calls from concerned ranchers and farmers
Description: The Waller County extension agent stated that he has received more telephone calls than usual during the past two weeks as the tension and stress continued to build for ranchers and farmers desperately waiting for rain.  He also noted that deer were venturing into people’s yards for food and water to survive.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Aug. 11, 2011
Places: Waller County, TX

Title: Sales more than double at the Abilene Livestock Auction in Texas
Description: Sales were up at the Abilene Livestock Auction since drought has cut into pasture and water supplies for cattle.  The yard foreman at the Abilene Livestock Auction estimated that 2,800 cattle were to be auctioned on July 26, up from the average of 1,200 animals.  Abilene Reporter-News (TX), July 28, 2011
Places: Brown County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Comanche County, TX, Eastland County, TX, Erath County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Haskell County, TX, Howard County, TX, Jones County, TX, Kent County, TX, Jayton, TX, Knox County, TX, Mills County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Stephens County, TX, Stonewall County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Abilene, TX, Throckmorton County, TX

Title: Jones, Kent county ranchers bringing cattle to sell in Abilene, Texas
Description: Ranchers from the Abilene area gathered to sell their livestock at auction as drought made it more difficult for ranchers to provide feed and water for their livestock.  A rancher from Jones County culled almost two-thirds of her cattle herd of 140 cattle since she couldn’t feed them.  The cattle had grazed grass down to the roots, which will make it harder for the grass to recover when the rain does return.  She said that it broke her heart to sell so many cattle.  A Kent County rancher brought 150 of his and his neighbor’s cattle to sell.  He stated that they were selling more of their herd than ever before and regretted having to sell, knowing that it will take years to rebuild his herd.  Abilene Reporter-News (TX), July 28, 2011
Places: Jones County, TX, Kent County, TX

Title: West Texas Food Bank received fewer donations as drought hurts ag production
Description: The West Texas Food Bank (WTFB)  has less to offer those in need as drought reduces the amount of produce farmers have to donate by roughly 25 percent.  In addition, demand was rising.  A spokesperson for the El Paso branch of the WTFB stated that they receive as much as half of their donations from farmers and individuals.  The WTFB serves 22 counties.  KVIA-TV ABC 7 El Paso (Texas), July 25, 2011
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Drought prompting Austin, Texas bats to come out earlier to find food
Description: Mexican free-tailed bats in Austin have been emerging earlier than usual from beneath the Ann Richards Congress Avenue Bridge as they travel further to reach their food sources.  Bugs were becoming increasingly scarce as drought reduced the amount of growing vegetation for the insects to eat, prompting the bugs to move into irrigated farmland.  With bats coming out earlier in the evening, they were under greater threat from predators, such as hawks.  Bats are very beneficial and performed a pest control service worth about $741,000 for eight counties in south central Texas, according to a study done in 2006.  Austin American-Statesman (TX), July 24, 2011
Places: Travis County, TX, Austin, TX

Title: One public boat ramp open at both Lake Buchanan and Lake Travis in central Texas
Description: Just one of the four public boat ramps at Lake Buchanan was still useable as water levels continued to fall.  At Lake Travis, only one of 11 public boat ramps was open.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 21, 2011
Places: Burnet County, TX, Llano County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: High volume of livestock sales at Coleman Livestock Auction in central Texas
Description: The owner of the Coleman Livestock Auction stated that ranchers have been selling calves early, due to the drought and lack of pasture and water.  Nearly 4,700 livestock were sold at auction on July 20, which is almost four times the number sold during the same week in 2010.  The auction owner lamented, "We're selling the mothers off, which is the ... factory of our business.  The cattle ain't here no more.  People need to see what's going on, it's devastating."  The executive director of the Livestock Marketing Association of Texas stated that panic selling was occurring in some pockets of the state as ranchers feel that they ought to sell while the price is high.  Galveston County Daily News (Texas), Aug. 3, 2011
Places: Coleman County, TX

Title: Massive numbers of livestock being auctioned in Gillespie County, Texas
Description: Ranchers brought 2,725 livestock to auction at Gillespie Livestock Co. in Fredericksburg for a sale that began at noon and ended at 1:45 a.m.  Drought and dry pastures left cattle with little to eat, prompting ranchers to choose between buying hay or selling livestock. The previous week when ranchers brought 3,610 cattle to auction, which set a new high for the number of animals sold there in a day, sales continued until 3:45 a.m.  The drought was also leading goat and sheep producers to sell many animals with 5,070 up for sale on July 19.
Places: Gillespie County, TX

Title: More residents in Dallas County, Texas consulting animal shelter about wildlife
Description: The Parker County Animal Shelter received a greater number of calls than usual about a wide variety of animals, according to the field supervisor, as drought brings the animals into closer contact with humans.  The shelter received a call from a man who was displeased that water moccasins from a dried up creek nearby had taken up residence in his backyard pond.  An officer from the shelter noted that there were at least a dozen water moccasins in the pond.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), July 18, 2011
Places: Parker County, TX

Title: Wildlife in the Panhandle and South Plains of Texas were perishing from the lack of food and water
Description: Wildlife in the Panhandle and South Plains of Texas were perishing from the lack of food and water and were unable to care for their young.  Pregnant does were giving birth prematurely, were unable to produce milk for their fawns, due to the does’ poor health, and left the fawns to fend for themselves.  Ten abandoned fawns were recently taken to the South Plains Wildlife Rehabilitation Center in Lubbock for care.  Songbirds and birds of prey also were also leaving their young because they were not able to find enough food to provide for themselves and their young.  There were fewer places to release the animals once the center had rehabilitated them because area water sources have become depleted.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), July 18, 2011
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Wheeler County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: Homeowner associations experience fish kills in Dallas County, Texas
Description: A pond consultant with a fishery in Coppell stated that the hot, dry weather was causing many fish kills in ponds in a number of homeowner associations.  Another problem that often occurs during drought when ponds become depleted is that noxious weeds and algae to thrive and reduce oxygen levels.  Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), July 18, 2011
Places: Dallas County, TX, Coppell, TX

Title: Guadalupe-Blanco River Authority in Texas encouraged its water customers to conserve water
Description: The Guadalupe-Blanco River Authority encouraged its water customers to conserve water and follow local drought restrictions.  The flow at Spring Branch into Canyon Reservoir was 1.4 cubic feet on July 10, whereas the median inflow is 161 cfs.  The San Marcos Spring flow was 107 cfs, but the median flow is 164 cfs.  KXAN-TV NBC 36 Austin (Texas), July 15, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Caldwell County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Comal County, TX, DeWitt County, TX, Gonzales County, TX, Guadalupe County, TX, Hays County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Refugio County, TX, Victoria County, TX

Title: Farmers in El Paso County, Texas, have less water for irrigation
Description: Some farmers in the Rio Grande watershed, including those in El Paso County, Texas, will have one less irrigation period this year, nine instead of the usual 10. The irrigation season will also end sooner, Aug. 28 instead of Sept. 11.El Paso Times, July 15, 2011
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Lake levels low, grass conditions poor in Lubbock County, Texas
Description: Our lake is about 5 feet low so all recreation except canoeing and fishing has been stopped. Also I have had to supplement my horses with feed due to poor grass conditions.
Places: Lubbock County, TX, Ransom Canyon, TX

Title: Well output dropping in Burnet County, Texas
Description: Mid July our well dropped by 50% output. Sept 1 the well output dropped again to about 100 gal/day. The well was only operated three to four times/day for livestock and personal use. Sept 7 the well is now completly dry. Having to bring water for livestock and personal use. Hopefully today, Sept 19 will get first water delivered in newly installed tank system (1500 gal cap). Plan to expand to 2000 gal cap in several weeks. Cost per month till water table rises will be about $300. Unknown cost to drill deeper at this point but several thousand $.
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Only two public boat ramps open at Lake Travis in central Texas
Description: Only two of the 11 public boat ramps at Lake Travis were open as drought continued to lower the water level.  Odessa American (Texas), July 12, 2011
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Black bears returned to Brewster County, Texas
Description: Drought and wildfires prompted black bears to leave Mexico and recolonize the Big Bend National Park and Black Gap Wildlife Management Area where they can access water from the Rio Grande River.  A natural resource management professor at Sul Ross State University stated that it wouldn’t be unusual for the bears to wander into Trans-Pecos communities in search of food and water.  Black bears used to inhabit the area.  Odessa American (Texas), July 11, 2011
Places: Brewster County, TX

Title: Producer in Parker County, Texas, reports dry pastures, tree loss, dry stockponds
Description: Pastures are extremely dry and brown even with irrigation. Animals are now supplemented with extra hay and brought in from the pasture in the afternoon and out of the sun due to extreme heat conditions. I have lost several large trees due to extreme drought. Stock pond is completely dry so livestock now receive supplemental water from well.CoCoRaHS Report from Aledo 2.9 SW on 7/7/2011
Places: Parker County, TX

Title: Drought emergency proclamation extended for Texas
Description: Governor Perry renewed the proclamation extending the drought emergency for much of the state of Texas.  Office of the Governor Rick Perry, Nov. 1, 2013.The governor of Texas extended the drought emergency proclamation another year because another hot, dry summer kept reservoirs and aquifers from being replenished.  The counties included in the declaration are Andrews, Aransas, Archer, Armstrong, Bailey, Bandera, Baylor, Bee, Borden, Bosque, Bowie, Briscoe, Brooks, Burnet, Callahan, Cameron, Carson, Castro, Childress, Clay, Cochran, Collingsworth, Cooke, Cottle, Crockett, Crosby, Culberson, Dallam, Dawson, Deaf Smith, Dickens, Dimmit, Donley, Duval, Edwards, El Paso, Erath, Fannin, Fisher, Floyd, Foard, Gaines, Garza, Gillespie, Gray, Grayson, Hale, Hall, Hamilton, Hansford, Hardeman, Hartley, Haskell, Hemphill, Hidalgo, Hill, Hockley, Hood, Hudspeth, Hutchinson, Jeff Davis, Jim Hogg, Jim Wells, Johnson, Jones, Kendall, Kenedy, Kent, Kerr, Kimble, King, Kleberg, Knox, La Salle, Lamar, Lamb, Lipscomb, Live Oak, Lubbock, Lynn, McMullen, Medina, Mitchell, Montague, Moore, Motley, Nolan, Nueces, Ochiltree, Oldham, Parmer, Potter, Presidio, Randall, Real, Red River, Refugio, Roberts, San Patricio, Schleicher, Scurry, Shackelford, Sherman, Somervell, Starr, Stephens, Stonewall, Sutton, Swisher, Taylor, Terry, Throckmorton, Val Verde, Webb, Wheeler, Wichita, Wilbarger, Willacy, Wise, Yoakum and Zapata. Title: Brazos County, Texas fire departments prepare for busy fire season
Description: Drought contributed to increased fire activity in Brazos County, which is a concern for fire chiefs who do not have sufficient personnel and equipment to meet the challenge.  Drought conditions were not expected to improve soon and were anticipated to lead to a bad fire season.  To prepare for wildfire outbreaks, the fire departments in Brazos County were aiming to create a Wildland Strike Team with better communication between fire departments and increased mutual-aid response when wildfires occur.  Bryan-College station Eagle (Texas), July 3, 2011
Places: Brazos County, TX

Title: Sale and use of fireworks prohibited in Taylor County, Texas
Description: Fireworks sales and the use of fireworks were prohibited in Taylor County because the drought makes it too dangerous to risk starting a fire.  In addition, all violators of the law in rural parts of the county will be ticketed.  City ordinances forbid the possession or use of fireworks in Abilene.  The county already had a burn ban in effect.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), July 2, 2011
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Water users asked to voluntarily limit water use in Austin County, Texas
Description: Ranchers ponds have dried up; watering cattle have died drinking too much water; purchase of hay has begun; pastures and lawns are brown; local businesses are selling more processed cattle food; many ranchers are cutting their cattle herds; energy customers were asked beginning yesterday to limit energy use between 3-5 because of overloaded system; water users have been asked to voluntarily limit use of water especially for lawns and flowers; heat advisories began today for heat indexes above 105; white-tailed deer have been reported drinking from swimming pools; outdoor burn ban has been in effect for most of the year.
Categories: Agriculture, Energy, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Austin County, TX

Title: Fireworks canceled in Williamson County, Texas
Description: Two Fourth of July fireworks displays were canceled at Dell Diamond, due to the drought and the burn ban. Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 7, 2012
Categories: Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Drought, water restrictions keep nursery sales down in Lavaca County, Texas
Description: I run a small plant nursery in a rural area. While I seem to have enough water from my well to keep things watered, many of my customers are on water restriction, so my sales are down. The yard looks very sad with drooping vines on the fences, since I only use water for the nursery, the landscape, other than our fig tree, has to fend for itself. Our well is old and quite shallow- only about 80 ft. deep and has to also serve the home.
Categories: Business & Industry, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Bee keeper in south central Texas sustained bees with sugar water and pollen supplement
Description: A bee keeper with 130 hives at various locations in south central Texas provided sugar water and a pollen supplement because drought depleted most natural sources of nutrition in the region.  Despite his efforts to nourish the bees, roughly 30 percent of the colonies died.  Austin American Statesman (Texas), March 23, 2012
Places: Guadalupe County, TX, Seguin, TX, Travis County, TX, Sunset Valley, TX

Title: Delayed start to fireworks sales in Bastrop, Hays, Travis and Williamson counties in Texas
Description: Fireworks vendors in Travis, Williamson, Hays and Bastrop counties chose to begin fireworks sales on July 1 rather than on June 24 as state law permits.  The delayed start to the firework sales season reduces the length of time that fires may inadvertently started by fireworks.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 9, 2011
Places: Bastrop County, TX, Hays County, TX, Travis County, TX, Williamson County, TX

Title: Edwards County, Texas, rancher facing losses
Description: Rain total at our ranch since Oct 1, 2010 is 2.32 inches. We are in the process of selling off our livestock as are many ranchers in our area. Drought is having a drastic effect on wildlife with the hottest months of the year coming up, many will not survive. Our water wells are all holding up OK, but have heard of several that are going dry & water table is falling off significantly. Monetary losses are difficult to determine, but are substantial. PRAY FOR RAIN!!!!CoCoRaHS Report from Rocksprings 8.5 WSW on 6/24/2011
Places: Ector County, TX

Title: Producers purchasing hay for horses in Denton County, Texas
Description: No precipitation in the last 30 days, combined with less than half of normal precipitation for the calendar year. Normally, we would not be feeding hay to our horses until the fall, when the grass stops growing. This year, we have had to purchase and feed hay that is being brought in to Texas from states to the west and north, which is very expensive. Horse hay prices have more than doubled in the last 2 months in N. TX.
Places: Denton County, TX

Title: Trees stressed, ponds drying up in Jack County, Texas
Description: It has been 49 days without rain - one day less than .01 hundredth was noticed, and more than 41 straight days with temperatures between 102 and 113. Today, I counted two Live Oaks, three Plums, and five Redbuds have all either dropped their leaves - or all their leaves are dead on the tree. This means severe shock from heat and lack of rainfall. All grasses are dead, dust devils roam every day over the plowed wheat fields, and all my neighbors have sold the majority of their cattle. My ponds have lost eleven to twelve feet of depth. Perhaps now would be a good time to hire a dozer, to dig out and enlarge my ponds to hold more water and raise the Conservation Depth Level that keeps the pond water from reaching 90+ degrees when oxygen depletion begins and aquatic life starts to fail. Whenever it rains again - my property drains rainfall from over 2000 acres - so if it rains 3.5 inches in one go - the ground saturates, and the water overflows two lakes north of me, and about a dozen other ponds that each overflows into another - until all that water meets from three directions and empties into my property into both of my ponds, and on into the Keechi Creek - that is a tributary of the Brazos River –meeting it 17 miles downstream - just below the Possum Kingdom Lake Dam. So - that is the only upside I can see from this drought - increase depth and area of my 3/4's dried ponds, and pray for better days of lower temperatures and rainfall.
Places: Jack County, TX

Title: Wichita County, Texas, bans fireworks, and municipal display is postponed
Description: Wichita County banned fireworks in 2011, and a few hours later, the city of Wichita Falls banned its planned municipal display. The city event is rescheduled for September. In an accompanying disaster declaration, the county said that drought created the possibility of large, fast-moving wildfire.Wichita Falls Times Record News, June 23, 2011
Places: Wichita County, TX

Title: El Paso, Texas, offers fireworks amnesty
Description: El Paso County authorities offered residents a week-long period of fireworks amnesty in which they could turn in fireworks. This comes after the county banned the sale, use and possession of fireworks. El Paso Times, June 23, 2011
Places: El Paso County, TX

Title: Rain helped contain fire in Grimes County, Texas
Description: Rain helped contain the Grimes County fire that had burned almost 5,300 acres and more than 70 homes and other buildings. A fire in Trinity and Polk counties that had burned more than 20,222 acres and two homes was 80 percent contained. The Texas Forest Service was battling 17 large fires that had consumed more than 145,000 acres. Austin-American Statesman, June 23, 2011
Places: Grimes County, TX, Polk County, TX, Trinity County, TX

Title: Rain helps end wildfire in Grimes County, Texas
Description: The Dyer Mill Fire in Grimes County had burned about 5,280 acres in and around Plantersville, Stoneham and Todd Mission, a lower estimate than the 6,100 provided earlier, because of better mapping technology. The fire was about 75 percent contained after the rain. The fire -- which most hurt the Millstone subdivision but also affected Pine Brook and Shadow Woods -- sparked Sunday at a barbecue on private property. It burned 30 homes, three businesses, and up to 35 more structures. Residents were being allowed back into their homes after being evacuated for a few days. More hot, dry weather was forecast.Bryan-College Station, Texas, Eagle, June 23, 2011
Places: Grimes County, TX

Title: Southeast Texas faces wildfire
Description: Wildfire in Grimes County, Texas had burned almost 5,300 acres and more than 70 homes and other buildings. Fire in Trinity and Polk counties had burned more than 20,222 acres and two homes. The Texas Forest Service was battling 17 large fires across 145,000 acres. A total of about 2,000 residents had been evacuated.  Austin-American Statesman, June 23, 2011
Places: Texas, Grimes County, TX, Houston, TX, Jasper County, TX, Kendall County, TX, Polk County, TX, Potter County, TX, Trinity County, TX, Walker County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Shifting soils necessitate frequent water pipe repairs in Guadalupe County, Texas
Description: The crack in the gumbo soil is now 42" deep. Was only 33" deep on 1 June. Have seen signs of 3 major repairs of water conduits within 1/2 mile of our place in the past week, due primarily to shifting soil. Our rural water supply system had a capital replacement project a few years ago, else there would be many more breaks now. In those days, the water pressure would go down to zero, everyone would call around to see if their water was also affected, we'd drive around to see where the break was, call it in, and wait for the water supplier to make the repair. Sometimes the water would be off for a couple hours. The capital replacement system has reduced the frequency of these incidents.CoCoRaHS Report from Marion 2.2 SSW on 6/15/2011
Places: Guadalupe County, TX

Title: Salt water barrier navigation lock closed to protect Houston, Texas water supply
Description: The salt water barrier navigation lock of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Galveston District’s Wallisville Lake Project was closed to prevent salt water from nearing the water intakes for Houston and Lake Anahuac.  Drought reduced the flow of the Trinity River to the extent that salt water was encroaching further upstream than normal.  The lock is opened hourly between 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. each day to permit boats to pass.  Digital Video and Imagery Distribution System (GA), June 15, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Chambers County, TX

Title: Workers put out small fire at Port Arthur Total refinery
Description: Drought appears to have been a contributing factor to a small grass fire at the Total Petrochemicals refinery in Port Arthur.Beaumont, Texas, Enterprise, June 14, 2011
Places: Jefferson County, TX

Title: Amarillo and county officials offer fireworks amnesty
Description: The city of Amarillo and Potter and Randall counties announced a fireworks amnesty program, offering to pick up and dispose of illegal fireworks. The announcement came a day after someone started a fire by launching fireworks. Fireworks are banned due to drought and heat.
Places: Amarillo, TX, Randall County, TX

Title: Trees dying in Harris County, Texas
Description: I copied this from the message board on the site I help administrate on.  It fits for most of our area. I am noticing the same in W. Houston. "Hey everyone - the situation is getting extremely dire for us. he Trees up here north of town are in a desperate situation. There are whole stands of pines now that have turned brown and are dying off. I've also seen a large number of oaks, especially white oaks, that are also turning completely brown. At the front of my neighborhood there is a tree buffer between some houses and the main road. The entire buffer (mostly pines with a few oaks) has now turned brown. I'm afraid the whole section will need to be chopped down.Un-irrigated shrubs are toast too."Of course the continuing triple digit temps aren't helping at all either. Many outlying communities already have water restrictions and I expect more and more to be added.CoCoRaHS Report from Spring Valley 2.7 NW on 6/14/2011
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Williamson County, Texas, plans to ban sale of fireworks
Description: Fireworks will not be for sale during the Fourth of July in Williamson County because of the drought. Williamson County Judge Dan Gattis issued a disaster declaration on June 14, 2011, banning the sale of fireworks. The declaration would be in effect for 60 hours, and then it can be sent to Gov. Rick Perry, who can extend it up to 30 days.  Under state law, it is legal through July 4 to sell fireworks in counties but not within city limits. Austin-American Statesman, June 14, 2011
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Texas Gov. Perry backed Travis County's fireworks ban until July 5
Description: Governor Rick Perry will consider Travis County’s order declaring a local state of disaster and banning the sale and use of any fireworks. Perry has indicated that he would grant an extension of the order until July 5, according to county staff.Austin-American Statesman, June 14, 2011
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Agriculture losses climb to $150 million in Rolling Plains of Texas
Description: The Rolling Plains region lost an estimated $150 million due to drought, according to a Texas Extension Agriculture economist.  Because agriculture losses translate to less spending in the local economy, the economist stated that the loss for the region was $500 million.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 13, 2011

Title: Water companies in South Texas urging residents to reduce water use
Description: Water companies in South Texas were urging residents to reduce water use as supplies become depleted.  The need to conserve water presents a challenge for companies that drill for oil and gas using a process called hydraulic fracturing, which, in the Barnett Shale region, can require as much as 13 million gallons of water per well.  Washington Post (D.C.), June 13, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Atascosa County, TX, Austin County, TX, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, DeWitt County, TX, Dimmit County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Gonzales County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Karnes County, TX, La Salle County, TX, Lee County, TX, Live Oak County, TX, Maverick County, TX, McMullen County, TX, Milam County, TX, Washington County, TX, Webb County, TX, Zavala County, TX

Title: Drought reduced wheat yields in Wilbarger County, Texas despite irrigation
Description: Irrigated wheat yields were down, due to drought, stated the Wilbarger County agriculture agent.  He noted that farmers cut off the wheat heads for cattle feed and left the rest to hold the soil in place.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 13, 2011
Places: Wilbarger County, TX

Title: Cotton producers in the Rolling Plains of Texas struggled to irrigate enough to be able to plant
Description: Cotton producers on the Rolling Plains of Texas struggled to irrigate enough to be able to plant.  Some cotton growers used light tillage called “scratching” to break the hard surface of the soil to permit the cotton plants to emerge more easily.  Other cotton growers had to replant their fields.  Blowing sand and soil erosion were still problems even in areas that had received rainfall recently.  Stock tanks were going dry, leaving little for livestock.  Ranchers continued to sell cattle.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 11, 2011

Title: Drought, heat and winds slowed forage growth in North Texas
Description: Drought, heat and winds slowed forage growth in North Texas.  Early season hay harvests were a little below normal.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 11, 2011

Title: Very little grass was growing in the Central region of Texas
Description: Very little grass was growing in the Central region of Texas.  Stock tanks were going dry.  Some farmers made their first cutting of hay, which was anticipated to be roughly 50 percent of a normal cutting.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 11, 2011

Title: Pastures in the Coastal Bend region of Texas suffering from the heat, drought
Description: Pastures in the Coastal Bend region were suffering from the heat and drought, forcing farmers to offer more supplemental feed for the livestock.  Sorghum matured more quickly than usual.  Wichita Falls Times Record News (TX), June 11, 2011
Places: Aransas County, TX, Austin County, TX, Bee County, TX, Calhoun County, TX, Colorado County, TX, DeWitt County, TX, Fayette County, TX, Goliad County, TX, Jackson County, TX, Karnes County, TX, Lavaca County, TX, Matagorda County, TX, Nueces County, TX, Refugio County, TX, San Patricio County, TX, Victoria County, TX, Washington County, TX, Wharton County, TX

Title: Public fireworks display permits not issued in Travis County, Texas
Description: The public Fourth of July fireworks display in Austin, Pflugerville, the Lake Travis area and Travis County were canceled because the Austin Fire Department did not approve permits for the public displays due to drought, heat and strong winds.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 9, 2011
Places: Travis County, TX, Austin, TX, Pflugerville, TX

Title: Fireworks banned through July 5 in multiple Texas panhandle counties
Description: Fireworks were banned through July 5 in Potter, Randall, Hall, Parmer, Carson, Moore, Donley, Hartley and Collingsworth counties since the governor extended the disaster declarations that were originally made at the county level.
Places: Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Donley County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Moore County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX

Title: Stocker cattle producers in Falls County, Texas transferred cattle to feedlots
Description: Stocker cattle producers in Falls County have transferred cattle to feedlots since pastures were very dry and hay production was much lower than usual, according to the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  Corn, milo and cotton also exhibited symptoms of severe drought stress.  Odessa American (Texas), June 9, 2011
Places: Falls County, TX

Title: Fireworks outlawed in Potter and Randall counties in Texas
Description: Fireworks were outlawed in Potter and Randall counties as the drought made the use of fireworks too dangerous.  Violators of the fireworks ban in these counties will be arrested, stated the mayor of Amarillo.  Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), June 9, 2011
Places: Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX

Title: Hay production down dramatically in Wood County, Texas
Description: Hay production in Wood County was down dramatically, according to the AgriLife Extension agent for the county.  He knew of farmers who had gotten just 25 to 50 percent of a normal first cutting.  Odessa American (Texas), June 9, 2011
Places: Wood County, TX

Title: Fireworks banned in Tom Green County, Texas
Description: Tom Green County commissioners banned the use of  fireworks due to the drought.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), June 8, 2011
Places: Tom Green County, TX

Title: Chambers County, Texas rancher spent $5,600 to provide water for his livestock
Description: A rancher near Winnie spent about $5,600 to have a well deepened, to purchase a pump and tank and to have a power pole installed.  He needed to provide an alternate water source for his longhorn cattle after the stock tank went dry.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), June 8, 2011
Places: Chambers County, TX

Title: Drought spurred record cattle sales at Brazos Valley Livestock Commission in Texas
Description: The general manager of the Brazos Valley Livestock Commission stated that record numbers of livestock were sold there in April and May as ranchers sold animals at good prices rather than feed them.  The highest livestock sales totals occurred in past five months as some ranchers chose to quit ranching.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), June 8, 2011
Places: Brazos County, TX

Title: Fireworks with sticks and fins outlawed in Taylor County, Texas
Description: Taylor County commissioners chose to outlaw the sale and use of fireworks with sticks and fins in unincorporated parts of the county while drought persists.  County commissioners also renewed the burn ban to last through September 5.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 7, 2011
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Fireworks with sticks and fins banned in Orange County, Texas
Description: The Orange County Commissioners Court has banned the sale and use of fireworks with sticks and fins in the unincorporated portions of the county.  Extreme drought conditions have increased the fire danger within the county.
Places: Orange County, TX

Title: Several Texas panhandle counties enacted disaster declarations, sought extensions from governor
Description: Authorities in Potter, Carson and Armstrong counties adopted 60-hour disaster declarations to prevent the sale and use of fireworks.  It was hoped that the governor of Texas would extend the declarations through the July 4 holiday to reduce the likelihood of fires inadvertently set by fireworks.  Parmer and Hall county officials also sought an extension of county disaster declarations, with Hall County receiving an extension.  Strong winds, heat and drought have increased the fire danger in the region.
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Carson County, TX, Hall County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Amarillo, TX

Title: Roughly 10 percent of the cotton fields south of Victoria, Texas did not emerge
Description: Roughly 10 percent of the cotton fields south of Victoria did not emerge due to the lack of moisture, according to a cotton and sorghum grower from Corpus Christi.  He said that crops north of Victoria fared much worse than those to the south.  Southeast Farm Press, June 7, 2011
Places: Victoria County, TX

Title: Fireworks with sticks and fins prohibited in Williamson County, Texas
Description: The Williamson County Commissioners Court prohibited the sales of fireworks with sticks and fins as the persistent drought raises the fire danger.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), June 7, 2011
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Fireworks prohibited in Stonewall County, Texas
Description: The Stonewall County judge issued an order prohibiting the sale and use of fireworks in the county for 60 hours and requested that the governor extend the order through July 5.  He was concerned that fireworks might ignite additional wildfires in the county in which 108,000 acres had already burned.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), June 7, 2011
Places: Stonewall County, TX

Title: Fireworks sales and use banned in the unincorporated parts of Harris County, Texas
Description: Harris County Commissioners Court prohibited the sale or use of fireworks with sticks and fins in the unincorporated portions of the county.  Fireworks are not permitted within Houston's city limits.  Firework sales begin on June 24.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), June 7, 2011

Title: Conditions too dry for planting sorghum in Armstrong County, Texas

Title: Forage growth in the Rolling Plains region of Texas was delayed
Description: Forage growth in the Rolling Plains region was delayed 14 to 28 days in response to drought and the cool spring.  Farmers were waiting for rain before planting cotton, but insurance deadlines may force them to plant without the rain.  Wheat yields were much lower than normal, leading some farmers to forgo the harvest.  Rain was desperately needed to fill stock tanks and to allow pastures to grow.  Some livestock producers were shipping cattle out because there was no pasture for them.   Wichita Falls Times Record News (Texas), June 4, 2011
Categories: Agriculture, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
