Title: Forage for livestock scarce, wildfires occurring in Kerr County, Texas
Description: Forage for livestock is way down. Wildlife is increasing competition with livestock for grazing and browsing. We are having to supplement with purchased hay, an economic hardship for us as it is something we only expect to do in the winter. As a firefighter, we are spending more time fighting fires, and we are responding full priority to the smallest grass fire. We are no longer permitted our burn barrels, and have had to switch off our electric fences. As a family, we elected not to plant any decorative plants this year. We are very concerned that our well will dry up this August.
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Society & Public Health
Places: Kerr County, TX

Title: Drought affects water supply, landscape, river flow, human and wildlife health in Kerr County, Texas
Description: Significant water conservation activity. Landscape deterioration. River flow slow requiring extra health precautions when swimming/boating. Deer health deteriorating. Allergy problems surfacing. Severe fire danger. Outside activities curtailed. CoCoRaHS Report from Hunt 5.8 WSW on 6/28/2011
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kerr County, TX

Title: Dryland wheat damaged by drought in the South Plains
Description: Dryland wheat in the South Plains region was severely hindered by dry conditions and in some fields was a complete loss, according to AgriLife Extension agents.  El Paso Times (Texas), March 1, 2011
Places: Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: West central Texas grains hurt by cold temperatures, drought
Description: Winter wheat and other small grains in west central Texas manifest significant damage from bitterly cold temperatures and drought, according to AgriLife Extension agents.
Places: Brown County, TX, Burnet County, TX, Callahan County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Concho County, TX, Fisher County, TX, Irion County, TX, Jones County, TX, Lampasas County, TX, Llano County, TX, Mason County, TX, McCulloch County, TX, Menard County, TX, Mills County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Runnels County, TX, San Saba County, TX, Schleicher County, TX, Shackelford County, TX, Sterling County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Tom Green County, TX

Title: Rancher near Elkhart, Texas recalled measures taken to survive drought of 2011
Description: To survive the drought in 2011, a rancher near Elkhart kept only her pregnant cattle as grass and hay supplies dwindled and two springs that flowed even during the 1950s drought finally stopped flowing.  She flagged down trucks carrying hay to find out the source of the hay in an attempt to get some for her animals.  Her family unloaded hay bales at 4 a.m. and spent $140,000 on hay.  Her son found a job in San Antonio to bring in some additional money.  She sold more livestock at a loss in an effort to reduce the demand for hay on her ranch.  She and other ranch hands began work at 4:30 a.m. on hot summer days because the heat was too intense by 10:30 a.m. to continue working outdoors.  The cattle herd was whittle down from 500 animals before the drought to 370 head.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), May 25, 2012
Places: Anderson County, TX

Title: Reduced pasture growth causes agricultural producer to rely in stored hay near Fairview, TX
Description: Reduced growth of spring grazing forage. More reliance on stored hay. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Fairview 1.5 ESE, submitted 3/17/2011)
Places: Collin County, TX

Title: Preparations for spring planting in Liberty County postponed due to drought
Description: The lack of rainfall forced farmers to postpone preparations for spring planting, according to AgriLife Extension agents.  El Paso Times (Texas), March 1, 2011
Places: Liberty County, TX

Title: Little winter wheat pasture for grazing in Deaf Smith County
Description: Livestock producers were searching for pasture since dry weather kept winter wheat pastures from providing much, if any, forage for cattle, according to the AgriLife Extension agent for Deaf Smith County.  SouthWest Farm Press, Feb. 28, 2011
Places: Deaf Smith County, TX

Title: Grass fires in Howard County
Description: There have been a number of grass fires in Howard County, according to the county AgriLife Extension agent.  He attributed the fires to dry weather and strong winds.  SouthWest Farm Press, Feb. 28, 2011
Places: Howard County, TX

Title: San Patricio County pastures lack adequate moisture
Description: Pastures have not had enough precipitation to recover well in San Patricio County after a recent cold spell, according to the county AgriLife Extension agent.  SouthWest Farm Press, Feb. 28, 2011
Places: San Patricio County, TX

Title: Dry weather limited pasture growth in Trinity County
Description: Dry weather limited pasture growth in Trinity County, leading producers to search for hay in other counties, according to the county AgriLife Extension.  Stock ponds were also low since there has not been enough rain to fill them.  SouthWest Farm Press, Feb. 28, 2011
Places: Trinity County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 3/7/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Mason and Llano counties received scattered showers on March 4.  Rainfall amounts ranged from 0.00 inched to 0.25 inches. These are reports from producers and using the LCRA weather stations. Surface water continues to dwindle and rivers and creeks are holding steady to slowly decreasing. Livestock feeding is being carried on and at a higer rate than usual. The small amout of rainfall received was welcome but fell way short of changing the drought conditions in either county. Impact Source:  Government
Places: Mason County, TX

Title: Major grass fires in the Texas Panhandle
Description: Major grass fires in the Texas Panhandle on 2/27/2011 some still burning. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Texline 0.3 WNW, submitted 2/28/2011)
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Livestock sales in San Angelo, Texas at least three times higher than usual
Description: Livestock sales at auction in San Angelo have been three times higher than usual for the past six months, according to the general manager.  He also noted that there were many cattle changing hands in country trades, making the number of livestock being sold more than three times the usual number.  From mid-May through mid-June, about 11,000 sheep and goats were sold weekly, stated the sheep and goats sales manager.  GO San Angelo/San Angelo Standard Times (Texas), Aug. 23, 2011
Places: Tom Green County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Guadalupe County
Description: The Guadalupe County commissioners’ court implemented a 90-day burn ban for the county at the request of the fire marshal because windy, dry weather and increasing fire danger have led to a greater number of wildfires.  On February 12 – 13, there were 18 fires, which was a burden for the volunteer fire department.  Seguin Gazette-Enterprise (TX), Feb. 23, 2011.
Places: Guadalupe County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Madison County
Description: The Madison County Commissioners enacted a day burn ban for the unincorporated parts of the county since there have been many accounts of outdoor burns that escape containment recently.  The county had a burn ban several weeks ago, but rescinded the ban on January 24 after adequate rainfall had lowered the fire danger.   The ban will remain effective for 90 days unless conditions change.  Madisonville Meteor (TX), Feb. 17, 2011.
Places: Madison County, TX

Title: The National Guard stepped up preparation for wildfires in western Texas
Description: The National Guard has helicopters ready for immediate dispatch in San Antonio and Austin in case of wildfires and has also placed additional aerial firefighting equipment in Abilene, Fredericksburg and Sweetwater.  Little precipitation has fallen west of Interstate 35 in recent months, leading to increased danger of wildfires due to various levels of drought, strong winds and dry grasses.  WOAI NBC 4 San Antonio (TX), Feb. 16, 2011.
Places: Bexar County, TX, Gillespie County, TX, Nolan County, TX, Taylor County, TX, Travis County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire impact from Government submitted on 4/14/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Young County is experiencing a severe drought.  Cattle raisers have suffered an 85% loss of grazing and have been forced to supplemental feed. Ranchers have had to reduce herd size due to lack of pasture. Wheat crops are being failed, and producers are making alternate management decisions because they cannot carry the crop to harvest.We have been under red flag warnings and burn bans with high winds, frequently above 30 mph, and no measurable rainfall since the freeze of Jan 4, 2011.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire, Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 5/2/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Young County is still experiencing a severe drought. Although minimal rains have fallen in some parts of the county, they have not penetrated the soil to promote new growth. Extreme winds have caused even drier conditions which have caused loss to row crops, native and improved grasses. Ranchers continue to supplemental feed their livestock. Tanks, creeks and streams are low and producers who have been allowed to irrigate off those streams have been asked to stop. Fluctuating temperatures continue to cause uncertainty for crops livestock and producers.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Public submitted on 4/14/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Lack of rain for over two months has caused extra feeding to become necessary.  Hay is now in short supply.  Last year's hay is all we have.  Not only is it too early for this year's hay but the lack of rain has made new hay doubtful.  It may become necessary to reduce the herd.Impact Source:  Public
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 5/9/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Dry conditions continue to plague Young County. Ranchers are still suffering from grazing losses, as well as losses due to wildfire activity. High winds and high temperatures (over 100 degrees)have continued to create dry conditions that are not suitable for growth of native pasture, improved grasses, and row crops. Supplemental feeding continues to be a costly management decision that ranchers are forced to make to support their herd size.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Grass fires in Parker County affect air quality in Tarrant County
Description: Even though we had snow it was a dry powdery snow with little if any actual moisture. There have been grass fires to the west of us in Parker County and to the northwest. The smoke in the air combined with existing unhealthy air makes it hard on my COPD. (Report for CoCoRaHS Observer at Fort Worth 12.5 NW, submitted 2/21/2011)
Places: Tarrant County, TX

Title: Wildfire in and around Lubbock County, TX
Description: Several wildfires broke out in and surrounding Lubbock County on 2-27, some homes had to be evacuated. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Lubbock 5.6 S, submitted 3/2/2011)
Places: Lubbock County, TX

Title: Vegetation showing signs of stress near Lubbock, TX
Description: The smaller pond at the park at 93rd and Memphis in Lubbock is literally reduced to mere puddles, but during a flood this pond usually gets so high it is impassable on the pavement. Only two of my bluebonetts have sprouted this season, due to very dry soil. The soil in my flowerbeds is extremely dry, despite my watering. However, there is still quite a bit of spring green around the neighborhood. Lots of wildfires. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Lubbock 5.6 S, submitted 4/4/2011)
Places: Lubbock County, TX

Title: Colorado River Municipal Water District asks its customers for 10 percent reduction in water use
Description: The Colorado River Municipal Water District asked its water customers to reduce their water use by 10 percent because its three supply lakes, Lake J.B. Thomas, E.V. Spence Reservoir and O.H. Ivie Reservoir are at 6, under 3 and just over 30 percent, respectively.  The CRMWD plans to enact mandatory water restrictions of 10 percent during the summer if substantial rain does not alleviate the water shortage.  Odessa American (TX), Feb. 7, 2011.  The Colorado River Municipal Water District board members voted to reduce water deliveries by an additional 10 percent starting July 1 as lake levels dwindled further.   Odessa American (Texas), June 8, 2011
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Borden County, TX, Coke County, TX, Coleman County, TX, Concho County, TX, Ector County, TX, Big Spring, TX, Mitchell County, TX, Runnels County, TX, Scurry County, TX, Snyder, TX

Title: Trees, crops stressed by lack of rainfall in Washington County, Texas
Description: Lost 2 large oaks, stock tank dry, all pasture vegetation stressed, impressive surface cracking (clay soils), burn ban in effect from February, wild fire burned over 20 sq. miles centered 15 miles from our property, lost most vegetable crops in spite of watering from our well, electric bill 20% higher than last year due to continuing 100+ degree days for 3 months, strong (20-30 mph) continuous daytime winds over March through May compounded drying out process.
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Washington County, TX

Title: Water accessibility for recreation reduce, fire risk increased in Erath County, TX
Description: Lake levels are down making getting a boat on the water difficult. Grass is dry and crisp when you walk across your lawn. This dry grass has increased the danger of fire making any small fire a potential to grow out of control very fast. The area has been under a burn ban for several weeks with no significant signs of rain to give hope that the ban will be lifted any time soon. Local farmers are having to feed hay to keep live stock fed and healthy. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Stephenville 2.6 NNW, submitted 3/16/2011)
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Erath County, TX

Title: Spring grasses and stock ponds decline near Shiner, TX
Description: With only .55 in. rain scattered out over the last 1 1/2 months we're starting to see our spring grasses decline and water levels dropping in our stock ponds. (Report from CoCoRaHS Observer at Shiner 5.1 ESE, submitted 3/17/2011)
Places: Lavaca County, TX

Title: Rancher's herbicide didn't absorb properly without rainfall in Gonzales County, TX
Description: It has been 24 days since there has been any form of measurable precipitation. It has been 71 days since there has been at least 0.10" in one day. It has also been 96 days since we have received 0.25" of rain in one 24-hour span. The ground is becoming more and more barren. Green grass has become brown, and mowing it is no longer a real concern. Hot weather mixed with high winds have added an extremely high fire danger to the mix. Without grass growing, ranchers are finding it increasingly difficult to make regular cuts of hay. One ranch has lost at least $1,800 for applying a herbicide to kill sand burrs. However, without rainfall the herbicide did not absorb properly. Some dead grass is still present, so feeding prices for cattle and horses has not risen yet. However, if the drought persists, ranchers' feed prices could rise in the next few weeks. CoCoRaHS report from Smiley 0.4 NNE on 4/22/2011.
Places: Gonzales County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 2/7/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Mason and Llano counties for the week of Feb-1 to Feb 7:  Conditions were very harsh last week with extreme cold temps and high winds. There is no winter grass available so the the hard freeze had no effect. Stands of native vegetation are poor due to the extreme drought in the fall. Sub moisture is at the top 2 to 3 inches then nothing for at least the next 2 feet. Livestock feeding is considerably above average and available livestock water is dwindling. Some ranchers are reporting they are having to haul water due to dry stock tanks. Some moisture was received in the form of snow and ice but only in small amounts.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Mason County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire impact from Government submitted on 3/15/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Producers reporting grazing losses for small grains and grasses.  Also some reports of selling off livestock have been made.  Burn ban in effect for the entire county indicates grazing quality is down and fire hazard is increased.  Six fires in the county in the last five weeks.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Comanche County, TX

Title: Wells, water sources drying up in Kendall County, Texas
Description: Water well has gone dry and must truck in water from town. Doing laundry at laundromat. Several trees have died or are dying. Shrubs and grasses are dead or dying. Wildlife is eating anything that has some green left. All the creeks in the county have dried up. Major river is a trickle at my house and dries up a few miles south of here. Severe wildfire danger.
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kendall County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Cameron County, Texas
Description: There has been a ban on outdoor burning in Cameron County since January, due to drought.  County authorities keep renewing the ban because the fire danger remains elevated.  Brownsville Herald (Texas), April 12, 2011; May 6, 2011; and June 2, 2011
Places: Cameron County, TX

Title: A rancher in Granger, Texas had to sell most of her livestock
Description: A rancher in Granger sold 145 of her 225 cattle because her pasture was dry and feed prices had risen by 40 percent.  Beaumont Enterprise (Texas), Dec. 16, 2011
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Public submitted on 2/2/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Week of 01/24 to 02/02, conditions in both Mason and Llano are still very dry. Due to lack of moisture and excessive winds. The recent cold front brought with it some moisture but only in amounts of 0.50 or less, according to LCRA and local comments.  I personally drilled a hole with a post hole digger last weekend and at 3 foot no sub moisture could be found. There was some submoisture for the approx. the first 3 inches but nothing after that.  Heavier than normal livestock feeding is underway, Livestock culling is higher than normal.  Livestock Water supplies are at approximatly 40% of compacity:--this includes dirt tanks,creeks and rivers. Available livestock forage is very poor and basically unavaiable.Impact Source:  Public
Places: Mason County, TX

Title: Plants & Wildlife impact from Public submitted on 4/19/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Creeks stopped running and are dry in many places. Wildlife coming into populated areas for water and forage.Impact Source:  Public
Places: Fort Bend County, TX, Harris County, TX, Waller County, TX

Title: Beef cattle herds in Texas continuing to recover from 2011
Description: Beef cattle producers in Texas were continuing to recover from 2011, the driest year on record for the state, as they cut their beef cow herds by about 20 percent for a loss of more than one million beef cattle.  By 2014, the number of beef cattle in Texas was 3.9 million, the lowest since 1958, according to National Agricultural Statistics Service.  In the Brazos Valley, beef cattle herds numbered 167,000 head.  In January 2016, the beef cattle population in Texas continued to rise to nearly 4.3 million statewide and 183,000 in the Brazos Valley as producers continued to rebuild herds.  "Since the drought was so severe, it really colors everything after," said Dave Anderson, Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service agricultural economist. "A drought that severe takes multiple years for plant life to recover."  He also noted that the slow herd growth was partially attributable to urban development, rising costs and the lingering effects of drought.Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), Aug. 28, 2016
Places: Texas, Brazos County, TX, Burleson County, TX, Grimes County, TX, Houston County, TX, Leon County, TX, Madison County, TX, Milam County, TX, Robertson County, TX, Washington County, TX

Title: The West Harris County Regional Water Authority in Texas took in roughly $10 million in surcharges for increased water sales
Description: The West Harris County Regional Water Authority took in roughly $10 million in surcharges for increased water sales during drought.  Revenue thus far in 2011 was $36.7 million.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Nov. 16, 2011
Places: Harris County, TX

Title: Drought depletes groundcover in Texas' Palo Duro Canyon
Description: Two photos taken a year apart from the Palo Duro Canyon State Park (Texas) visitors center are attached. 2010 was very wet - and one year later, 2011 is in exceptional drought. The differences in vegetation are striking. The area in the photographs is mostly Armstrong County. In 2011, the grasses and other low-lying ground cover is non-existent, exposing the light colored soils.From Ron McQueen, Lubbock NWS, July 12, 2011
Places: Armstrong County, TX

Title: Extensive wildfires lead Burnet County (Texas) community to seek Firewise Community status; recreation curtailed on lakes Travis and Buchanan
Description: Mainly in 2011, we had extensive wildfires in Texas and had to be extremely careful about fires and protecting homes.  My community is becoming a Firewise Community.  Our lakes Travis & Buchanan are very low and recreation and fishing have been mostly curtailed.  We are blessed that our well is OK.  The summer heat was extreme last year, taking a toll on animals and electric bills.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Buchanan Dam 7.4 NNE on 4/21/2012
Places: Burnet County, TX

Title: Drought taking a toll on plants and butterflies in Montgomery County, TX
Description: Constant vigilance on wildfires, reviewing daily reports and communicating. Personally have been watering public areas, to save trees and vegetation. Now trying to save a pine in my own yard that has been attacked by beetles. Pines are very vulnerable to beetles in a drought. Butterfly counts are way down, both in species and in numbers. The forest wilted and many hardwoods are dead already. 06/11 - first substantial rain in months.CoCoRaHS Report from The Woodlands 1.4 WNW on 6/22/2011
Places: Montgomery County, TX

Title: Water Supply & Quality impact from Public submitted on 3/30/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Sam Rayburn Reservoir is really low.Impact Source:  Public
Places: Nacogdoches County, TX

Title: A cattle rancher west of San Antonio, Texas sold 75 percent of his livestock
Description: A cattle rancher west of San Antonio sold 75 percent of his livestock during the recent drought and cannot begin to rebuild his herd because he had not received enough rain to fill stock tanks.  The rancher also noted that creeks were not running.  Houston Chronicle (Texas), Jan. 4, 2014
Places: Bexar County, TX

Title: North Texas ranchers not ready to rebuild cattle herds
Description: Some North Texas ranchers remained wary of rebuilding their cattle herds as drought and low water supplies persisted and the cost of cattle continued to be prohibitive.  Before the drought, which began about four years ago, live cattle traded for $0.95 per pound, but at present were selling for $1.62 per pound.Fort Worth Star-Telegram (Texas), March 25, 2015
Categories: Agriculture, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Collin County, TX, Dallas County, TX, Denton County, TX, Ellis County, TX, Erath County, TX, Franklin County, TX, Grayson County, TX, Hood County, TX, Hunt County, TX, Johnson County, TX, Kaufman County, TX, Lamar County, TX, Navarro County, TX, Palo Pinto County, TX, Parker County, TX, Red River County, TX, Rockwall County, TX, Somervell County, TX, Tarrant County, TX, Wise County, TX

Title: No cotton crop in Taylor County, Texas; wildfires increasing, wildlife looking for water
Description: I did not plant winter wheat last year, no summer hay this year and the outlook for more La Nina promises more dry weather. No cotton in our area. Our VFD has logged more fires this year (8 months) than in previous full years. Of 7 stock tanks, one has a little water. A recent 1.63 inches of rain did not close the cracks in the bottoms of the tanks. A 350 acre fire near our north fence burned through heavy mesquite and juniper. Normally, there are "skeletons" of the trees. Much of this burned completely to the ground leaving few standing above ground. Most cattle herds are gone in the area. Last week, 6 horses were found dead on a ranch about 100 miles east of here with feed but no water. A few towns are building pipelines to other water sources. Deer and othe game are very stressed. Of 4 nestings of barn swallows and black phoebes on our porch, no young survived to fledge this year. Currently at 67 100+ days and 17 high temp records. This exacerbates the drought raises electric power use and shortages.
Categories: Agriculture, Energy, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Producers feeding cattle, cutting back herds in Pecos and Terrell counties in Texas
Description: Submitted on behalf of the Pecos/Terrell County Farm Service Agency Committee:  A lack of rainfall is causing producers in Pecos and Terrell counties to have to put out feed for livestock's main source of food; not even as a supplement.  The area has never recovered from the 2011 drought.  Many producers are already having to cut back their herds and sell.  Herds are being reduced and people are talking about selling out completely.From Pecos County, Texas, on March 21, 2018
Places: Pecos County, TX, Terrell County, TX

Title: Producer begins selling cattle in Victoria County, Texas
Description: 8/15/11 - began feeding cattle every bite they eat, nothing left in pastures but dirt. Sold calf crop early, to take pressure off cows. Will begin selling cows as hay inventory drops. Very little hay available for sale - mostly maize stalks or rice straw in situations where it is not economical to go for second crop of rice.
Places: Victoria County, TX, Inez, TX

Title: Cattle thefts continued in Texas
Description: Cattle theft remained a problem in Texas, particularly as drought has driven cattle prices up in recent years.  Fewer livestock have been stolen because ranchers sold off animals as drought gripped the state in 2011, so there were fewer animals to steal.  In 2011, there were 804 reported cases of theft, involving 13,000 livestock stolen or missing, while the value of recovered livestock came to about $4.07 million.  In 2012, there were about 790 reported cases of theft, including 6,320 livestock stolen or missing.  The value of recovered livestock amounted to $3.3 million.  In 2013, there were 700 reports of stolen livestock, involving 4,200 livestock.  Authorities recovered $2.2 million in livestock.  Since cattle production was down, prices for livestock were at record highs in 2014 when there were 726 cases of stolen livestock, involving 5,325 animals valued at $4.89 million, an uptick of more than $800,000 from 2011.  KGBT-TV CBS 4 Harlingen (Texas), Oct. 28, 2015

Title: Efforts to bolster the pronghorn population in the Trans-Pecos region of Texas were on hold until drought abates
Description: Efforts to bolster the pronghorn population in the Trans-Pecos region of Texas were on hold until drought abates in West Texas.  Two hundred pronghorn antelope were transported from the Dalhart area to Presidio County in 2011, but at least 63 of the animals succumbed to predators, a stress-related condition, parasites, collisions with vehicles and other things.  Of the 80 animals tracked with radio collars, 63 have died.  There was less cover for birthing does, leaving the pronghorn antelope more exposed to predators, such as coyotes, mountain lions, bobcats and golden eagles.  Livestock producers grazed their cattle on the grass, further reducing the cover for does giving birth.  The existing pronghorn antelope already present in the Trans-Pecos region was also diminished by the drought.  The deer population decreased by 40 percent on some ranches as food and water became difficult to find.  Amarillo Globe-News (Texas), March 6, 2012
Places: Brewster County, TX, Presidio County, TX

Title: Dickens County, Texas, wells going dry, ranchers reducing size of herd
Description: Drought just keeps getting worse here.  Hearing reports of wells going dry and people having to haul house water if they can find it.  Most stock tanks are dry and have been for 3 years now. Cattle men are still culling their herds trying to keep the best they have in case it starts to rain again.  I have raised very little hay now since 2010.  The taxing people just keep raising our taxes and there isn't any income to pay them.  The drought is hurting the wild life also. This is so much worse than the 50's spell we had here.  Also, most of the water wells are turning much more goopy and salty than in years past turning the ground white where the pivots are running.  In short, it just doesn't look good for this area at all.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Dickens 2.3 SW on 5/8/2014
Places: Dickens County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 5/9/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Conditions continue to get worse in the county.  Isolated areas received good rainfall on May 1, that did run a small amount of water but 90% of the county did not get those rains.  No rainfall was received in the past week and the excessive heat, over 100 degrees, has caused additional problems for producers. There is no soil moisture for producers to plant hay crops and there has not been any stream flow to run water.  Pastures continue to burn up and ponds are drying up rapidly.  Conditions are worse than the week before but small chances of rain are in the forecast, which all are hoping will occur.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Stephens County, TX

Title: Record high cotton abandonment on the High Plains of Texas
Description: Fifty-four percent of the 4.53 million acres of cotton on the High Plains of Texas were abandoned, making this the highest abandonment rate for the Plains Cotton Growers, an association including 41 counties on the High Plains of Texas.  There were 2,476,960 acres of dryland cotton planted, and most of that—2,179,071 acres—were lost to drought, according to the Farm Service Agency.  Since insurance claims were still being processed, it remains to be seen whether or not the remaining 297,889 acres of dryland cotton are harvestable.  There were 1,919,307 acres of irrigated cotton, of which, 227,920 acres had failed, leaving another 1.69 million acres for harvest.  The average abandonment rate ranges from 15 to 20 percent.
Places: Andrews County, TX, Armstrong County, TX, Bailey County, TX, Borden County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Castro County, TX, Cochran County, TX, Crosby County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Dawson County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Dickens County, TX, Floyd County, TX, Gaines County, TX, Garza County, TX, Hale County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hockley County, TX, Howard County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lamb County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Lubbock County, TX, Lynn County, TX, Martin County, TX, Midland County, TX, Moore County, TX, Motley County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Parmer County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Swisher County, TX, Terry County, TX, Yoakum County, TX

Title: New Braunfels, Texas, institutes water rationing
Description: Rainfall at this station was 33" in 2010 and 19" in 2011.  Stage 3 water rationing went into effect on 8/10/2012.  This is the first time the city has been at stage 3.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #New Braunfels 2.4 S on 9/6/2012
Categories: Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Comal County, TX, New Braunfels, TX

Title: More than 25,000 pecan trees in San Saba County died from drought in 2011
Description: More than 25,000 pecan trees in San Saba County died from drought in 2011.  Many pecan growers were waiting until 2013 to do the majority of the replanting.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Nov. 6, 2012
Places: San Saba County, TX

Title: Animal rescue sees increase in feed costs in Kerr County, Texas
Description: The costs of running an animal rescue have increased dramatically. Hay needs to be purchased and fed all year instead of just the winter. The feed stores are rationing hay purchases and the price is approximately $15 for a 2 strand rectangular bale, large round bales are $165. The wildlife have little to eat or drink. There has been some rainfall in the past month but it is too little at this point to provide any significant grass. Some horse rescues nearby are not accepting any horses due to the cost of feed and gas.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Harper 6.5 SW on 1/30/2012
Places: Kerr County, TX

Title: Many native plants and trees dying in Comal County, Texas
Description: 6.41" of measurable rain since 01/01/2011 - probably some 20-21" below normal. Seems to be establishing a new normal. Many native plants and trees (Live Oak, Mountain Laurel, Cedar) are dying or dead. Wildlife very tenuous we are beginning to see a deer die-off as the food sources are very scarce. Homeowners are seeing very valuable landscape trees and shrubs die and will experience additional costs to have the dead trees removed. Grass is non-existant. This has become the worst I've seen in my 63 year lifetime. Drought leads to more heat and more drought. Reservoir and lake levels approaching 50% and less. Cattle are being sold cheap, below investment levels. Wells haven't gone dry, yet but we are beginning to be concerned. Cities have been under water usage restrictions for a long time now. Water mains in cities are rupturing. Recreational use of rivers and lakes is impededed. Cannot calculate the economic costs to public and private enterprise. Long range forecasts are not promising.
Places: Comal County, TX

Title: Drought cut sorghum production by 60 percent in the Texas Panhandle in 2011
Description: Drought cut sorghum production by 60 percent in the Texas Panhandle in 2011, and at least 90 percent of the sorghum seed is produced in the Texas Panhandle.  As a result, farmers may not be able to find supplies of sorghum seed, stated a forage and cover crop specialist for Millborn Seeds in Brookings, South Dakota.  Yankton Press & Dakotan, (S.D.), May 11, 2012
Places: Armstrong County, TX, Briscoe County, TX, Carson County, TX, Collingsworth County, TX, Dallam County, TX, Deaf Smith County, TX, Donley County, TX, Gray County, TX, Hall County, TX, Hansford County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Hemphill County, TX, Hutchinson County, TX, Lipscomb County, TX, Moore County, TX, Ochiltree County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Randall County, TX, Roberts County, TX, Sherman County, TX, Wheeler County, TX

Title: Extreme heat, drought in Maverick County, Texas
Description: We have been under extreme fire alert for virtually a year. A field across from me of only 5 acres flared so quickly it was gone (brush and grass) within minutes. Tinder dry is not descriptive enough. Ground deeper than I care to dig over 24 inches is dry. Irrigation continues to be possible along the Rio Grande but at a high cost to agriculture as allotments have been used and water now when available must be purchased at high rate. Only significant rains since 09/2010 were 2 days mid August of less than an inch and that varied across the county. When speaking to "old hands" in their 80's none can remember such a drought. We have had hotter summers but our "normal" heat with weeks in the hundreds with no rain has impacted immensely. Many folks in agriculture are quitting. Mesquite trees are dying that have lived over a century. Prickly pear that in years past could be used as range feed is withering. Brown outs have become common to conserve energy. High energy bills are impacting the poor particularly the elderly who for health and age must use more electrical energy to make life bearable. Cattle in the fields require water to be hauled as natural water sources have disappeared. I cannot overstate the effects of this drought on everyone and everything in this county. Virtually all rural areas in the county rely on wells or local water sources often requiring water to be boiled to make it safe.
Categories: Agriculture, Energy, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Maverick County, TX

Title: Agricultural income in Bastrop County fell roughly $37 million in 2011
Description: Agricultural income in Bastrop County fell to just under $23 million in 2011, down roughly $37 million from 2010, due to drought, according to the county AgriLife extension agent.  Income from corn and vegetables fell by $300,000 each; cotton production was down by $140,000; pecan production declined by at least $1 million; and hay production dropped by $31.3 million.  Agricultural activities usually generate $50 to $60 million annually.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 20, 2012
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Wildlife affected by drought in Aransas County, Texas
Description: We have mulitiple bird baths & feeders in the yard they are empty daily now as to the would not empty for 4 to 5 days. Have had several birds,squirels on our porch landing on the humming bird feeders trying to get water of an evening when I am arriving home. They do not scatter they just watch me... their desire for water is greater than their fear of a human. I know that the animals are praying when they see me, that I will get them water before I even go into the house. As for the surrounding area in Rockport the wetlands are dry, not seeing the normal spoonbills, cranes etc. for a couple of weeks. The cows next door are knocking down fences to find water and grass that they need. The oak trees here are very stressed as well. Seeing more little dust devils around here.
Places: Aransas County, TX

Title: Excessive fire activity in Brazos County, Texas
Description: The precinct 2 fire department in Brazos County responded to more fire calls in January 2011 than they did during the first six months of 2010, according to the fire chief.  Bryan-College station Eagle (Texas), July 3, 2011
Places: Brazos County, TX

Title: About 41,500 acres blackened in Pecos County, Texas
Description: Roughly 41,500 acres have burned in Pecos County since the beginning of the year.  The Cannon Fire scorched 9,200 acres with 40 percent containment.  The Little Smokey fire expanded to 6,000 acres and was 20 percent contained.  The DRH fire blackened 26,200 acres with 50 percent containment.  Odessa American (Texas), April 15, 2011
Places: Pecos County, TX

Title: Restrictions on outdoor burning in Hays County
Description: The Hays County Commissioners Court enacted restrictions on outdoor burning for 90 days in unincorporated portions of the county due to dry conditions and high fire danger.  People must have the permission of the Fire Marshal to do any burning, but may burn trash without permission if they use a screen to prevent sparks from escaping.  On December 21, the Keetch-Byram Drought Index was 532.  Austin American-Statesman (TX), Dec. 21
Places: Hays County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Travis County, Texas
Description: Travis County has a ban on outdoor burning through March 9 due to the drought conditions.  Most counties in the western two-thirds of the state have fire restrictions.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Feb. 28, 2011 and the Texas Forest Service website.  The burn ban remained in effect for Travis County through November 16, 2011.  The Travis County Commissioners Court renewed the ban again as it has done since December 14, 2010.  The ban was lifted for three days in February.  Across Texas, 231 counties have bans on outdoor burning, according to the Texas Forest Service.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Oct. 18, 2011.  The burn ban for Travis County was rescinded.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), Dec. 1, 2011
Places: Travis County, TX

Title: Trees lost in Hays County, Texas
Description: Lost two live oak trees, one 85 years old, the other 75 years old.  Also lost a cedar elm, about 25 years old.  Grass that normally reaches 3-4 feet in height was only 5 inches tall.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Buda 4.6 WNW on 12/13/2011
Places: Hays County, TX

Title: Bexar County commissioners adopt burn ban for unincorporated portions of county
Description: Bexar County commissioners adopted a  burn ban for unincorporated portions of county for the next 90 days due to the exceptionally dry conditions that have increased the risk of wildfires.  San Antonio Express-News (TX), Dec. 8
Places: Bexar County, TX

Title: Burn ban in Brown County, Texas
Description: Brown County commissioners renewed a burn ban for the past six months because dry conditions made outdoor burning too dangerous.  After rain fell and lowered the Keetch-Byram Drought Index, the commissioners finally opted not to renew the ban in favor of allowing personal and agricultural burns to be done.  Abilene Reporter-News (Texas), May 9, 2011
Places: Brown County, TX

Title: Hard red winter wheat struggling in western Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas
Description: Some hard red winter wheat in western Kansas, Cimarron and Texas counties in Oklahoma and farmland west of Amarillo, Texas did not germinate or just barely came up before winter arrived because there was not enough rainfall.  The delayed growth of the wheat means that, even if rain falls to stimulate plant growth, the plants will develop their root systems rather than produce more shoots as the wheat needs to do to have a good yield.   Wheat that did grow was ravaged by very cold temperatures.  OklahomaFarmReport.com (Okla.), March 4, 2011
Places: Cheyenne County, KS, Decatur County, KS, Finney County, KS, Ford County, KS, Gove County, KS, Graham County, KS, Grant County, KS, Gray County, KS, Greeley County, KS, Hamilton County, KS, Haskell County, KS, Hodgeman County, KS, Kearny County, KS, Lane County, KS, Logan County, KS, Morton County, KS, Ness County, KS, Norton County, KS, Rawlins County, KS, Scott County, KS, Seward County, KS, Sheridan County, KS, Sherman County, KS, Stanton County, KS, Stevens County, KS, Thomas County, KS, Trego County, KS, Wallace County, KS, Wichita County, KS, Cimarron County, OK, Texas County, OK, Dallam County, TX, Hartley County, TX, Moore County, TX, Oldham County, TX, Potter County, TX, Sherman County, TX

Title: Wildlife seeking food and water in Llano County, Texas
Description: The drought continues...with no end in sight. It will take a lot of rain for the land to recover. I grew up during the 40's-50's drought in South Texas, and in some ways this has been more severe on the wildlife. I have been feeding birds and deer on my 5-ac for 13 years. The deer population has increased from 4-6 to 9-12. In the last few months I have had to go to multiple evening feedings of a high protein deer food and corn 5:1. Different than the 1:1 just a year ago. Besides no grasses there have been no weeds, flowers, or fruit on the Mexican persimmon (a favorite of the deer, 'coons, etc.) My feed store bill has gone from the normal $30/month to $80/month and increasing still. My well production has declined; I have hooked up a 300-gal tank and on-demand pump for the house. For outside, I am getting water in 65-gal barrels from friends with good wells, and sump-pumping into my rainwater tanks so I can use that system. I put out about 20 gallons of water out for wildlife daily. (A small tank for the deer, bird bath, and 16-in. saucers on the ground for rabbits, birds, and occasionally a snake or some other critter...lately a skunk (that broke into my screened porch.) I raised only 4 tomato plants in the garden, and have lost my asparagus 'patch' of 10 years. I will have a new well dug this month or next...if I hit water, I will complete the well when either my current well goes dry, or I get the money saved for completion. In Rio Llano (as in the county) wells have gone dry, or are low producing, and animals particularly skunks seem to be plentiful around areas where water is being put out for livestock, etc. The City is at stage 4 so all the yards and most outside vegetation is drying. The Llano River has stopped flowing on occasion...which didn't even happen a few years ago during a prolonged dry spell. Since I am retired other than feed for wildlife and water concerns, I personally have not been impacted to a great extent. Rancher friends report that their weaned calves are at about 300lbs vs 500+lbs during normal years. Cattle and goats are being sold off with increasing frequency. All my feeding has allowed one of my does to raise twin fawns....most reports are that the does are raising only the strongest or just walking away.
Places: Llano County, TX

Title: Ponds drying up in Bastrop County, Texas
Description: This area between Bastrop and Smithville has been in a drought since Nov. 2010. I have 4 ponds and 1 has dried up completely and the other three are about 1/3 of their normal capacity. Several large pine trees and quite a few smaller oaks have died.
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Burn ban in effect for Taylor County, TX
Description: Commissioners in Taylor County have enacted a burn ban effective for 90 days. This is a preventative measure in case predicted dryer than normal condition actually occur. Reporter News (TX), Nov. 10, 2010.  Update:  The ban was ended early at the behest of the Taylor County Commissioners Court.  Abilene Reporter-News (TX), Feb. 3, 2011.
Places: Taylor County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 2/16/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Foard County received approximately .9 inch of moisture accumulation from the snow storms the first couple weeks of February. Although quite welcome the accumulation was not nearly enough to significantly affect our moisture shortage of the past several months. No running water resulted from the accumulation and annually seeded small grain forage is of no grazing value this year. Farm pond levels are in pretty good shape.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 5/4/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Foard County continues to suffer extreme drought conditions. Little moisture fall has been recorded since October 2010. Annually seeded forage crops produced little or no grazing this year. Farm ponds are dry or drying up. Rainfall is approximately 84% below normal this calendar year and 82% below normal since October 18th.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 5/18/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Foard County continues to suffer extreme drought conditions. Annually seeded forage crops produced little or no grazing this year. Farm ponds are dry or drying up. Total recorded moisture-fall since November 1, 2010 has been 1.49 inches, which is 82% below normal. Dry conditions, combined with almost daily high winds and above normal temperatures, have resulted in the driest November through April since 1955 and the driest November through May in recorded history.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Forage crops produce little; farm ponds drying up in Foard County, Texas
Description: Foard County continues to suffer extreme drought conditions. Annually seeded forage crops produced little or no grazing this year. Many farm ponds have been dry long enough that they are being ‘cleaned out’ and many more continue drying up. Total recorded moisture-fall since November 1, 2010 has been 3.42 inches, which is 82% below normal. Dry conditions, hot winds, and well above normal temperatures, have resulted in the driest November through July in recorded history. On August 16th the area broke a 31 year old record of number of days above 100 degrees with our 81st day. The forecast indicates at least 7 more days of the same. The county has elevated its drought level to #3, which means outside watering is only permitted 1 day a week and only for livestock.
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 6/1/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Foard County, Texas, continues to suffer extreme drought conditions. Annually seeded forage crops (Wheat, Oats, Triticale, etc.) produced no grazing in May this year. Farm ponds continue to dry up. Total recorded moisture-fall since November 1, 2010 has been 3.31 inches, which is 77% below normal. Dry conditions, combined with almost daily high winds and above normal temperatures, have resulted in the driest November through April since 1955 and the driest November through May in recorded history.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 5/26/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Foard County continues to suffer extreme drought conditions. Annually seeded forage crops produced little or no grazing this year. Farm ponds are dry or drying up. Total recorded moisture-fall since November 1, 2010 has been 3.47 inches, which is 71% below normal. Dry conditions, combined with almost daily high winds and above normal temperatures, have resulted in the driest November through April since 1955 and the driest November through May in recorded history.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Lubbock, Texas farmer irrigated and gave up on saving corn
Description: A farmer near Lubbock spent $28,000 to irrigate 500 acres before giving up on irrigating 75 acres of corn in favor of using the water on crops that were more likely to withstand the drought.  Drought and heat eventually killed the unirrigated corn, which amounts to one-sixth of the land he has cultivated.  The wasted water and expense troubles him.  GO San Angelo/San Angelo Standard Times (TX), July 27, 2011
Places: Lubbock County, TX

Title: Many producers liquidating their herds in Foard County, Texas
Description: Foard County continues to suffer extreme drought conditions. No spring or summer sorghum forage was produced in the county this year. A small amount of irrigated alfalfa was cut very early in the season, but record high temperatures this summer have been a significant deterrent to normal hay production. Fall small grain planting season is here and many fields have not been plowed since fall 2010. 85% of the county’s stock ponds are dry or unusable. Approximately 50% of stock has been liquidated due to lack of water and/or forage. Total recorded moisture-fall since January 1, 2011 has been 3.7 inches, 82% below normal. Dry conditions, combined with almost daily winds and record breaking triple digit temperatures, has resulted in the driest November through August in recorded history and easily the driest calendar year on record.
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire, Water Supply & Quality impact from Government submitted on 2/24/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.The county was blessed with a bit of a sprinkle early this AM and though no measureable accumulation was received, we are encouraged at least by the increased humidity. Conditions continue to be of great concern for small grain producers and grass fire danger is at an extreme level.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Government submitted on 7/13/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Foard County continues to suffer extreme drought conditions. Annually seeded forage crops produced little or no grazing this year. Farm ponds continue to dry up. Total recorded moisture-fall since November 1, 2010 has been 3.42 inches, which is 79.7% below normal. Dry conditions, combined with almost daily high winds in June and above normal temperatures, have resulted in the driest November through June since in recorded history. Daily high temperatures have been in the triple digits for over 30 consecutive days, with most being over 105 degrees.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Foard County, TX

Title: Rancher fillling water tanks for cattle daily in Austin County, Texas
Description: Drought began last fall. Cattle pond has been empty for 3 months. Filling water cattle tanks daily with several hundred gallons. Pasture grass in very poor condition to no grass condition. Supplement feeding ongoing daily. Large trees 200 years old in the area now dead. Burn burns since last fall. Area wildlife under severe conditions as well.
Places: Austin County, TX

Title: Llama rescue operation facing difficulties in midst of drought in Kerr County, Texas
Description: We rescue llamas and have a non-profit established. Because of the drought, wells are drying up, hay prices are higher, and feed prices. Donations are down as others are impacted because they have to purchase hay/feed. What would normally be pasture is just bare dirt. The number of llamas needing rescue is at an all-time high as ranches/farms are closing their operations due to the cost of care of animals. We also have poultry for pest control and eggs. The predators/wildlife do not have their normal feed supply so the predators are eating more poultry to survive and other wildlife are eating the feed we put out for our animals.
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Kerr County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Public submitted on 6/9/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Farms plant crops and pray only to see their crops burn in the 103 degree heat. Crops and pastures are drying up, water is scarce. Hay that was harvested last year was enough to last 3 winters, all of it has been exhausted because there is poor grazing land conditions for the cattle to graze on due to lack of moisture and/or fire.Impact Source:  PublicMore Information:  http://www.myfoxlubbock.com/news/local/story/Ag-Day-extreme-drought/Y9nkTriAJUewfhQmN_3Fng.cspx
Places: Hale County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire impact from Public submitted on 1/11/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.We have had very little rainfall since September 2010. Small grain crops, such as wheat and oats, are failing. What has come up cannot be grazed. Producers are feeding cattle.There is an abundance of dry grass throughout the county. With the shortage of moisture, fire danger is high.Impact Source:  Public
Places: Eastland County, TX

Title: Society & Public Health impact from Public submitted on 6/17/2011
Description: Local firworks are cancelled because of the drought. (User-submitted media report; http://www.myfoxlubbock.com/news/local/story/fireworks-4th-july-festival-broadway-lubbock/bxxAKK7ll0WOc_b5d3iwPg.cspx)Impact Source:  PublicMore Information:  http://www.myfoxlubbock.com/news/local/story/fireworks-4th-july-festival-broadway-lubbock/bxxAKK7ll0WOc_b5d3iwPg.cspx
Places: Hale County, TX

Title: Drought taking toll on Bastrop County, Texas
Description: The seasonal creek which borders our land is dry, and pond and tanks in our area are nearly dried up. Wildflowers were very sparse this spring. Pines and oaks on our wooded property are dying. Grasses are sparse in our meadows. Hot dry winds have caused damage to vegetables in our garden, and we are losing plants even drought-tolerant plants in our landscaped areas. A local small vegetable stand had very little to sell this year, and closed early for the season. A burn ban is in effect, as well as a fireworks ban. We have already had one small fire on an adjacent property, and the danger of fire is extreme. Deer are coming to drink from a tub of water in our meadow, frequently in the middle of the afternoon. This is one of the few sources of water in the vicinity, since our neighbor's tank is nearly dry. All day long, birds are concentrating around our birdbath, and we are seeing many more visitors to our birdfeeders than we usually do this time of year.
Categories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bastrop County, TX

Title: Wildlife, homes affected by drought in Williamson County, Texas
Description: Deciduous trees are losing their leaves. Ground cover vegetation, both lawn grass and unmaintained areas with weeds and grasses, has turned brown and is brittle under foot. Walking across my brown lawn reminds me of walking across ground that is covered with snow that has refrozen and crunches when stepped on. The impatiens my wife planted finally died off last week despite watering them sufficiently to keep them alive without over watering them to the point of burning their leaves. This is the first time that has ever happened. Wildlife has few sources of water. I have observed Starlings and Grackles waiting in trees around parking lots for cars to pull out of a parking space so that the birds can get a drink from the little puddle of water created from the car's air conditioning. I refill the bird bath in my yard twice per day. I have seen rabbits standing on their hind legs to get a drink from the bird bath. I had never seen a rabbit drink water in my 50 years until last week. I go through 100 pounds of bird seed for my bird feeder each month. I have a high concentration of heavy black clay in my soil. Despite watering as much as possible within the confines of the mandatory water restrictions we are under, I have not been able to prevent large cracks from opening in my back yard. Some cracks are 2" wide with no measurable bottom to the crack. An 8' rod can be inserted in the cracks to the full 8' depth without hitting bottom. My concrete driveway has sections that have risen (or lowered) by as much as 2". Using a rubber mallet produces a hollow sound in some sections of the driveway. Cracks have developed in most of the concrete slabs on my driveway. One slab has a crack to full depth and a corner of the slab representing about 20% of the slab has broken. When my wife pulls into the driveway I can watch the slabs move up and down. My back door leading to my deck behind the house has gotten to where I won't open it anymore because it sticks so bad. I fear I may have a cracked foundation (slab). Electricity costs for air conditioning needed due to the record breaking high temperatures have increased by about 10% from past years. My water bill exceeded $100 last month for the first time ever due to watering my lawn.
Places: Williamson County, TX

Title: Low water level of Toledo Bend on Texas/Louisiana border led to $4 million revenue shortfall
Description: The Sabine River Authority lost more than $4 million in revenue during the last fiscal year because there was too little water in Toledo Bend for hydroelectric power generation.  Electricity sales were anticipated to bring in $5 million in the present year’s budget, but the executive director of the SRA acknowledged that the probability of that happening is low.  Alexandria Town Talk (La.), Oct. 25, 2011
Places: De Soto Parish, LA, Sabine Parish, LA, Newton County, TX, Sabine County, TX, Shelby County, TX

Title: Power generation low at Lake Texoma
Description: Power generation at Lake Texoma has remained at about 15 percent of average, or 1.2 hours per day, since May 2012 to conserve water in the lake.  The generation totals for the last three fiscal years, from October 2010 through September 2013, have been the lowest since the project began in 1950.  Lake Texoma recently entered Drought Level 2 on Nov. 6 when the lake receded to 612 feet, or 77 percent of conservation pool storage, so power generation is likely to remain low in the near future.North Texas e-News (Fannin, Texas), Nov. 6, 2013
Places: Bryan County, OK, Johnston County, OK, Marshall County, OK, Cooke County, TX, Grayson County, TX

Title: Producers selling cattle; wells going dry in Gonzales County, Texas
Description: No rain for two months. 85 days over 100 degrees. Hottest July, hottest August, hottest summer on record. Only 12 inches of rain in the past year. That's a shortfall of 26 1/2 inches or 70% below normal. Already worst drought in history. Fires burning all around. Forecast = La Nina, no rain to speak of until probably next April. We have no grass, three ponds dried up, there's no hay available. We're struggling to try to feed something to our cows. Everyone is selling all their cattle around us and expect we will have to, too. Wells going dry all around us. The cities of San Antonio and Austin are fighting it out over which one can steal all our underground water first, and government water districts are conspiring with them with rules that prevent farmers from digging wells down to the deep aquifer. They can't actually sell our water but they collect a handsome "transport fee" for all the water taken. We will be having devastating subsidence on top of all the other drought consequences. We haven't got a chance.
Places: Gonzales County, TX

Title: Hudspeth County, Texas, forced to sell cattle, no pasture grass for livestock
Description: 2010 was the last year we had beneficial rain. We have had less than 10 inches of rain in over two and a half years. Most rain has been light showers and very spotty. We fear some of our grass has died while wells have gone dry and our springs have quit flowing. We made no grass in 2012, and we forced to lease a ranch for a portion of our cattle. We sold over a third of our cows and many cows did not breed back.  We have been feeding year round. This month we received some isolated rain, which will help us significantly.  The runoff had greened up grass in the draws and we are hopeful we will receive more.  If it does not rain this summer we can not survive another year.  This drought has been devastating; impacting our cattle and wildlife.  It is impossible to put a dollar amount of the impact.  We have lost hunting income, forage, water sources and suffered significant wind erosion of land.  We are very hopeful however conditions are going to improve.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Van Horn 9.0 SW on 6/25/2013
Places: Hudspeth County, TX

Title: Agriculture impact from Public submitted on 4/14/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.The lack of rain has significantly reduced our prospects for grain crops, no spring grass is comming, and we have nothing for cattle to eat. Ground conditions are not any where close to what they should be in order to plant hay, or grass.  We spent $425.00 ac. on fertilizer and it has not rained a drop since Feb. 2011.  The conditions in this county is SEVERE!!!Impact Source:  PublicMonetary Loss:  Currently up to $500,000
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Forage costs double; cattle herds stressed in Guadalupe County, Texas
Description: We are halfway through the 10th month of the current drought, with a total rainfall to date of 9.78 inches, which equals about 39 percent of normal rainfall for this location. The drought is worsening, as agriculturally significant rainfalls (i.e. over one inch in 24 hours) occurred mainly in the early second and fourth months. The only exception to this pattern was a 1.65-inch rain recorded in the ninth month. This current drought follows a one-year period of normal rainfall. Before that, this station suffered greatly from the effects of a two-year drought that began Sept. 5, 2007 and lasted until Sept. 7, 2009. From September 2007 through August 2008 rainfall totaled 19.19 inches at this station, and from September 2008 through August 2009 rainfall totaled 15.94 inches, for a two-year total of 35.13 inches, or just over 50 percent of normal. The toll on Plants and Wildlife for that two-year drought could be estimated at more than $10,000 to $20,000 because of the loss of several hundred mature trees on a 40-acre property in the Post Oak Savannah ecosystem of Texas. The losses included several hickory trees estimated to be 100 years old or older, plus numerous post oaks, blackjack oaks and Shumard oaks. In the current 10-month drought, two out of three stock ponds went dry in the eighth month. The main impact, to date, is the doubling of the cost of forage (hay) to sustain a small herd of cattle and three horses; stress on the cattle herd, contributing to the death of one cow; and necessary culling of the herd, forcing the sale of otherwise healthy and productive mama cows.
Places: Guadalupe County, TX

Title: Wildlife affected by drought in Bandera County, Texas
Description: I chose 9-8-2010 as the start date as that was last time we received almost an inch of rain. Since the first of the year, including todays rain, we have received 4.07 inches of rain. The drought has not ended. Oak trees are dying. The grass never turned green this year. We are lucky enough to have the last flowing creek (Mill Creek) run through our property. It continues to trickle over the dam. Many of us in this area are dependent on Mill Creek for drinking and household water, so it is essential for our ability to live in our homes. We find more dead fawns than we have seen live ones, and no turkey poults have been sighted. We are a rural area and are blessed (that is the only word I can think of that applies) that there have been no fires.
Categories: Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Bandera County, TX

Title: Wilson County, Texas, increased price of water, water restrictions
Description: All communities are at a minimum Stage II drought condition.  Landscaping has suffered drastically, as have all outdoor activities.  Regular watering has not been allowed in three years.  The cost of water per gallon has skyrocketed, as well.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #La Vernia 3.6 SSW on 5/9/2014
Categories: Agriculture, Relief, Response & Restrictions, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Wilson County, TX

Title: Local lake levels low, high temperatures affecting activity in Victoria County, Texas
Description: We just broke the record for most 100 plus degree days in a row. The record was set in 1911 at 16 but we just had an offical 101 today which puts us at 17 days continuous and are forecast to get 100 plus at least the next four days. I am inland from the Gulf of Mexico about 25 miles and normally the sea breeze keeps us cool and we only get high temperatures when the wind is from the southwest off of Mexico desert. We have had 7.63 inches of rain this year with our normal rainfall around 40 inches. The grass is dead with large cracks, have to be careful when walking out in yard. The trees have dropped about half their leaves because of the lack of water. The local lake is about half full and the boat ramps are closed. I am seeing alot of animals and birds using my gold fish pond for water. With the heat index near 109 every day work is slowed way down and people are not going out so business is slow. We are in the highest rating of drought and have had a burn ban for months now. The forecast is for little or no rain thru September and above normal temps. I saw a lot more irrigation of crops this year than in the past. The harvest this year was poor due to the quality of the crops. Electric use is way up due to the high temps. We also have set three record high-low temps with the temps at night around 80 degrees.
Categories: Plants & Wildlife, Society & Public Health, Tourism & Recreation
Places: Victoria County, TX

Title: Low water levels and wells running dry in Kendall County, Texas
Description: Water table level is at record low which means that water wells are going dry. Mine is still ok. No gardening or landscaping due to lack of water. Daily 20-30 mph winds dry out soil faster than can be watered. One local water company has banned landscape watering entirely. Heat wave of 100 degree days adds to problems and makes people do less activities. Creeks and ponds are dry. River close by is at 1.5ft and moving at 12cfs. Inflow to a large lake is now less than outflow thus lake level is now falling. Some large area lakes are down by 30 feet or more. As stated in daily report, junipers are dying in large numbers. Big increase in grass and brush fires. Only hope for relief will come from the tropics.CoCoRaHS Report from Boerne 8.5 NNW on 6/18/2011
Places: Kendall County, TX

Title: Agriculture, Fire impact from Government submitted on 4/12/2011
Description: The following report was submitted.Due to lack of rainfall pastures are in severe condition and stock ponds are drying up.  No grass is going and wildfires are increasing daily.  The county has not had any significant rain since September 2010.  The county is in an extreme drought condition and producers are having to supplement hay and some have begun to sell off their herds.Impact Source:  Government
Places: Stephens County, TX

Title: Drought eliminated honey production in Nueces County, Texas
Description: A beekeeper in Calallen, northwest of Corpus Christi stated that drought prevented his bees from making honey the past two years.  Without rain to grow flowers, the bees do not produce honey.  He noted that he lost half of his bees due to the current drought.  Bryan-College Station Eagle (Texas), May 6, 2012
Places: Nueces County, TX

Title: Persistent drought leads to herd reductions in Young County, Texas
Description: Although the county has recieved some rain, conditions for livestock producers remain grim. Livestock producers are still having to reduce herd size due to lack of grass and feed sources. Tanks levels are still low and water remains a valuable commodity that is often being trucked in for livestock usage. High winds have already begun to reduce soil moisture levels and the rain was insufficient for row crop farmers to plant a viable crop. Drought conditions are persistent.
Places: Young County, TX

Title: Brewster County, Texas, stressed vegetation, forced to cut cow herd due to lack of feed, burn ban
Description: Very little precipitation during 2013 water year.  So far in the 2014 water year beginning 10/01/2014 there has been slight precipitation and more wind than ordinary.  We had extreme icing conditions for a five day period with 20 power poles snapped and complete power outage during the five day period.  Also several extended hard freezes (2-4 day duration), and a very late hard freeze (20 F) in late April.  The late freeze killed the leaves of most mesquite bushes, many shrubs and trees.  Mesquite is coming back from the base and most damaged trees and shrubs are leafing out again.  A few trees and shrubs might have been killed.  The combination of extreme windy, dry conditions with cold temperatures have stressed all vegetation.  There is very little if any grass growing.  Livestock are being fed hay, cake and grazing on whatever they can find.  We are being vigilant removing poisonous plants from pastures to prevent livestock deaths.  We have been forced to shut down our swine operation due to the increased operating costs from the drought.  We have cut the cow herd by 75% because of lack of feed.  The wild deer look horrible, we are letting them eat with the other livestock to help them out.  The numbers of mature Rio Grande Turkeys on the ranch are diminishing.  We have not observed a clutch of young in the last two years.  We have not seen quail for six years.  We have quit watering our landscape with the exception of a few select trees and shrubs.  Our well began sucking air during Summer 2012 while we were attempting to irrigate some areas of good native grass for the livestock.  We have not irrigated since and have not had any further problems with the well.  Brewster county has had a burn ban in place for over four years.  It has been briefly lifted during that time when we have snow or a lengthy wet period.  But most people do not burn even then and we all have large piles of brush that we will someday burn or just let decompose.  CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Alpine 7.9 SE on 5/7/2014
Categories: Agriculture, Fire, Plants & Wildlife, Relief, Response & Restrictions
Places: Brewster County, TX

Title: Producer sells some breeding stock, continues to buy supplemental feed in Brewster County, Texas
Description: We have had to sell some of our breeding cattle and pigs, keeping only the best because of the huge increase in feed prices and lack of grass.  We continue to buy hay and supplemental feed for the remaining cattle and horses at a much higher cost for lesser quality feed.   We have lost most of the grass in the pastures and almost half of the trees have died.  We have spent a lot of time and money pulling out dead trees and trying to prevent severe erosion and gullies forming when we do get rain.  With the drought, the ground water is not being replenished and our well is not supplying water as it historically has.  We have sucked air a few times while attempting to water the remaining windbreak trees around the farm and keep some of the pasture grass from dying.  We keep three thousand gallons of water in stock tanks available for fire fighting and for deer, turkeys and other wildlife to drink.CoCoRaHS Report from Station #Alpine 7.9 SE on 4/30/2012
Places: Brewster County, TX

Title: Producers selling cattle, wells going dry in Real County, Texas
Description: Wells are going dry. Even with some rain there is still a severe drought. My neighbors have sold off all their beef cattle. Corn crops are 60% of usual.
Places: Real County, TX

Title: Frustration with the Lower Colorado River Authority's management of water during dry years in central Texas
Description: Many residents and Austin city officials feel that the Lower Colorado River Authority should have managed the Highland Lakes differently since 2008 to conserve more water, according to the Austin American-Statesman.  When Lake Buchanan and Lake Travis fall to 30 percent of capacity, Austin will enact more stringent water restrictions.  The only worse drought the region has experienced was from 1947 to 1957.  Austin American-Statesman (Texas), July 21, 2013
Categories: Society & Public Health, Water Supply & Quality
Places: Burnet County, TX, Llano County, TX, Travis County, TX
